ARCH2011.subject: ARCH
ARCH2011.name: Arch Design Studio I
ARCH2011.description: Elementary design exercises exploring fundamental issues of form and space through analysis of architectural elements and compositions and their use in creative problem solving.

ARCH2012.subject: ARCH
ARCH2012.name: Arch Design Studio II
ARCH2012.description: Elementary design exercises focusing upon the compositional integration of building and site through the creative assimilation of programmatic, technical, and contextual requirements.

ARCH2111.subject: ARCH
ARCH2111.name: History of Arch I
ARCH2111.description: Architectural history from antiquity through the eighteenth century emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.

ARCH2112.subject: ARCH
ARCH2112.name: History of Arch II
ARCH2112.description: Architectural history during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.

ARCH2115.subject: ARCH
ARCH2115.name: Modern Arch & Art
ARCH2115.description: A brief survey of architecture and art in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including a discussion of related influences on developments in those fields.

ARCH2211.subject: ARCH
ARCH2211.name: Construction Tech I
ARCH2211.description: Introduction to building anatomy, technical and expressive characteristics of materials and their organizational assembly.

ARCH2472.subject: ARCH
ARCH2472.name: Arch Modeling & Media 2
ARCH2472.description: Intermediate approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

ARCH2474.subject: ARCH
ARCH2474.name: Arch Modeling & Media 3
ARCH2474.description: Advanced approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

ARCH2698.subject: ARCH
ARCH2698.name: Research Assistantship
ARCH2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

ARCH2699.subject: ARCH
ARCH2699.name: Undergraduate Research
ARCH2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

ARCH3011.subject: ARCH
ARCH3011.name: Arch Design Studio III
ARCH3011.description: Intermediate architectural design projects emphasizing the functional priorities and expressive potential of building technologies through studio problems of varying programmatic and contextual complexity.

ARCH3012.subject: ARCH
ARCH3012.name: Arch Design Studio IV
ARCH3012.description: Intermediate architectural design projects exploring the inter-relationships of various programmatic models, normative building types, and technological themes within specific physical, urban, and cultural contexts.

ARCH3135.subject: ARCH
ARCH3135.name: City Literacy
ARCH3135.description: The course frames the city as material and social space, focusing on everyday experience in exemplary cities to explore how they are conceived and negotiated.

ARCH3231.subject: ARCH
ARCH3231.name: Environmental Systems I
ARCH3231.description: Human physiology, the occupation of space, and principles of sustainability. Micro-climate, energy consumption, thermal loading, passive solar strategies, daylighting, optics, and acoustics.

ARCH3241.subject: ARCH
ARCH3241.name: Fund of Structures
ARCH3241.description: Physics of structure: principles of statics, strengths of materials, and the dynamic forces acting upon them.

ARCH4011.subject: ARCH
ARCH4011.name: Arch Design Studio V
ARCH4011.description: Advanced studies in architectural design emphasizing application of analytical, conceptual, and representational skills within projects that engage and problematize urban context culturally, ecologically, and technologically.

ARCH4012.subject: ARCH
ARCH4012.name: Arch Design Studio VI
ARCH4012.description: Advanced studies in architectural design emphasizing application of analytical, conceptual, and representational skills within projects that engage and problematize context culturally, ecologically, and technologically.

ARCH4107.subject: ARCH
ARCH4107.name: Intro to Historic Preser
ARCH4107.description: This course provides an overview of the history, philosophy, organization, current legislation, policies, and practice of historic preservation.

ARCH4109.subject: ARCH
ARCH4109.name: Arch and Minimalism
ARCH4109.description: This course examines the influence of "minimalism," the 1960s art phenomenon, upon architecture culture and production from 1968-present.

ARCH4110.subject: ARCH
ARCH4110.name: Public Space
ARCH4110.description: This course addresses questions concerning present-day configurations of public space as a platform for analysis of the contemporary city.

ARCH4112.subject: ARCH
ARCH4112.name: Arch in Georgia
ARCH4112.description: A field study and archival research on the architecture of the state of Georgia outside of Atlanta.

ARCH4113.subject: ARCH
ARCH4113.name: Renaissance&Manner Arch
ARCH4113.description: Investigation of the history and theory of Renaissance and Mannerist architecture with a primary emphasis on Italy.

ARCH4114.subject: ARCH
ARCH4114.name: Medieval Architecture
ARCH4114.description: Investigations of the architecture of Medieval Europe with an emphasis on English and French Romanesque and Gothic, including towns and castles.

ARCH4115.subject: ARCH
ARCH4115.name: Intro Classical Design
ARCH4115.description: An introduction to the principles of Classical and traditional architectural design through readings, discussions, and site visits with Classical architects.

ARCH4117.subject: ARCH
ARCH4117.name: Arts and Crafts Arch
ARCH4117.description: Investigations in the theory, design, and building methods of English and American architects associated with the Arts and Crafts Movement.

ARCH4118.subject: ARCH
ARCH4118.name: American Academic Arch
ARCH4118.description: Investigations of the history and theory of late nineteenth- and twentieth-century classicism in America.

ARCH4119.subject: ARCH
ARCH4119.name: Arch-Frank Lloyd Wright
ARCH4119.description: Investigations on the life and work of Frank Lloyd Wright.

ARCH4120.subject: ARCH
ARCH4120.name: Atlanta Architecture
ARCH4120.description: Investigations through lectures, reading, and research of the history of Atlanta architecture and significant architectural firms from the city's founding to the present.

ARCH4123.subject: ARCH
ARCH4123.name: European Modernism
ARCH4123.description: Survey of European architecture from Art Nouveau to LeCorbusier.

ARCH4124.subject: ARCH
ARCH4124.name: Hist of Arch in the U.S.
ARCH4124.description: History investigations of architecture within the continental United States from the colonial period to the present.

ARCH4125.subject: ARCH
ARCH4125.name: French Arch
ARCH4125.description: History of French architecture from Ledoux to LeCorbusier with special emphasis on Paris.

ARCH4126.subject: ARCH
ARCH4126.name: Paris Urban History
ARCH4126.description: The social, cultural, urban, and architectural history of the city of Paris, from its founding until the present. Course offered in Paris only.

ARCH4127.subject: ARCH
ARCH4127.name: Intro to Art & Arch in Italy
ARCH4127.description: Required preparation for the COA Summer Program in Italy. The course includes the fundamentals of art and architecture, basic Italian language skills, and library research for required summer program projects.

ARCH4128.subject: ARCH
ARCH4128.name: Barcelona Architecture
ARCH4128.description: Architectural history of the city of Barcelona and its public spaces, with a focus on the major urban and architectural projects since 1850. Offered through the Studies Abroad Program.

ARCH4129.subject: ARCH
ARCH4129.name: Form and Narrative
ARCH4129.description: This theory course will involve an extended comparison between architecture and related art forms, especially painting, film, and writing.

ARCH4133.subject: ARCH
ARCH4133.name: Arch& Discourse Everyday
ARCH4133.description: Application of the concept of the everyday to architectural practice from perspectives of European social theory, American cultural landscape studies, and contemporary architectural theory.

ARCH4137.subject: ARCH
ARCH4137.name: Postwar Arch & Urbanism
ARCH4137.description: Introduction to the economic, social, political, cultural, and technological forces that shape architecture and cities in the United States after World War II.

ARCH4140.subject: ARCH
ARCH4140.name: Modern Arch Theory
ARCH4140.description: Introduction to modern and contemporary architectural theory and criticism, including writings and manifestoes, analyses, projects and buildings.

ARCH4142.subject: ARCH
ARCH4142.name: Dwelling Env Behav Des
ARCH4142.description: Explores scholarship and case studies from multiple disciplines relating to issues of place, community identity and memory, culturally constructed meaning, and appropriate use of resources.

ARCH4143.subject: ARCH
ARCH4143.name: Museums Hist Theo Des
ARCH4143.description: Investigates museums as manifestations of the construction and content of knowledge, the public mission of cultural and scientific institutions and the framing of visitors experience.

ARCH4151.subject: ARCH
ARCH4151.name: History of Urban Form
ARCH4151.description: History of the city as a collective work of architecture with an emphasis on the city's physical form and space. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 4151 and COA 6151.

ARCH4220.subject: ARCH
ARCH4220.name: Construction Tech II
ARCH4220.description: Integration, representation, and constructability of building assemblies and structural systems. Grading, drainage, foundations, structure, and enclosure in relation to building codes and principles of sustainability.

ARCH4225.subject: ARCH
ARCH4225.name: Reinvestigating Details
ARCH4225.description: Explores the role of the detail in contemporary architectural practice.

ARCH4227.subject: ARCH
ARCH4227.name: Architecture & Ecology
ARCH4227.description: Introduction to ecological design theory, research, and practice in architecture, including writings, criticism, and analyses of buildings and projects.

ARCH4231.subject: ARCH
ARCH4231.name: Environmental Systems II
ARCH4231.description: Active building systems design: artificial lighting, mechanical, electrical, communication, transportation systems. Case studies of integrated and sustainable building assemblies.

ARCH4251.subject: ARCH
ARCH4251.name: Structures I
ARCH4251.description: Gravity loads on building structures. Introduction to structural planning. Design of wood and steel structures. Properties of wood and architectural metals. Computer-based analysis of structures.

ARCH4252.subject: ARCH
ARCH4252.name: Structures II
ARCH4252.description: Lateral loads and lateral load resisting systems for building structures. Design and application of Portland cement concrete mixtures. Design of reinforced concrete structures. Building foundations.

ARCH4253.subject: ARCH
ARCH4253.name: Adv Structures Seminar
ARCH4253.description: Fundamentals of steel and concrete design and the computerized design of steel and concrete structural systems for multi-story buildings.

ARCH4303.subject: ARCH
ARCH4303.name: Programming & Bldg Eval
ARCH4303.description: Building programming and evaluation of building performance with respect to the aims of organizational users, policy development, and the process of planning and design decisions.

ARCH4305.subject: ARCH
ARCH4305.name: Cross-Cultural Practice
ARCH4305.description: This course will address the material culture of globalization and cultural diffusion, emphasizing the multicultural registers of work produced between and across geographical, cultural, and disciplinary boundaries.

ARCH4315.subject: ARCH
ARCH4315.name: Professional Practice
ARCH4315.description: Principles and framework of professional practice including ethics, legal climate, business practices and contracts, project process and management, office organization, and methods of building production.

ARCH4316.subject: ARCH
ARCH4316.name: Traditions of Practice
ARCH4316.description: Critical examination of architectural practice. Cultural derivation and technological transformation of various conventions of representation, construction, and design; speculation about future paradigms of architectural practice.

ARCH4330.subject: ARCH
ARCH4330.name: Clients and Users
ARCH4330.description: Theories and methods of architectural programming and evaluation.

ARCH4334.subject: ARCH
ARCH4334.name: Housing and Culture
ARCH4334.description: Examination of social, cultural, and behavioral issues as they influence the form of houses and housing.

ARCH4335.subject: ARCH
ARCH4335.name: Social Practice of Arch
ARCH4335.description: Introduction to theories and findings about human use and experience of architecture.

ARCH4411.subject: ARCH
ARCH4411.name: Intro to Visual Arts
ARCH4411.description: Orientation to issues of visual perception and representation of form and space through freehand drawing, composition, color, texture, mixed-media, and journal making.

ARCH4412.subject: ARCH
ARCH4412.name: Life Drawing
ARCH4412.description: Studio instruction in figure drawing from the live model with emphasis on the structure and dynamics of the human figure.

ARCH4413.subject: ARCH
ARCH4413.name: Collage Making
ARCH4413.description: Concepts of collage within art, architecture, and culture; manual and electronic approaches to two and three-dimensional collage making.

ARCH4414.subject: ARCH
ARCH4414.name: Represent in Watercolor
ARCH4414.description: Introductory course in the use of transparent watercolor for field painting and architectural representation. Theory of pigment characteristics in applied painting.

ARCH4415.subject: ARCH
ARCH4415.name: Photography I
ARCH4415.description: Introduction to studio, darkroom, and field photography with emphasis on composition, processing, and printing.

ARCH4416.subject: ARCH
ARCH4416.name: Photography II
ARCH4416.description: Advanced techniques in photography. Use of color, filters, four-by- five format cameras with emphasis on architectural photography.

ARCH4417.subject: ARCH
ARCH4417.name: Furnishing Buildings
ARCH4417.description: A course that focuses on schematic design development of furniture. The emphasis of this course is on conceptual development and material and structural clarity.

ARCH4698.subject: ARCH
ARCH4698.name: Research Assistantship
ARCH4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

ARCH4699.subject: ARCH
ARCH4699.name: Undergraduate Research
ARCH4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

ARCH4770.subject: ARCH
ARCH4770.name: Environmental Design
ARCH4770.description: Introduction to psychological concepts relevant to environmental design. Survey of selected methods for assessing human-made environments. Crosslisted with PSYC 4770.

ARCH4863.subject: ARCH
ARCH4863.name: Special Topics
ARCH4863.description: Topics of current interest in architecture.

ARCH6024.subject: ARCH
ARCH6024.name: Arch Core I Studio
ARCH6024.description: Foundation studies in architectural design emphasizing enalytical and analogical generative strategies applied to studio problems that engage architectural representation, composition, and fabrication. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6024 and ARCH 4021.

ARCH6026.subject: ARCH
ARCH6026.name: Arch Core II Studio
ARCH6026.description: Intermediate studies in architectural design emphasizing integrative design strategies that engage the programmatic, contextual, and constructed dimentions of architecure and its representations. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6026 and ARCH 4022.

ARCH6027.subject: ARCH
ARCH6027.name: Arch Core III Studio
ARCH6027.description: Intermediate studies in architectural design emphasizing integrative design strategies that engage the programmatic, contextual, and constructed dimensions of architecture and its representations. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6027 and ARCH 4023.

ARCH6051.subject: ARCH
ARCH6051.name: Arch Options Studio I
ARCH6051.description: Advance studion problems in Architecture emphasizing research and application in the areas of history and theory, urban and environmental design, culture and practice, electronic media, and construction technology.

ARCH6052.subject: ARCH
ARCH6052.name: Arch Options Studio II
ARCH6052.description: Advanced studio problems in architecure emphasizing research and application in the areas of history and theory, urban and environmental design, culture and practice, electronic media, and construction technology.

ARCH6069.subject: ARCH
ARCH6069.name: Advanced Arch Design I
ARCH6069.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

ARCH6070.subject: ARCH
ARCH6070.name: Advanced Arch Design II
ARCH6070.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

ARCH6071.subject: ARCH
ARCH6071.name: Arch Des & Res Studio I
ARCH6071.description: Advanced architectural design emphasizing innovation through applied research. Emerging methods of design generation/evaluation. Changing topics: healthcare, fabrication, urbanism, ecology, building performance, cultural institutions.

ARCH6072.subject: ARCH
ARCH6072.name: Arch Des & Res Studio 2
ARCH6072.description: Advanced architectural design emphasizing innovation through applied research. Emerging methods of design generation/evaluation. Changing topics: healthcare, fabrication, urbanism, ecology, building performance, cultural institutions.

ARCH6105.subject: ARCH
ARCH6105.name: Arch History I
ARCH6105.description: Architectural history from aniquity through the 18th century emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6105 and ARCH 4105 or ARCH 2111.

ARCH6106.subject: ARCH
ARCH6106.name: Arch History II
ARCH6106.description: Architectural history during the 19th and 20th centuries emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6106 and ARCH 4106 or ARCH 2112.

ARCH6107.subject: ARCH
ARCH6107.name: Intro to Historic Preser
ARCH6107.description: This course provides an overview of the history, philosophy, organization, current legislation, policies, and practice of historic preservation.

ARCH6109.subject: ARCH
ARCH6109.name: Arch and Minimalism
ARCH6109.description: This course examines the influence of "minimalism," the 1960s art phenomenon, upon architecture culture and production from 1968-present.

ARCH6110.subject: ARCH
ARCH6110.name: Public Space
ARCH6110.description: This course addresses questions concerning present-day configurations of public spaces as a platform for analysis of the contemporary city.

ARCH6112.subject: ARCH
ARCH6112.name: Islamic Arch & Urbanism
ARCH6112.description: Two-part survey of Asian architecture and urbanism (excluding East Asia). The Islamic world up to the 18th century: the Mughal, Raj, and post-independence periods in Indian subcontinent.

ARCH6113.subject: ARCH
ARCH6113.name: Hist Renaiss&Manner Arch
ARCH6113.description: Investigation of the history and theory of Renaissance and Mannerist architecture with a primary emphasis on Italy.

ARCH6114.subject: ARCH
ARCH6114.name: Arch&Discourse Everyday
ARCH6114.description: Application of the concept of the everyday to architectural practice from perspectives of European social theory, American cultural landscape studies, and contemporary architectural theory.

ARCH6115.subject: ARCH
ARCH6115.name: Intro Classical Design
ARCH6115.description: An introduction to the principles of Classical and traditional architectural design through readings, discussions, and site visits with Classical architects.

ARCH6117.subject: ARCH
ARCH6117.name: Arch-Arts&Crafts Movemnt
ARCH6117.description: Study of the theory, design, and construction of the "artistic" house as embodied in the English and American Arts and Crafts Movement and in related developments elsewhere.

ARCH6119.subject: ARCH
ARCH6119.name: FL Wright& His Influence
ARCH6119.description: Study of the life, work, and influence of Frank Lloyd Wright, including work of his apprentices and followers.

ARCH6120.subject: ARCH
ARCH6120.name: History of Atlanta Arch
ARCH6120.description: Study of the architecture of the Atlanta metro area.

ARCH6127.subject: ARCH
ARCH6127.name: Intro-Art& Arch in Italy
ARCH6127.description: Required preparation for the COA Summer Program in Italy. Includes the fundamentals of art and architecture; basic Italian language skills; library research for required summer program projects.

ARCH6129.subject: ARCH
ARCH6129.name: Form and Narrative
ARCH6129.description: This theory course will involve an extended comparison between architecture and related art forms, especially painting, film, and writing.

ARCH6135.subject: ARCH
ARCH6135.name: Arch Representation
ARCH6135.description: Systems of architectural representation and codes of thinking, drawing, and reading architecture.

ARCH6136.subject: ARCH
ARCH6136.name: Arch and Ideology
ARCH6136.description: Architecture and politics in Italy, Germany, and the Soviet Union between the wars.

ARCH6137.subject: ARCH
ARCH6137.name: Postwar Arch & Urbanism
ARCH6137.description: Introduction to the economic, social, political, cultural, and technological forces that shape architecture and cities in the United States after World War II.

ARCH6142.subject: ARCH
ARCH6142.name: Dwelling Env Behav Des
ARCH6142.description: Explores scholarship and case studies from multiple disciplines relating to issues of place, community identity and memory, culturally contstructed meaning, and appropriate use of resources.

ARCH6143.subject: ARCH
ARCH6143.name: Museums Hist Thry Design
ARCH6143.description: Investigates museums as manifestations of the construction and content of knowledge, the public mission of cultural and scientific institutions and the framing of visitors experience.

ARCH6151.subject: ARCH
ARCH6151.name: Theories of Urban Design
ARCH6151.description: Contemporary theories of urban design and their relationship to the contemporary city examined through architects' writings, urban projects, and interdisciplinary criticism.

ARCH6152.subject: ARCH
ARCH6152.name: Landscape Architecture
ARCH6152.description: History and theory of the designed landscape and garden from the ancient world to the present.

ARCH6153.subject: ARCH
ARCH6153.name: Hist&Theory-Modern City
ARCH6153.description: An examination of the evolution of the modern city in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries with particular reference to architectural, city planning, and urban design theories.

ARCH6154.subject: ARCH
ARCH6154.name: Intro to Urban Design
ARCH6154.description: Introduction of urban design ideas, research, and practice, examining traditional qualities of the American city and their possible applications in the contemporary city.

ARCH6155.subject: ARCH
ARCH6155.name: Contemp Arch in Europe
ARCH6155.description: A course on contemporary architecture and urban projects in Europe, including the architect's writings, published criticism, and analyses of the buildings and projects.

ARCH6160.subject: ARCH
ARCH6160.name: Race and Space
ARCH6160.description: This course examines the relationship between architecture - as social practice and as a labor market - and race in the United States.

ARCH6171.subject: ARCH
ARCH6171.name: Design Intention in Arch
ARCH6171.description: Reviews theories of interpretive criticism in architecture, and develops methodological approaches to interpreting criticizing, and formulating conceptual intent in architectural design.

ARCH6206.subject: ARCH
ARCH6206.name: Building Assemblies
ARCH6206.description: Structural and cladding systems integration, environmental control, and tectonic representation explored through historical and contemporary case studies and applied design solutions.

ARCH6209.subject: ARCH
ARCH6209.name: Building Enclosure
ARCH6209.description: Investigations of enclosure design from three perspectives (technology, form, and culture), analyzing relationships of the four Semperian elements and Alberti's three parts of the enclosure.

ARCH6210.subject: ARCH
ARCH6210.name: Architectonics
ARCH6210.description: The study of architecture of form from both an historical and a mathematical perspective. The formal theory is applied mathematics, group theory, combinatroics, as well as recent studies in the history of mathematics.

ARCH6215.subject: ARCH
ARCH6215.name: Contemp Arch&Constr Tech
ARCH6215.description: General exposure to questions pertaining to the production of building systems and assemblies through a series of case study projects by contemporary practicing architects.

ARCH6216.subject: ARCH
ARCH6216.name: Eco-Tectonics
ARCH6216.description: Strategies of ecologically sustainable design and construction and the role of the architect in the stewardship of the environment.

ARCH6218.subject: ARCH
ARCH6218.name: Material Logic of Arch
ARCH6218.description: Introduction to scientific and practical nature of architectural materials: soils, cements, metals, plastics, and glazing materials. Laboratory includes fabrication of, and experiments on, architectural materials.

ARCH6225.subject: ARCH
ARCH6225.name: Reinvestigating Details
ARCH6225.description: Explores the role of the detail in contemporary architectural practice.

ARCH6226.subject: ARCH
ARCH6226.name: Green Construction
ARCH6226.description: This course focuses on the means, methods, strategies, and technologies to improve the energy efficiency and performance of buildings, and to reduce the environmental impact of buildings.

ARCH6227.subject: ARCH
ARCH6227.name: Architecture + Ecology
ARCH6227.description: Introduction to ecological design theory, research, and practice in architecture, including writings, criticism, and analyses of buildings and projects.

ARCH6228.subject: ARCH
ARCH6228.name: Analyt Invest Urb Design
ARCH6228.description: Measures of urban and spatial form. Analysis of street connectivity. Models of space use and spatial congnition. Comparison and evaluation of design alternatives.

ARCH6229.subject: ARCH
ARCH6229.name: Construction Tech I
ARCH6229.description: Introduction to building anatomy, technical and expressive characteristics of materials and their organizational assembly. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6229 and ARCH 4219.

ARCH6230.subject: ARCH
ARCH6230.name: Construction Tech 2
ARCH6230.description: Integration, representation, and constructability of building assemblies and structural systems. Grading, drainage, foundations, structure, and enclosure in relation to building codes and principles of sustainability.

ARCH6241.subject: ARCH
ARCH6241.name: Bldg Simula Design Pract
ARCH6241.description: Learn to use mainstream simulation packages to support building design in domains of Energy, CFD, Lighting, Ventilation

ARCH6242.subject: ARCH
ARCH6242.name: Bldg Physics Modeling
ARCH6242.description: Survey of basic thermo-fluid energy and mass flows in buildings, the interrelations between these flows, physical system modeling, and implications for building performance goals.

ARCH6251.subject: ARCH
ARCH6251.name: Building Structures I
ARCH6251.description: Introduction to design and analysis of building structures and ordering of structural systems to resist gravity and lateral loads. Emphasis on wood structures.

ARCH6252.subject: ARCH
ARCH6252.name: Building Structures II
ARCH6252.description: Introduction to structural design and framing systems for steel and concrete with consideration of lateral loads and lateral load resisting systems.

ARCH6268.subject: ARCH
ARCH6268.name: Adv Arch, Cult & Behav
ARCH6268.description: Theories, models, methods and case studies linking architectural design to culture and behavior.

ARCH6271.subject: ARCH
ARCH6271.name: Healthcare Des Of Future
ARCH6271.description: Introduction to research-based approaches to integrated healthcare design innovation.

ARCH6303.subject: ARCH
ARCH6303.name: Urban Design Policy
ARCH6303.description: Introduction to urban design policy and practice across a range of scales including planning, architecture, landscape architecture, civil engineering, public policy and administration. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6303 and CP 6834.

ARCH6305.subject: ARCH
ARCH6305.name: Cross-Cultural Practice
ARCH6305.description: This course will address the material culture of globalization and cultural diffusion, emphasizing the multicultural registers of work produced between and across geographical, cultural, and disciplinary boundaries.

ARCH6312.subject: ARCH
ARCH6312.name: Ecological Practice
ARCH6312.description: An historically and culturally grounded examination of the ecological perspective. Critical and productive engagement with green guidelines, laws, products, design briefs, and procedures.

ARCH6313.subject: ARCH
ARCH6313.name: Traditions Arch Practice
ARCH6313.description: Critical examination of architectural practice. Cultural derivation and technological transformation of various conventions of representation, construction, and design; speculations about future paradigms of architectural practice.

ARCH6315.subject: ARCH
ARCH6315.name: Practice of Arch I
ARCH6315.description: Architectural practice from historical, sociological, and ethical perspectives with focus on professional leadership, practice management, and entrepreneurship.

ARCH6316.subject: ARCH
ARCH6316.name: Practice of Arch 2
ARCH6316.description: Methods of architectural project delivery and project management. Fundamentals of building economics. Emergent models of research-driven architectural practice.

ARCH6350.subject: ARCH
ARCH6350.name: Theory of Architecture I
ARCH6350.description: Architectural program. Building types from functional and morphological perspectives. Design responses to building programs in the context of culture and politics. Architectural responses to site.

ARCH6352.subject: ARCH
ARCH6352.name: Theory of Architecture 2
ARCH6352.description: Approaches to architectural form, style, and tectonics from aesthetic, social, and technological perspectives. Instrumental and symbolic uses of architectural media in design and building production.

ARCH6404.subject: ARCH
ARCH6404.name: Electronic Media
ARCH6404.description: The influence of electronic media upon representation and invention in architecture.

ARCH6412.subject: ARCH
ARCH6412.name: Dwelling Env Behav Des
ARCH6412.description: Explores scholarship and case studies from multiple disciplines relating to issues of place, community identity and memory, culturally constructed meaning, and appropriate use of resources.

ARCH6417.subject: ARCH
ARCH6417.name: Furnishing Buildings
ARCH6417.description: A course that focuses on schematic design and design development of furniture. The emphasis of this course is on conceptual and material/structural clarity.

ARCH6420.subject: ARCH
ARCH6420.name: Design Computing
ARCH6420.description: Survey of computer representations and modeling techniques, including pixel-based images, vector-based drawing systems, and surface and solid modeling; use of applications built upon these systems. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6420 and ARCH 4420.

ARCH6426.subject: ARCH
ARCH6426.name: 3D Modeling
ARCH6426.description: Construction of 3D computer models of architectural structures. Topics include: geometry creation, light and materials property, rendering, data exchange, and basic animation.

ARCH6427.subject: ARCH
ARCH6427.name: Adv Modeling & Animation
ARCH6427.description: Advanced computer modeling of architectural form. Topics include: parametric design, parametric materials, special effects, object libraries, animation, and video production.

ARCH6428.subject: ARCH
ARCH6428.name: Formal Sys-Dgn,Art&Arch
ARCH6428.description: This course will examine generative descriptions of languages of design, art, and architecture and explore various computational approaches to design with a special emphasis on shape grammars.

ARCH6447.subject: ARCH
ARCH6447.name: Urban Ecological Design
ARCH6447.description: This course engages the contemporary issues of urban ecology and its articulation to design. It explores relationship between urban forms and flows of ecology, energy, material, water and information. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6447 and CP 6836.

ARCH6470.subject: ARCH
ARCH6470.name: Arch Modeling & Media I
ARCH6470.description: Introductory approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

ARCH6472.subject: ARCH
ARCH6472.name: Arch Modeling & Media 2
ARCH6472.description: Intermediate approaches to two dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

ARCH6474.subject: ARCH
ARCH6474.name: Arch Modeling & Media 3
ARCH6474.description: Advanced approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

ARCH6501.subject: ARCH
ARCH6501.name: Analog-Digital Des Comp
ARCH6501.description: Analog and digital approaches in design computation. Visual and symbolic representations. Algorithmic and computational tools. History and logic.

ARCH6502.subject: ARCH
ARCH6502.name: Design Scripting
ARCH6502.description: Learning the concepts and application of scripting languages in architecture and form generation.

ARCH6503.subject: ARCH
ARCH6503.name: BIM Applications
ARCH6503.description: Survey of Building Information Modeling - its technologies exploration of new technologies to be applied and new procedures of project execution.

ARCH6504.subject: ARCH
ARCH6504.name: Fabrication Workshop
ARCH6504.description: Parametric design, planning and programming. Develop design for fabrication in specific materials including wood, plastic, metals, concrete, or composite.

ARCH6505.subject: ARCH
ARCH6505.name: Geometric Constructs
ARCH6505.description: Geometric surface and solid construction fundamentals using parametric modeling tools; use of sketching workbenches.

ARCH6506.subject: ARCH
ARCH6506.name: Materials/Fabrications
ARCH6506.description: Physical and constructional properties of building materials. Fabrication techniques for building components. Digital representations of materials, components, and fabrication processes.

ARCH6507.subject: ARCH
ARCH6507.name: Parametric Design
ARCH6507.description: Design using parametric modeling tools; use of sketching workbenches and development of custom parametric models.

ARCH6508.subject: ARCH
ARCH6508.name: Shape Grammars
ARCH6508.description: Shape grammars are a powerful formal system for the generative description, interpretation and evaluation of designs.

ARCH6509.subject: ARCH
ARCH6509.name: Comp Creativity Des Cogn
ARCH6509.description: This course investigates computational methods, models tools that support design creativity and cognition. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6509 and ID 6509.

ARCH6531.subject: ARCH
ARCH6531.name: Environmental Systems I
ARCH6531.description: Basics of heat, light, and sound applied to buildings. Thermal loading, passive thermal control, thermal comfort, climate, passive solar strategies, light and daylighting, acoustics.

ARCH6532.subject: ARCH
ARCH6532.name: Environmental Systems II
ARCH6532.description: Survey of active building systems: artificial lighting, mechanical (HVAC), electrical plumbing, transportation systems. Choice of active systems for sustainability, cost, etc.

ARCH6731.subject: ARCH
ARCH6731.name: Zero Energy House
ARCH6731.description: Design, analysis, operation, construction, and cost feasibility of so-called "zero energy" houses. Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6731 and BC 6731.

ARCH7042.subject: ARCH
ARCH7042.name: Urban Design Workshop
ARCH7042.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region. Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

ARCH7043.subject: ARCH
ARCH7043.name: Urban Design Workshop
ARCH7043.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region. Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

ARCH7044.subject: ARCH
ARCH7044.name: Urban Design Workshop
ARCH7044.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region. Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

ARCH7045.subject: ARCH
ARCH7045.name: Urban Design Workshop
ARCH7045.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region. Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

ARCH7060.subject: ARCH
ARCH7060.name: Critical Positions
ARCH7060.description: Advanced topics in the theory of architectural production focusing upon contemporary ethical dilemmas and the development of critical positions of design.

ARCH7252.subject: ARCH
ARCH7252.name: Computa Bldg Simulation
ARCH7252.description: Students learn how to develop their own extensible Building Simulation software using Finite Element discretization in Matlab and apply it to research problem.

ARCH7471.subject: ARCH
ARCH7471.name: Cogn Funct Visual Design
ARCH7471.description: Presents fundamentals of imaginative and cognitive functioning of visual design in buildings, and develops inter-disciplinary approaches to investigating visual form of buildings.

ARCH8100.subject: ARCH
ARCH8100.name: Intro to Arch Research 1
ARCH8100.description: Fundamental issues and methods across specializations in architectural research modules on causation and simulation.

ARCH8101.subject: ARCH
ARCH8101.name: Intro to Arch Research 2
ARCH8101.description: Fundamental issues and methods across specializations in architectural research; modules on representation and interpretation.

ARCH8102.subject: ARCH
ARCH8102.name: Intro To Arch Research 3
ARCH8102.description: Fundamental issues and methods across specializations in architectural research; modules on historiography and epistemology and on theories of design.

ARCH8863.subject: ARCH
ARCH8863.name: Special Topics
ARCH8863.description: Topics of current interest in architecture.

ARCH8997.subject: ARCH
ARCH8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
ARCH8997.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

ARCH8998.subject: ARCH
ARCH8998.name: Research Assistantship
ARCH8998.description: For gratuate students holding graduate research assistantships.

AS1110.subject: AS
AS1110.name: Foundations of the AF I
AS1110.description: A survey course designed to introduce students to the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Topics include: military customs and courtesies, Air Force officer opportunities, and an introduction to communication skills. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets, and complements this course by providing cadets with followership experiences.

AS1111.subject: AS
AS1111.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS1111.description: Introduction to the customs, traditions, and courtesies of the Air Force through drill and ceremonies, guest speakers, physical fitness activities, sports, and base visits.

AS1120.subject: AS
AS1120.name: Foundations of the AF II
AS1120.description: A survey course designed to introduce students to the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Featured topics include: mission and organization of the Air Force, officership, and professionalism. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS1121.subject: AS
AS1121.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS1121.description: Continuation of AS 1111. Emphasis on role and responsibilities of an Air Force junior officer. Air Force customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and introduction to the military environment.

AS2210.subject: AS
AS2210.name: US Air & Space Power I
AS2210.description: This course provides the students with a knowledge level of understanding for the general element and employment of air and space power, and is designed to examine general aspects of it through a historical perspective covering a time period from the first balloons and dirigibles to the beginning of the Vietnam War. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course by providing cadets with followership experiences.

AS2211.subject: AS
AS2211.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS2211.description: Emphasizes development of techniques used to direct and inform. Prepares students for field training.

AS2220.subject: AS
AS2220.name: US Air & Space Power II
AS2220.description: This course is a continuation of AS 2210 and examines the use of air and space power from Southeast Asia to the space age global positioning systems of the Persian Gulf War. In addition, the students will continue to discuss the importance of the Air Force Core Values with the use of operational examples and historical Air Force leaders, and will continue to develop their communication skills. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS2221.subject: AS
AS2221.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS2221.description: Continuation of AS 2211. Emphasis on preparation for field training.

AS3310.subject: AS
AS3310.name: Leadership Studies I
AS3310.description: A study of leadership, management fundamentals, professional knowledge, and communication skills required of an Air Force junior officer. Case studies are used to examine Air Force leadership and management situations as a means of demonstrating and exercising practical application of the concepts being studied. A mandatory Leadership Laboratory for AFROTC cadets complements this course.

AS3311.subject: AS
AS3311.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS3311.description: Supervisory practice and exercise of leadership functions in controlling and directing activities of the cadet corps. Practical development of leadership potential.

AS3320.subject: AS
AS3320.name: Leadership Studies II
AS3320.description: Examine the Air Force personnel and evaluation systems, leadership ethics, and Air Force supervision and counseling techniques. A mandatory Leadership Laboratory for AFROTC cadets complements this course by providing advanced leadership experiences in office-type activities, giving students the opportunity to apply the leadership and management principles of this course.

AS3321.subject: AS
AS3321.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS3321.description: Continues AS 3311 with emphasis on supervisory and leadership skills, and advantages of an Air Force career.

AS4410.subject: AS
AS4410.name: National Security Affair
AS4410.description: Examines the national security process, Air Force structure, and doctrine. Special topics of interest focus on civilian control of the military and joint operations with the Army, Navy, and Marines. Within this structure, continued emphasis is given to refining communication skills. A mandatory Leadership Laboratory for AFROTC cadets complements this course.

AS4411.subject: AS
AS4411.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS4411.description: Exercise of management functions in planning, supervising, and directing cadet corps activities. Emphasis on acquiring proficiency in military leadership skills.

AS4420.subject: AS
AS4420.name: Prep for Active Duty
AS4420.description: Topics include the military as a profession, regional studies, officership, military justice, advanced leadership ethics, preparation for active duty, and current issues affecting military professionalism. A mandatory Leadership Laboratory for AFROTC cadets complements this course.

AS4421.subject: AS
AS4421.name: Leadership Laboratory
AS4421.description: Continues AS 4411. Emphasis on developing top-level management skills. Includes the planning, organizing, and implementation of cadet military training.

ASE6001.subject: ASE
ASE6001.name: Fund Modern Sys Eng
ASE6001.description: Explore a wide range of modern systems engineering principles and development methodologies. Address requirements engineering, systems definition, design and analysis, implementation, operation, and technical management.

ASE6002.subject: ASE
ASE6002.name: Systems Design/Analysis
ASE6002.description: Introduce emerging techniques for systems and systems-of-systems analysis including IPPD, DOE, Taguchi methods, response surface equations, multi-attribute decision making, and concept feasibility assessment.

ASE6003.subject: ASE
ASE6003.name: Modeling/Sim Sys Eng
ASE6003.description: Introduction to modeling and simulation for systems engineers. Topics include problem formulation, conceptual modeling, simulation methodologies, verification and validation, DOE, simulation execution, and output analysis.

ASE6004.subject: ASE
ASE6004.name: Leading Sys Eng Teams
ASE6004.description: Systems engineering processes provide a model for successfully managing complex systems. Learn to apply management and development techniques used for successful commercial and government programs.

ASE6005.subject: ASE
ASE6005.name: Adv Topics SE - SysML
ASE6005.description: This core elective introduces SymML as a system modeling and design tool, with example applications, guidelines for application, and student projects on implementations in practice.

ASE6006.subject: ASE
ASE6006.name: Systems Engineering Lab
ASE6006.description: Application of working knowledge of systems engineering techniques applied to a "case study" in an applicable domain.

ASE6101.subject: ASE
ASE6101.name: Analysis & Synth-Vehicle
ASE6101.description: Vehicle Preliminary Design involves design iteration with disciplinary physics-based methods and tools. Includes geometry and databases from conceptual design, six DOF modeling, analysis, and synthesized baseline.

ASE6102.subject: ASE
ASE6102.name: System of Systems & Arch
ASE6102.description: Develop a broader understanding of the interdependencies and interoperability issues, interfaces, and processes for creating and defining Systems Architecture for complex systems.

ASE6103.subject: ASE
ASE6103.name: System Lifecycle & Integ
ASE6103.description: System preliminary design must address product and process design throughout system lifecycle from integration through manufacturing to phase-out along with interfaces to other emerging systems.

ASE6104.subject: ASE
ASE6104.name: Capstone Complex Systems
ASE6104.description: Student teams apply methods and techniques taught throughout the program to conduct complex system Conceptual Design based on requirements provided in a Request for Proposal.

ASE6111.subject: ASE
ASE6111.name: Analysis & Synth-Sensors
ASE6111.description: Defines, classifies, and examines technology used in stand-alone sensor systems. Centers on system-engineering trades useful in designing systems of sensors and systems of systems.

ASE6121.subject: ASE
ASE6121.name: Analysis & Synth-InfoSys
ASE6121.description: Tools and approaches for analysis and synthesis of enterprise information systems. Topics include user-centered requirement, scenario-based design, UML, network/communications, iterative prototyping, and enterprise support.

ASE8803.subject: ASE
ASE8803.name: Special Topics
ASE8803.description: Topics of current interest in Applied Systems Engineering.

BC2600.subject: BC
BC2600.name: Construction Contracting
BC2600.description: The goal of this course is to teach students the basics of construction contracting, business methods, organizational models, bidding, construction insurance, and labor relations.

BC2610.subject: BC
BC2610.name: Construction Tech I
BC2610.description: An introduction to the planning and physical development process for the construction of projects of residential and light construction scale.

BC2620.subject: BC
BC2620.name: Construction Tech II
BC2620.description: A continuation of Construction Technology I with an emphasis on large- scale and high-rise building, i.e., commercial building construction.

BC2630.subject: BC
BC2630.name: Construction Seminar
BC2630.description: Provides an introduction to the construction industry with emphasis on exploring career opportunities in construction.

BC2698.subject: BC
BC2698.name: Research Assistantship
BC2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC2699.subject: BC
BC2699.name: Undergraduate Research
BC2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC3600.subject: BC
BC3600.name: Construction Cost Mgt
BC3600.description: Introduction to cost principles and cost analysis of construction projects, including classification of work, quantity survey techniques, construction operation costs, and bid proposals.

BC3610.subject: BC
BC3610.name: Construction Law
BC3610.description: Legal aspects of construction contracts, bonds, insurance, and bidding. Owner, architect, contractor, and subcontractor relationships.

BC3620.subject: BC
BC3620.name: Real Est&Cnst Fin&Acct
BC3620.description: General introduction to the financing of construction and real estate development projects. Emphasis on financing requirements, activities, sources, and uses.

BC3630.subject: BC
BC3630.name: Project Management I
BC3630.description: This course will offer construction planning and management techniques for project design and construction with a focus on different scheduling methods and their use.

BC3640.subject: BC
BC3640.name: Construction Mechanics
BC3640.description: An introductory course to the evaluation of behavior of buildings, the properties of structural materials, and the behavior of load-resisting members.

BC4050.subject: BC
BC4050.name: Building Info Modeling
BC4050.description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices.

BC4110.subject: BC
BC4110.name: Trends & Pol For Res Dev
BC4110.description: An overview of development in the United States, current trends in residential development, and the impact of external factors on residential development. This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

BC4120.subject: BC
BC4120.name: Community Dsgn & Constr
BC4120.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC4130.subject: BC
BC4130.name: Intg Design Constr & Dev
BC4130.description: A study of contemporary examples of an integrated approach to design, construction and development. Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points of view.

BC4600.subject: BC
BC4600.name: Project Management II
BC4600.description: This course covers practical project management, technology, and tools for this approach and the required management skills for successful execution of projects.

BC4610.subject: BC
BC4610.name: Value Engr & Bldg Econ
BC4610.description: First part is an introduction to principles and methodology. Second part is an introduction to economic principles and theories and how to apply the concepts and methods of building economics.

BC4620.subject: BC
BC4620.name: Bldg Structural Analysis
BC4620.description: Emphasis being placed on the practical design and construction of structural elements. The course includes basic design principles with a heavy emphasis on constructability and buildability.

BC4630.subject: BC
BC4630.name: Senior Capstone Project
BC4630.description: A senior construction project that includes redevelopment analysis and feasibility study, project development, and construction.

BC4640.subject: BC
BC4640.name: Construction Marketing
BC4640.description: Methods of construction marketing and business development. Innovative computer applications, verbal skills development, professional strategies, market segmentation, and buyer behavior.

BC4650.subject: BC
BC4650.name: Lab for Sustainable Dsgn
BC4650.description: The goal of the laboratory is to teach students a comprehensive sustainable design and construction information system and a program of real-world, hands-on projects.

BC4660.subject: BC
BC4660.name: Entrepreneurship-Constru
BC4660.description: Basics of construction business risk assessment, looking for construction opportunities, capital investment, computerized construction business, and business failures.

BC4672.subject: BC
BC4672.name: MEP Systems
BC4672.description: The course will cover the fundamentals of design, selection, installation, commissioning, and maintenance of mechanical, electrical and plumbing systems. Credit not allowed for both BC 4672 and BC4670.

BC4680.subject: BC
BC4680.name: Professional Internship
BC4680.description: Students work for a professional architecture/engineering/ construction company in which they learn, first-hand, about the construction industry.

BC4698.subject: BC
BC4698.name: Research Assistantship
BC4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC4699.subject: BC
BC4699.name: Undergraduate Research
BC4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC4700.subject: BC
BC4700.name: Construction Management
BC4700.description: An accelerated-pace course designed to provide a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning, budgeting, estimation, scheduling, and project close out.

BC4710.subject: BC
BC4710.name: Green Construction
BC4710.description: This course focuses on the means, methods, strategies, and technologies to improve the energy efficiency and performance of buildings, and to reduce the environmental impact of buildings.

BC4720.subject: BC
BC4720.name: Resident Constr&Prop Mgt
BC4720.description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing, leasing, and financing.

BC4730.subject: BC
BC4730.name: Best Prac Multi-Fam Prop
BC4730.description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

BC4735.subject: BC
BC4735.name: Real Estate Dev&Construc
BC4735.description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

BC4843.subject: BC
BC4843.name: Special Topics
BC4843.description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

BC6002.subject: BC
BC6002.name: Issues In Sust Construct
BC6002.description: Course designed to help students achieve a basic understanding of the materials used in the commercial segments in the construction industry and how these relate to sustainable construction.

BC6004.subject: BC
BC6004.name: Sustainable Energy AEC
BC6004.description: An introductory course on sustainale energy in architecture, engineering and construction. The goal of the course is to introduce students to fundamental concepts of sustainable sources of energy to power buildings and address the impact of these sources to applicable green building rating systems

BC6025.subject: BC
BC6025.name: Construction Management
BC6025.description: An accelerated paced course providing graduate students a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning, budgeting, estimating, scheduling and project closeout.

BC6050.subject: BC
BC6050.name: Building Info Modeling
BC6050.description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices. Credit will not be awarded for both BC 4050 and BC 6050.

BC6100.subject: BC
BC6100.name: Prof Trends-Facility Mgt
BC6100.description: An introductory course covering the organizational, managerial, ethical, and legal principles for the delivery of facility management services. Includes contracts and risk management.

BC6125.subject: BC
BC6125.name: Professional Internship
BC6125.description: A course in which students work for a professional architecture/engineering/construction company in which they learn, first-hand, about the construction industry.

BC6150.subject: BC
BC6150.name: Design-Build Orgn & Mgt
BC6150.description: Introduction to Design-Build (DB) as a project delivery system. Provides information about the organization, the process, and the effects of DB on the industry.

BC6175.subject: BC
BC6175.name: Real Estate Dev & Constr
BC6175.description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

BC6185.subject: BC
BC6185.name: Intro to Const Prog Mgt
BC6185.description: Survey of the construction program management profession, focusing on the comprehensive management of single and multiple building programs including pre-design, design, construction and post-construction activities.

BC6200.subject: BC
BC6200.name: Maint Mgt-Built Assets
BC6200.description: This course covers the processes by which a facility and its systems are serviced and maintained during the facility's life cycle. Includes acquisition, installation, operation, maintenance, and disposal of built assets.

BC6250.subject: BC
BC6250.name: Value Mgt-Integrated Dgn
BC6250.description: Principles and methodology of value management analysis concepts and an examination of future values and worth criteria affecting building design, construction, furnishings, and operations performance.

BC6275.subject: BC
BC6275.name: Community Dsgn & Constr
BC6275.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC6285.subject: BC
BC6285.name: Mgt of Predesign Phase
BC6285.description: Examination of the Program Manager's role and responsibilities as owner during the pre-design phase including feasibility, organization, financing, legal, entitlement, planning, budgeting, scheduling, and team selection.

BC6300.subject: BC
BC6300.name: Safety & Environ Issues
BC6300.description: This course covers the environmental issues related to the performance of buildings and the health and risk factors for new and existing buildings.

BC6350.subject: BC
BC6350.name: Design& Construction Law
BC6350.description: Overview of construction law and legal issues encountered by the construction manager including U.S. laws, general concepts and definitions, contractor relationships, and relevant case studies.

BC6375.subject: BC
BC6375.name: Trends & Pol For Res Dev
BC6375.description: An overview of development in the United States, current trends in residential development, and the impact of governmental regulations on residential development. This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

BC6385.subject: BC
BC6385.name: Mgt of Design Phase
BC6385.description: Examination of the Program Manager's role and responsibilities as Owner during the design phase.

BC6400.subject: BC
BC6400.name: Fac Pln,Proj Mgt&Benchmk
BC6400.description: This course introduces the techniques of planning project management, benchmarking, and their applications to facility management. Includes space forecasting, scheduling and control of projects, and benchmarking studies.

BC6500.subject: BC
BC6500.name: Real Est Assest&Prop Mgt
BC6500.description: This course covers real estate financial management and performance topics from a decision making and strategic planning orientation for facilities management professionals.

BC6550.subject: BC
BC6550.name: Design&Constr Processes
BC6550.description: Offers a framework for use and application of design, contract, and performance documents for successful execution of various forms of integrated project delivery systems.

BC6575.subject: BC
BC6575.name: Real Estate Prod Finance
BC6575.description: Business model and financing process required to produce new real estate developments through an investigation of land acquisition, development and construction financial management.

BC6585.subject: BC
BC6585.name: Mgt of Constr as Owner
BC6585.description: Survey of construction management from the owner's perspective.

BC6600.subject: BC
BC6600.name: Fac Mgt Financial Analy
BC6600.description: This course covers real property concepts, issues, and topics pertinent to the facility management professional. The topics include site selection, property market analysis, legal documents, and land use control.

BC6650.subject: BC
BC6650.name: Advanced Project Mgt
BC6650.description: A four-phased coverage of project management including organization, planning and scheduling, control, budgeting, and ending with project testing, evaluation, and termination.

BC6675.subject: BC
BC6675.name: Res Design & Constr
BC6675.description: Course will examine the application of market, community, and regulatory factors to single family housing design and construction; construction management process required for efficient delivery.

BC6685.subject: BC
BC6685.name: Leadership in Des&Constr
BC6685.description: Framework and guidelines for effective leadership and communications during design and construction.

BC6700.subject: BC
BC6700.name: Adv Facility Mgt Practic
BC6700.description: Students apply specific methods and procedures from core courses to actual business situations in the facility and property management industry.

BC6731.subject: BC
BC6731.name: Zero Energy Housing
BC6731.description: Design, analysis, operation, construction, and cost feasibility of so-called "zero energy" houses. Credit not allowed for both BC 6731 and ARCH 6731.

BC6800.subject: BC
BC6800.name: Facil&Prop Mgt Capstone
BC6800.description: Designed to integrate the learning from basic topics through the use of actual case studies and situations found within the facility and property management industry.

BC6910.subject: BC
BC6910.name: Best Prac Multi-Fam Prop
BC6910.description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

BC6920.subject: BC
BC6920.name: Intro-Resident Prop Mgt
BC6920.description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing, leasing, and financing.

BC6930.subject: BC
BC6930.name: Intg Design Constr & Dev
BC6930.description: This course will focus on contemporary integrated approach to design, construction and development. Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points aof view. Examples to be selected from the Atlanta region.

BC7100.subject: BC
BC7100.name: Quant Meth Constr Resch
BC7100.description: Introductory course in graduate research in the building construction industry. Covers types of research, sampling methods, and basic analysis and evaluation techniques.

BC7200.subject: BC
BC7200.name: Adv Readings In BC
BC7200.description: This course is designed around advanced readings in research and practice for PhD students working in the building construction area.

BC8000.subject: BC
BC8000.name: PhD Seminar
BC8000.description: This is an introduction to PhD-level research in Building Construction.

BC8100.subject: BC
BC8100.name: Research Methodology
BC8100.description: Research design course that teaches the basics of creating credible scientific research plans with examples from construction related research.

BC8811.subject: BC
BC8811.name: Special Topics
BC8811.description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

BC8812.subject: BC
BC8812.name: Special Topics
BC8812.description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

BC8843.description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

BC8997.subject: BC
BC8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
BC8997.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantship.

BC8998.subject: BC
BC8998.name: Research Assistantship
BC8998.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantship.

BC8999.subject: BC
BC8999.name: Doctorial Thesis Prep
BC8999.description: This course is designed to synthesize the knowledge and skills developed in previous research courses and apply them to the doctoral dissertation process for students in Building Construction.

BC9000.subject: BC
BC9000.name: Doctoral Thesis
BC9000.description: Preparation of doctoral thesis for Ph.D. in Building Construction.

BIOL1510.subject: BIOL
BIOL1510.name: Biological Principles
BIOL1510.description: An introduction to the basic principles of modern biology, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, homeostasis, evolution, and ecological relationships.

BIOL1511.subject: BIOL
BIOL1511.name: Honors Biological Prin
BIOL1511.description: An advanced introduction to the principles of modern biology, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, homeostasis, evolution, and ecological relationships.

BIOL1520.subject: BIOL
BIOL1520.name: Intro to Organismal Biol
BIOL1520.description: An introduction to biology at the organ and organismal levels, with emphasis on physiological processes and integration of growth and development.

BIOL1521.subject: BIOL
BIOL1521.name: Honors Organismal Biol
BIOL1521.description: Introduction to biology at the organ and organismal levels, with emphasis on biodiversity, physiological processes, and integration of growth, reproduction and development.

BIOL2100.subject: BIOL
BIOL2100.name: Biogeography-New Zealand
BIOL2100.description: Introduction to theory of island biogeography focused on New Zealand's geological history and unique biota.

BIOL2335.subject: BIOL
BIOL2335.name: General Ecology
BIOL2335.description: Introduction to ecological processes at individual, population, and community levels that occur in plant, animal, and microbial taxa, and their relevance to current environmental problems.

BIOL2336.subject: BIOL
BIOL2336.name: General Ecology Lab
BIOL2336.description: The companion laboratory for BIOL 2335 (Ecology). This course stresses understanding ecological concepts through a combination of lab and field experiments, and computer simulations. 0

BIOL2337.subject: BIOL
BIOL2337.name: Honors Ecology
BIOL2337.description: A problem-based learning course in ecology. Student teams will do research and solve challenges typically faced by ecologists and environmental scientists.

BIOL2338.subject: BIOL
BIOL2338.name: Honors Ecology Lab
BIOL2338.description: Companion course to Honors Ecology. Student teams will explore solutions to ecological challenges using experiments and mathematical models.

BIOL2344.subject: BIOL
BIOL2344.name: Genetics
BIOL2344.description: Mendelian and molecular genetics; principles of inheritance, gene structure and function, foundations of recombinant DNA technology, genetic basis of variation and evolution.

BIOL2345.subject: BIOL
BIOL2345.name: Genetics Laboratory
BIOL2345.description: A laboratory course in the fundamental techniques of genetic analysis.

BIOL2354.subject: BIOL
BIOL2354.name: Honors Genetics
BIOL2354.description: A comprehensive genetics course incorporating discussions of primary literature. Topics include molecular genetics and gene action, transfer systems and mapping, cytological, quantitative and population genetics. Credit not allowed for bothBIOL 2354 and BIOL 2344.

BIOL2355.subject: BIOL
BIOL2355.name: Honors Genetics Lab
BIOL2355.description: Hands-on introduction to practical techniques, critical thinking, and important concepts in genetics. Students carry out laboratory experiments that explore transmission, population, and molecular genetics.

BIOL2400.subject: BIOL
BIOL2400.name: Math Models in Biol
BIOL2400.description: Introductory probability and deterministic models in biology, including discrete and continuous probability distributions and dynamic models from molecular and cellular biology to ecology and epidemiology.

BIOL2694.subject: BIOL
BIOL2694.name: Intern Assistantship
BIOL2694.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOL2695.subject: BIOL
BIOL2695.name: Undergraduate Internship
BIOL2695.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for credit freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOL2698.name: Research Assistantship
BIOL2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL2699.name: Undergraduate Research
BIOL2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL2801.name: Special Topics
BIOL2801.description: This designation enables the School of Biology to provide new lecture courses dealing with areas of current interest in biological sciences.

BIOL2901.name: Special Problems
BIOL2901.description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL2902.name: Special Problems
BIOL2902.description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL2904.name: Special Problem
