BIOL2905.subject: BIOL
BIOL2905.name: Special Problems
BIOL2905.description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL3100.subject: BIOL
BIOL3100.name: Ecology&Evol-Australia
BIOL3100.description: Evolution and ecology of Australian ecosystems, including rainforests, open woodlands, coastal habitats; conservation of endangered ecosystems. Earns Biology technical credit. Research project required.

BIOL3300.subject: BIOL
BIOL3300.name: Tropical Ecology
BIOL3300.description: Ecological processes in the tropics including community organizations, biotic interactions, biodiversity, coevolution. Students perform research projects in rain forest, cloud forest, and seashore.

BIOL3380.subject: BIOL
BIOL3380.name: Intro Microbiology
BIOL3380.description: Basic biology of bacteria, fungi, algae, and viruses, with emphasis on bacteriology.

BIOL3450.subject: BIOL
BIOL3450.name: Cell Molecular Biol
BIOL3450.description: An introduction to the structure and function of cells and their organelles with emphasis on eucaryotic cellular and molecular processes. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 3450 and BIOL 3340.

BIOL3451.subject: BIOL
BIOL3451.name: Cell Molecular Biol Lab
BIOL3451.description: An introduction to experimental methods of cell and molecular biology research that will cover some fundamental topics of cell biology. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 3451 and BIOL 3341.

BIOL3600.subject: BIOL
BIOL3600.name: Intro Evolutionary Biol
BIOL3600.description: Comprehensive introduction to evolutionary biology. Includes focus on processes (natural selection, genetic drift) and resulting patterns (genome organization, phylogeny) illustrated with prokaryote and eukaryote examples.

BIOL3751.subject: BIOL
BIOL3751.name: Anatomy & Physiology
BIOL3751.description: Study of human anatomy and fundamental physiological mechanisms. Topics include nervous, musculoskeletal, and cardiorespiratory systems. Free elective for biology majors. Crosslisted with AP 3751.

BIOL3753.subject: BIOL
BIOL3753.name: Anatomy
BIOL3753.description: Detailed study of human body structures using a regional and systems approach. Emphasis is placed on structural relationships and the integration of body systems.

BIOL3754.subject: BIOL
BIOL3754.name: Anatomy Lab
BIOL3754.description: A detailed hands-on study of human structure using high-resolution models, specialized specimens and dissection of selected mammalian organs and tissues.

BIOL3755.subject: BIOL
BIOL3755.name: Human Physiology
BIOL3755.description: Students will explore the function and adaptation of the human body emphasizing neuromuscular, cardio-respiratory, gastrointenstinal, endocrine, and urinary systems to maintain homeostasis and human health.

BIOL3756.subject: BIOL
BIOL3756.name: Physiology Lab
BIOL3756.description: A laboratory application of concepts in Physiology, providing hands-on experience focusing on primarily on non-invasive human experiments supplemented with in vitro tissues experiments.

BIOL3813.subject: BIOL
BIOL3813.name: Special Topics
BIOL3813.description: Topics of current interest not covered in other courses in the department.

BIOL4012.subject: BIOL
BIOL4012.name: Protein Biology
BIOL4012.description: Biological view of proteins, including protein biosynthesis, processing, modification, folding, trafficking, interactions, degradation, natural and directed evolution, assembly diseases, amyloids, prions and protein-based inheritance.

BIOL4015.subject: BIOL
BIOL4015.name: Cancer Bio/Tech
BIOL4015.description: This course covers basic concepts of cancer biology and new technologies that are being developed to understand, detect, treat, and prevent cancer. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4015 and BIOL 7015.

BIOL4101.subject: BIOL
BIOL4101.name: Sensory Ecology
BIOL4101.description: A quantitative analyses of communication channels and information acquisition involving visual, auditory, mechanosensory, and olfactory modalities across a range of species and habitats.

BIOL4105.subject: BIOL
BIOL4105.name: Macromolecular Modeling
BIOL4105.description: Principles and practices in the use of molecular mechanics methods (minimization; molecular dynamics) to study structure-function relationships in biological macromolecules.

BIOL4150.subject: BIOL
BIOL4150.name: Genomics&Appl Bioinfor
BIOL4150.description: Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence, gene expression, and proteomics data from public databases and other sources; applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4150 and BIOL 6150.

BIOL4221.subject: BIOL
BIOL4221.name: Biological Oceanography
BIOL4221.description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries.

BIOL4225.subject: BIOL
BIOL4225.name: Molecular Evolution
BIOL4225.description: Evolutionary processes at molecular level, organizations of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

BIOL4340.subject: BIOL
BIOL4340.name: Medical Microbiology
BIOL4340.description: Advanced study of bacteria, protozoa, fungi, and viruses that cause human diseases; emphasis on epidemiology, mechanisms of disease causation, prevention, and treatment.

BIOL4401.subject: BIOL
BIOL4401.name: Exper Dgn&Statis Methods
BIOL4401.description: Introductory course on experimental design, hypothesis testing and basic statistical techniques commonly applied in biological research. Exercises based on computer statistical software packages.

BIOL4410.subject: BIOL
BIOL4410.name: Microbial Ecology
BIOL4410.description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

BIOL4417.subject: BIOL
BIOL4417.name: Marine Ecology
BIOL4417.description: An overview of the physical forces and biotic interactions structuring marine communities and of the major threats to these communities. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4417 and BIOL 6417.

BIOL4418.subject: BIOL
BIOL4418.name: Microbial Physiology
BIOL4418.description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

BIOL4422.subject: BIOL
BIOL4422.name: Theoretical Ecology
BIOL4422.description: Theoretical foundations of ecology, from the population to the community and ecosystem levels.

BIOL4428.subject: BIOL
BIOL4428.name: Population Dynamics
BIOL4428.description: Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics, regulation, and evolution of natural populations, emphasizing the connections with mathematical models, genetics, and ecology. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 4428 and BIOL 6428.

BIOL4440.subject: BIOL
BIOL4440.name: Plant Physiology
BIOL4440.description: Chemical transformation in photosynthesis, photophysiology and water relationships, organic nutrition and effects of hormones on growth and development of plants.

BIOL4446.subject: BIOL
BIOL4446.name: Animal Physiology
BIOL4446.description: Systems physiology including nerves, muscles, kidney, digestion, circulation, endocrinology, reproduction, and respiration.

BIOL4460.subject: BIOL
BIOL4460.name: Comm Biological Research
BIOL4460.description: Students learn to convey the importance of research findings in the biological sciences and to critically evaluate research results through discussions and scientific presentations. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 4450 and BIOL 4460.

BIOL4464.subject: BIOL
BIOL4464.name: Developmental Biology
BIOL4464.description: Investigations of cell differentiation and development using the tools of molecular genetics and cell biology.

BIOL4471.subject: BIOL
BIOL4471.name: Behavior Biology
BIOL4471.description: An introduction to the study of the principles of behavior of all kinds of organisms, from microbes to mammals.

BIOL4478.subject: BIOL
BIOL4478.name: Biophysics
BIOL4478.description: Biophysical aspects of nucleic acids, proteins, and their interactions.

BIOL4480.subject: BIOL
BIOL4480.name: Evolution-Develop Biol
BIOL4480.description: This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4480 and BIOL 6480.

BIOL4545.subject: BIOL
BIOL4545.name: Human Genetics
BIOL4545.description: Introduction to the genetics and evolution of complex human traits, focusing on contemporary approaches to understanding susceptibility to malignant, metabolic, immune and psychological diseases.

BIOL4570.subject: BIOL
BIOL4570.name: Immunology & Immunochem
BIOL4570.description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications.

BIOL4590.subject: BIOL
BIOL4590.name: Research Project Lab
BIOL4590.description: Experience in designing, implementing, and communicating a biology research project, and practical training in modern approaches for biological research.

BIOL4607.subject: BIOL
BIOL4607.name: Molecular Microbiology
BIOL4607.description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches, regulatory mechanisms in disease-causing and environmental bacteria, and biotechnology applications derived from microbes. Credit not awarded for both BIOL 4607 and BIOL 4608 or BIOL 4607 and BIOL 6608 or BIOL 4607 and BIOL 6607.

BIOL4608.subject: BIOL
BIOL4608.name: Prokaryotic Mole Genetics
BIOL4608.description: The molecular genetics of bacteria and their viruses, with emphasis in the organization, replication, expression, transfer and experimental manipulation of prokaryotic genes and genomes. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4220 and BIOL 4608 or BIOL 4608 and BIOL 4607 or BIOL 4608 and BIOL 6607.

BIOL4620.subject: BIOL
BIOL4620.name: Aquatic Chemical Ecology
BIOL4620.description: Focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation, community organization, and ecosystem function. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4620 and BIOL 6620.

BIOL4650.subject: BIOL
BIOL4650.name: Bioethics
BIOL4650.description: This course will examine the process of scientific inquiry and the ethical implications of research in the biological sciences.

BIOL4668.subject: BIOL
BIOL4668.name: Eukaryotic Mol Genetics
BIOL4668.description: Topics in molecular genetics, including genetic engineering techniques, gene expression and regulation, genetic structure, stability and evolution, with emphasis on eukaryotic organisms.

BIOL4690.subject: BIOL
BIOL4690.name: Independnt Research Proj
BIOL4690.description: Independent research with proposal and manuscript writing, conducted with the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL4694.subject: BIOL
BIOL4694.name: Intern Assistantship
BIOL4694.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for pay for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOL4695.subject: BIOL
BIOL4695.name: Undergraduate Internship
BIOL4695.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for credit for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOL4696.subject: BIOL
BIOL4696.name: Biol Teaching Assistant
BIOL4696.description: Biology teaching carried out under the guidance of a faculty member. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4696 and BIOL 4697.

BIOL4697.subject: BIOL
BIOL4697.name: Biol Undergrad Teaching
BIOL4697.description: An introduction to teaching biology for undergraduate teaching assistants, with a focus on effective teaching active engagement of students, and development of innovative classroom activities. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4696 and BIOL 4697.

BIOL4698.subject: BIOL
BIOL4698.name: Research Assistantship
BIOL4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL4699.subject: BIOL
BIOL4699.name: Undergraduate Research
BIOL4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL4740.subject: BIOL
BIOL4740.name: Bio-Inspired Design
BIOL4740.description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration, utilizing principles of scaling, adaptability, and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4740 and (ISYE 4740 or PTFE 4740 or MSE 4740 or ME 4740).

BIOL4746.subject: BIOL
BIOL4746.name: Signaling Molecules
BIOL4746.description: The diversity of chemical signals between organisms and their structural specifications will be presented along with chemical and biological methods for isolating signaling molecules.

BIOL4752.subject: BIOL
BIOL4752.name: Intro Neuroscience
BIOL4752.description: Goals are to understand the components of the nervous system and their functional interactions, and appreciate the complexity of higher order brain functions and pathways. Crosslisted with BMED 4752.

BIOL4755.subject: BIOL
BIOL4755.name: Mathematical Biology
BIOL4755.description: An introduction to practical applications of mathematical models to help unravel the underlying mechanisms involved in biological processes. Crosslisted with MATH 4755.

BIOL4801.subject: BIOL
BIOL4801.name: Special Topics
BIOL4801.description: This designation enables the School of Biology to provide new lecture courses dealing with areas of current interest in biological science.

BIOL4802.name: Special Topics
BIOL4802.description: This designation enables the School of Biology to provide new lecture courses dealing with areas of current interest in biological science.

BIOL4805.name: Special Topics
BIOL4805.description: This designation enables the School of Biology to provide new lecture courses dealing with areas of current interest in biological science.

BIOL4901.subject: BIOL
BIOL4901.name: Special Problems
BIOL4901.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member. To be offered any term with credit to be arranged. Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free elective) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL4902.subject: BIOL
BIOL4902.name: Special Problems
BIOL4902.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member. To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged. Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL4903.name: Special Problems
BIOL4903.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member. To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged. Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL4904.name: Special Problems
BIOL4904.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member. To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged. Seven hours ( four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL4905.name: Special Problems
BIOL4905.description: Special problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member. To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged. Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL4910.subject: BIOL
BIOL4910.name: Honors Research Thesis
BIOL4910.description: Writing and submission of an Undergraduate Research Thesis describing research accomplishments with a biology faculty member.

BIOL6150.subject: BIOL
BIOL6150.name: Genomics Appl Bioinf
BIOL6150.description: Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence, gene expression, and proteomics data from public databases and other sources; applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6150 and BIOL 4150.

BIOL6221.subject: BIOL
BIOL6221.name: Biological Oceanography
BIOL6221.description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean, including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries.

BIOL6410.subject: BIOL
BIOL6410.name: Microbial Ecology
BIOL6410.description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

BIOL6417.subject: BIOL
BIOL6417.name: Marine Ecology
BIOL6417.description: An overview of the ecological and evolutionary patterns, processes, and mechanisms affecting the organization, structure, and function of a broad variety of marine communities. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6417 and BIOL 4417.

BIOL6418.subject: BIOL
BIOL6418.name: Microbial Physiology
BIOL6418.description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

BIOL6422.subject: BIOL
BIOL6422.name: Theoretical Ecology
BIOL6422.description: Theoretical foundations of ecology, from the population to the community and ecosystem levels.

BIOL6478.subject: BIOL
BIOL6478.name: Methods Molec Biophysics
BIOL6478.description: An introduction to biophysical methods that are employed to study biological macromolecules and their interaction to gain understanding of how they function. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6478 and BIOL 4478.

BIOL6480.subject: BIOL
BIOL6480.name: Evolution-Develop Biol
BIOL6480.description: This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6480 and BIOL 4480.

BIOL6570.subject: BIOL
BIOL6570.name: Immunology
BIOL6570.description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications, with emphasis on immunological methods used in molecular and cell biological research.

BIOL6600.subject: BIOL
BIOL6600.name: Evolution
BIOL6600.description: An introduction to evolutionary patterns and processes, including the history of life, phylogenetics, population genetics, quantitative genetics, molecular evolution, and other important topics in evolutionary biology.

BIOL6608.subject: BIOL
BIOL6608.name: Prokaryotic Molec Gene
BIOL6608.description: Molecular mechanisms of bacterial and plasmid genetic processes. Topics covered include genome organization, DNA replication, transcription, and translation. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 6608 and BIOL 4607 or BIOL 6608 and BIOL 6607.

BIOL6611.subject: BIOL
BIOL6611.name: Adv Microbial Physiology
BIOL6611.description: Advanced studies of selected aspects of the physiololgy of prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganisms.

BIOL6620.subject: BIOL
BIOL6620.name: Aquatic Chemical Ecology
BIOL6620.description: The course focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation, community organization, and ecosystem function. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6620 and BIOL 4620.

BIOL6623.subject: BIOL
BIOL6623.name: Exper-Aquatic Signaling
BIOL6623.description: A full-time commitment to student-originated, but faculty-guided, interdisciplinary research in aquatic chemical signaling using field, lab, and flume facilities at Skidaway Institution of Oceanography on the coast.

BIOL6626.subject: BIOL
BIOL6626.name: Physiological Ecology
BIOL6626.description: Study of the basic physiological processes and systems in vertebrates and invertebrates. Comparative study on how these systems are adapted for specific environments and functions.

BIOL6628.subject: BIOL
BIOL6628.name: Aquatic Toxicology
BIOL6628.description: Study of the biological effects of toxicants on aquatic organisms-mechanisms of toxicity, biotransformation, toxicity tests, ecological risk assessment.

BIOL6630.subject: BIOL
BIOL6630.name: Adv Microbial Ecology
BIOL6630.description: Advanced studies of selected aspects of the ecology of prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms.

BIOL6720.subject: BIOL
BIOL6720.name: Env Microbial Genomics
BIOL6720.description: To introduce advanced concepts and principles of contemporary environmental microbiological research and assosciated bioinformatics techniques through representative examples from recent literature.

BIOL6756.subject: BIOL
BIOL6756.name: Signaling Molecules
BIOL6756.description: The diversity of chemical signals between organisms and their structural specificities will be presented along with chemical and biological methods for isolating signaling molecules. Crosslisted with CEE 6756 and CHEM 6756.

BIOL6765.subject: BIOL
BIOL6765.name: Geomicrobiology
BIOL6765.description: Interactions between microorganisms and the geosphere, microbial energetics and genetics; geochemical controls on microbial diversity and activity. Crosslisted with EAS 6765.

BIOL7001.subject: BIOL
BIOL7001.name: Found-Molecul&Cell Biol
BIOL7001.description: The goal of this course is to provide new students with fundamental knowledge in the general areas of prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular biology, biochemistry, structural biology, and bioinformatics.

BIOL7010.subject: BIOL
BIOL7010.name: Advanced Cell Biology
BIOL7010.description: Current topics in eukarytotic cell biology including membrane functions, intracellular sorting and compartmentalization, cell signaling, cell cycle, cytoskeleton, cell adhesion, motility, and current experimental approaches.

BIOL7015.subject: BIOL
BIOL7015.name: Cancer Biol/Tech
BIOL7015.description: This course covers the major concepts of cancer biology as well as to state-of-the-art technologies that are being applied to cancer research, detection and treatment. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 7015 and BIOL 4015.

BIOL7023.subject: BIOL
BIOL7023.name: Bioinformatics
BIOL7023.description: Introduction to mathematical, statistical, and computer methods of nucleic acid and protein sequence analysis and interpretation. Algorithms for gene finding, protein structure and function prediction, constructing phylogenetic trees.

BIOL7101.subject: BIOL
BIOL7101.name: Advanced Sensory Ecology
BIOL7101.description: A quantitative analysis of how organisms of all kinds obtain information about their environment, and how they use it to guide locomotions.

BIOL7110.subject: BIOL
BIOL7110.name: Macromolecular Modeling
BIOL7110.description: Principles and practices in the use of molecular mechanics methods (minimization: molecular dynamics) to study structure-function relationships in biological macromolecules.

BIOL7111.subject: BIOL
BIOL7111.name: Molecular Evolution
BIOL7111.description: Evolutionary processes at the molecular level, organizations of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

BIOL7210.subject: BIOL
BIOL7210.name: Computational Genomics
BIOL7210.description: In this active learning class, students will learn to convert sequence information into knowledge through the use of computational genomics tools, applications and databases.

BIOL7668.subject: BIOL
BIOL7668.name: Eukaryotic Molec Genetic
BIOL7668.description: Topics in molecular genetics of eukaryotic organisms, including: gene structure and expression, protein processing and folding, genome stability, and molecular evolution.

BIOL7913.subject: BIOL
BIOL7913.name: Advances in Microbiology
BIOL7913.description: Topics of current interest in microbial physiology, applied microbiology, microbial ecology, and medical microbiology.

BIOL7914.subject: BIOL
BIOL7914.name: Advances in Bacteriology
BIOL7914.description: Topics of current interest in the physiology and ecology of bacteria and applications to practical problems.

BIOL7923.subject: BIOL
BIOL7923.name: Advances in Ecology
BIOL7923.description: Topics of current interest in the general areas of population growth and limitation, and the structure and stability of ecosystems.

BIOL7924.subject: BIOL
BIOL7924.name: Adv-Environmental Biol
BIOL7924.description: Topics of current interest in environmental biology.

BIOL7963.subject: BIOL
BIOL7963.name: Advances-Molecular Biol
BIOL7963.description: Topics of current interest in molecular biology.

BIOL7964.subject: BIOL
BIOL7964.name: Advances in Genetics
BIOL7964.description: Topics of current interest in genetics.

BIOL8000.subject: BIOL
BIOL8000.name: Integrative Biol Seminar
BIOL8000.description: A reading and discussion course structured around the School of Biology weekly seminar.

BIOL8002.subject: BIOL
BIOL8002.name: Seminar
BIOL8002.description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

BIOL8003.subject: BIOL
BIOL8003.name: Seminar
BIOL8003.description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

BIOL8005.subject: BIOL
BIOL8005.name: Signals in the Sea Sem
BIOL8005.description: Students and invited authorities in the field will present seminars and lead discussions focused on currently emerging topics in aquatic chemical ecology and signaling.

BIOL8006.subject: BIOL
BIOL8006.name: Integrative Systems Biol
BIOL8006.description: This course will investigate, using samples from the literature and faculty research, the general principles of biological systems, from gene expression circuits to ecological communities.

BIOL8106.subject: BIOL
BIOL8106.name: Tools of Science Seminar
BIOL8106.description: This course addresses issues important to all successful scientists and engineers such as: research ethics; collaborations between industry, academics, and government; women and minorities in science; balancing research, teaching and service; writing, editing, and reviewing, presentations; job interviews; time management; speaking to the public and media; and scientific and university politics.

BIOL8801.subject: BIOL
BIOL8801.name: Special Topics
BIOL8801.description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL8802.description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL8901.name: Special Problems
BIOL8901.description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
BIOL8997.description: For graduate students holding a teaching assistantship.

BIOL8998.name: Research Assistantship
BIOL8998.description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

BMED1000.subject: BMED
BMED1000.name: Intro to Biomedical Engr
BMED1000.description: An introduction to the field of biomedical engineering, with an emphasis on career preparation.

BMED1300.subject: BMED
BMED1300.name: Problems-Biomed Engr I
BMED1300.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies.

BMED1750.subject: BMED
BMED1750.name: Intro to Bioengineering
BMED1750.description: An introduction to the field of bioengineering, including the application of engineering principles and methods to problems in biology and medicine, the integration of engineering with biology, and the emerging industrial opportunities. Crosslisted with AE, CHE, ECE, ME, and MSE 1750.

BMED1801.name: Special Topics
BMED1801.description: Courses in special topics of current interest not included in the regular course offerings.

BMED2210.subject: BMED
BMED2210.name: Conservation Prin in BME
BMED2210.description: A study of material and energy balances applied to problems in biomedical engineering.

BMED2250.subject: BMED
BMED2250.name: Problems in Biomed Engr
BMED2250.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 2250 and BMED 1300.

BMED2300.subject: BMED
BMED2300.name: Problems-Biomed Engr II
BMED2300.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methods.

BMED2310.subject: BMED
BMED2310.name: Intro Biomed Engr Design
BMED2310.description: In small teams students will apply problem-based learning and human centered design to reverse engineer, analyze, and redesign medical devices. Credit will not be awareded for both BMED 2310 and BMED 2300.

BMED2400.subject: BMED
BMED2400.name: Intro-Bioengr Stats
BMED2400.description: Introduction to statistical modeling and data analysis in bioscientific and bioengineering applications. Topics include estimation, testing, regression, and experimental design.

BMED2698.subject: BMED
BMED2698.name: Research Assistantship
BMED2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED3100.subject: BMED
BMED3100.name: Systems Physiology
BMED3100.description: An introduction to human physiology emphasizing biomedical engineering aproaches to the understanding of basic organ function, disease states, and medical intervention.

BMED3110.subject: BMED
BMED3110.name: Quant Engr Physio Lab I
BMED3110.description: A hands-on lab providing an active learning team environment to reinforce selected engineering principles of physiology, emphasizing a quantitative model-oriented approach to physiological systems.

BMED3300.subject: BMED
BMED3300.name: Biotransport
BMED3300.description: Fundamental principles of fluid, heat, and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems.

BMED3310.subject: BMED
BMED3310.name: Biotransport
BMED3310.description: Fundamental principles of fluid, heat, and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3310 and BMED 3300.

BMED3400.subject: BMED
BMED3400.name: Intro to Biomechanics
BMED3400.description: An introduction to the basic concepts and methods in biomechanics, including statistics and the mechanics of biomaterials. The biomedical applications of mechanics will be illustrated.

BMED3500.subject: BMED
BMED3500.name: Sensors& Instrumentation
BMED3500.description: A study of basic concepts and design of electronic sensors and instrumentation used in biomedical measurements. Standard clinical measurement techniques will also be examined.

BMED3510.subject: BMED
BMED3510.name: Biomed Systems & Model
BMED3510.description: Basic concepts, modeling tools and analysis techniques for the study of biochemical, bioelectrical and biomedical systems.

BMED3520.subject: BMED
BMED3520.name: Biomed Sys & Modeling
BMED3520.description: Introduction of computational systems biology, including the modeling process, various types of models, standard analysis and simulation of systems, and applications in real-world biological systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3520 and BMED 3510.

BMED3600.subject: BMED
BMED3600.name: Physio Cell & Mol Syst
BMED3600.description: In depth cell and molecular physiology focused on cellular responses to stimuli, including cell organization/ reorganization, membrane transport/kinetics, cell signaling/ molecular biology, mechanobiology and energy requirements.

BMED3610.subject: BMED
BMED3610.name: Quant Engr Physio Lab II
BMED3610.description: This lab provides an active learning team environment, incorporating common cell/molecular biology techniques, to reinforce selected engineering principles in an in vitro cell culture setting.

BMED4400.subject: BMED
BMED4400.name: Neuroengineering Fund
BMED4400.description: Lab and lecture on current topics in Neuroengineering, including electrophysiology, clinical and diagnostic neuroengineering, neural prosthetics, sensory-motor integration, neuromorphic VLSI, neurodynamics and neurorobotics.

BMED4477.subject: BMED
BMED4477.name: Bio Networks & Genomics
BMED4477.description: Introduction to modeling of biological networks involved in gene regulation, cell signaling and metabolism. Mathematical modeling of cellular processes, such as gene expression, using genomic data.

BMED4500.subject: BMED
BMED4500.name: Cell & Tissue Engr Lab
BMED4500.description: The principles of cell and tissue engineering will be presented as a laboratory course to give students a hands-on experience. Cell engineering topics include receptor/ligand interactions, cell cycle/metabolism, cell adhesion, cellular mechanics, cell signal transduction, and cell transfection. Tissue engineering topics include applications, biomaterials/scaffolds and cells for reparative medicine, bioreactors and bioprocessing, functional assessment, in vivo issues.

BMED4600.subject: BMED
BMED4600.name: Senior Design Project I
BMED4600.description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints. Credit not allowed for BMED 4600 and BMED 4603 (or BMED 4601).

BMED4601.subject: BMED
BMED4601.name: Senior Design Project II
BMED4601.description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints. Credit not allowed for both BMED 4601 and BMED 4603 (or BMED 4600).

BMED4602.subject: BMED
BMED4602.name: Capstone Design
BMED4602.description: Team-oriented design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints. Includes introduction to relevant regulatory, intellectual property, and business management topics.

BMED4603.subject: BMED
BMED4603.name: Advanced Design
BMED4603.description: Continuation of a team-oriented design experience initiated in BMED 4602 Capstone Design. Includes more advanced relevant regulatory. intellectual property, and business management topics. Credit not allowed for both BMED 4603 and BMED 4600 (or BMED 4601).

BMED4698.subject: BMED
BMED4698.name: Research Assistantship
BMED4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED4699.subject: BMED
BMED4699.name: Undergraduate Research
BMED4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED4740.subject: BMED
BMED4740.name: Bio-Inspired Design
BMED4740.description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration, utilizing principles of scaling, adaptability, and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems.

BMED4750.subject: BMED
BMED4750.name: Diagnostic Imaging Phys
BMED4750.description: Physics and image formation methods for conventional X-ray, digital X-ray CT, nuclear medicine, and magnetic resonance and ultrasound imaging. Crosslisted with MP 4750 and NRE 4750.

BMED4751.subject: BMED
BMED4751.name: Intro to Biomaterials
BMED4751.description: Introduction to different classes of biomaterials (polymers, metals, ceramics) and physiological responses to biomaterial implantation. Topics include material properties, host response, and biomaterial characterization techniques. Crosslisted with MSE 4751.

BMED4752.subject: BMED
BMED4752.name: Intro Neuroscience
BMED4752.description: Goals are to understand the components of the nervous system and their functional interactions, and appreciate the complexity of higher order brain functions and pathways. Crosslisted with BIOL 4752.

BMED4757.subject: BMED
BMED4757.name: Biofluid Mechanics
BMED4757.description: Introduction to the study of blood flow in the cardiovascular system. Emphasis on modeling and the potential of flow studies for clinical research application. Crosslisted with AE, CHE and ME 4757.

BMED4758.subject: BMED
BMED4758.name: Biosolid Mechanics
BMED4758.description: The mechanics of living tissue, e.g., arteries, skin, heart muscle, ligament, tendon, cartilage, and bone. Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells. Applications. Crosslisted with AE, CHE, and ME 4758.

BMED4765.subject: BMED
BMED4765.name: Drug Design,Devlpmnt&Delivery
BMED4765.description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods for delivery into the body. Includes student presentations. Crosslisted with CHEM and CHBE 4765.

BMED4781.subject: BMED
BMED4781.name: Biomed Instrumentation
BMED4781.description: A study of medical instrumentation from a systems viewpoint. Pertinent physiological and electro-physiological concepts will be covered. Credit not allowed for both BMED 4781 and (CHE 4781 or ME 4781 or CHBE 4781 or ECE 4781).

BMED4782.subject: BMED
BMED4782.name: Biosystems Analysis
BMED4782.description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems, including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with CHE, ECE, and ME 4782.

BMED4783.subject: BMED
BMED4783.name: Intro-Medical Image Proc
BMED4783.description: A study of mathematical methods used in medical image acquisition and processing. Concepts, algorithms, and methods associated with acquisition, processing, and display of two- and three-dimensional medical imaged are studied. Crosslisted with ECE 4783.

BMED4784.subject: BMED
BMED4784.name: Engr Electrophysiology
BMED4784.description: Basic concepts of electrophysiology from an engineering perspective. Functionality of relevant organs and systems; instrumentation tools which monitor electrophysiology function. Crosslisted with ECE 4784.

BMED4801.description: Courses in special topics of current interest not included in the regular course offerings.

BMED4900.name: Special Problems
BMED4900.description: Individualized studies in certain specialized areas of interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED4902.name: Special Problems
