HP8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
HP8997.description: For graduate students holding a graduate teaching assistantship.

HP8998.subject: HP
HP8998.name: Research Assistantship
HP8998.description: For graduate students holding a graduate research assistantship.

HS4001.subject: HS
HS4001.name: Intro to Health Systems
HS4001.description: Background of U.S. healthcare; the workforce; mechanisms and costs of delivery; facilities; ambulatory care; regulation and quality; managed care, finance, and role of government.

HS6000.subject: HS
HS6000.name: Healthcare Delivery
HS6000.description: Historical background; the healthcare workforce; nature, problems, and costs of delivery sites; health planning, finance, role of government, alternative delivery models, and health policy.

HS6100.subject: HS
HS6100.name: Healthcare Deliv Models
HS6100.description: Progression in service delivery from individual providers to complex financing and delivery organizations. Alternative models are explored with an emphasis on access, efficiency, and effectiveness.

HS6200.subject: HS
HS6200.name: Healthcare Financial Mgt
HS6200.description: Applications of accounting and finance in the healthcare delivery system; methods of reimbursement, product costing, strategic financial planning, and capital formation.

HS6300.subject: HS
HS6300.name: Healthcare Info Systems
HS6300.description: Application of information systems to assist in medical practice including communication within the healthcare enterprise, reimbursement for care, clinical decision making, and assessment of outcomes.

HS6400.subject: HS
HS6400.name: Health Systems Practice
HS6400.description: An actual project conducted by individual graduate students within a healthcare institution or a health service organization. Project has both a faculty and site sponsor.

HS8803.subject: HS
HS8803.name: Special Topics
HS8803.description: Topics of current interest in health systems.

HS8813.subject: HS
HS8813.name: Special Topics
HS8813.description: Topics of current interest in health systems.

HS8997.subject: HS
HS8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
HS8997.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

HS8998.subject: HS
HS8998.name: Research Assistantship
HS8998.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

HTS1001.subject: HTS
HTS1001.name: Intro-Hist, Tech, & Soc
HTS1001.description: An introduction to classic texts, key concepts, and research opportunitites in history and sociology.

HTS1031.subject: HTS
HTS1031.name: Europe Since Renaissance
HTS1031.description: Social, political, economic, and cultural history of Europe since the Renaissance. Topics include Renaissance; Reformation; political, scientific, and industrial revolutions; nationalism; fascism and communism; decolonization.

HTS1081.subject: HTS
HTS1081.name: Engineering in History
HTS1081.description: Uses historical case studies to examine the relationship between engineers and the larger society in which they function. Often taught jointly with engineering faculty.

HTS2001.subject: HTS
HTS2001.name: Early American History
HTS2001.description: North America to 1763, including native cultures, contacts with European colonizers, settlement strategies and patterns, and foundation of American political and economic institutions.

HTS2002.subject: HTS
HTS2002.name: American Revolution
HTS2002.description: The American Revolution as political debate, war, and social upheaval, with attention to the framing and ratification of the Constitution.

HTS2006.subject: HTS
HTS2006.name: Hist-Old South to 1865
HTS2006.description: A study of social, political, and economic developments in the South from the colonial period through the Civil War.

HTS2007.subject: HTS
HTS2007.name: History of the New South
HTS2007.description: An examination of social, political, and economic developments from the Reconstruction period to the present.

HTS2011.subject: HTS
HTS2011.name: The Gilded Age
HTS2011.description: Populism, the currency question, immigration, the rise of big business, war, and reform in one of the most turbulent periods of American history.

HTS2013.subject: HTS
HTS2013.name: Modern America
HTS2013.description: Dawning of the atomic age, anticommunism, the Civil Rights Movement, New Frontier and Great Society, Vietnam and the tumultuous 1960s, and end of Cold War.

HTS2015.subject: HTS
HTS2015.name: History Sports America
HTS2015.description: Examines American sport from colonial to contemporary times. Focuses on the rise of organized sports and the influence of race, class, gender, and ethnicity.

HTS2016.subject: HTS
HTS2016.name: Soc Issues&Public Policy
HTS2016.description: Draws on sociological theory and research to understand the major economic, social, and cultural issues facing American society today.

HTS2036.subject: HTS
HTS2036.name: Revolutionary Europe
HTS2036.description: Industrialization and political revolution, the development of political ideologies and labor activism, modern nation-state building, and imperialism from the French Revolution to World War I.

HTS2037.subject: HTS
HTS2037.name: 20th Century Europe
HTS2037.description: Global war and the Bolshevik Revolution, rise and fall of Mussolini and Hitler, Stalinism, the Holocaust, Cold War, decolonization, and the movement toward European integration.

HTS2040.subject: HTS
HTS2040.name: Hist Islamic Societies
HTS2040.description: Survey of Middle East from pre-Islamic times to Ottoman rule, tracing the development of Islamic society and emphasizing the plurality of culture in the region.

HTS2041.subject: HTS
HTS2041.name: Hist-Modern Middle East
HTS2041.description: The transformation of the Middle East in the modern era and the relationship of the "East" and "West" in the contemporary world.

HTS2061.subject: HTS
HTS2061.name: Traditional Asia
HTS2061.description: Civilizations of East Asia up to 1850, emphasizing traditional cultures in China and Japan, including religion, science, formation of empires, social life, and commerce.

HTS2062.subject: HTS
HTS2062.name: Asia in the Modern World
HTS2062.description: Civilizations of India, China, and Japan since 1600, emphasizing Western impact and adaptation of these countries' political, economic, and social systems.

HTS2080.subject: HTS
HTS2080.name: Intro Hist Disease & Med
HTS2080.description: Introduction to the history of disease and medicine since the Renaissance focusing on infectious diseases, the rise of germ theory, and evolution of medical training. Cerdit not allowed for both HTS 2080 and HTS 3087.

HTS2081.subject: HTS
HTS2081.name: Scientific Revolution
HTS2081.description: A critical approach to the Scientific Revolution, introducing students to primary documents and images from the period and emphasizing interpretive strategies and methods.

HTS2082.subject: HTS
HTS2082.name: Tech& Sci-Industrial Age
HTS2082.description: Surveys major developments in technology and science since 1600 and places them in the broader social context of their times.

HTS2084.subject: HTS
HTS2084.name: Technology and Society
HTS2084.description: Analyzes social conditions that promote or retard technological activity, emphasizing role of business, the state, and scientific and engineering professions, and the emergence of consumerism.

HTS2085.subject: HTS
HTS2085.name: Reel History I
HTS2085.description: Students evaluate films as sources for specific historical events by viewing films, reading historical documents, and applying critical analysis to written assignments and class discussions.

HTS2100.subject: HTS
HTS2100.name: Sci, Tech & Modern World
HTS2100.description: An introduction to perspectives on how developments in science and technology at once reflect and influence politics and society on a global scale.

HTS2101.subject: HTS
HTS2101.name: Research Methods
HTS2101.description: Interdisciplinary survey based on critical readings of the methods historians and social scientists use to generate knowledge about social life. Students engage in "hands-on" research.

HTS2698.subject: HTS
HTS2698.name: Research Assistantship
HTS2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

HTS2699.subject: HTS
HTS2699.name: Undergraduate Research
HTS2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

HTS2803.subject: HTS
HTS2803.name: Special Topics
HTS2803.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS2813.subject: HTS
HTS2813.name: Special Topics
HTS2813.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS2823.subject: HTS
HTS2823.name: Special Topics
HTS2823.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS3001.subject: HTS
HTS3001.name: American Economic Hist
HTS3001.description: U.S. economic history since 1607, including regional specialization, agriculture, industrialization, technology, government and economy, money and banking, labor, international trade, and contemporary economic problems.

HTS3002.subject: HTS
HTS3002.name: Hist-American Business
HTS3002.description: Evolution of business institutions from colonial period to present, including entrepreneurship, business-government relations, institutional innovation, and twentieth century managerial capitalism.

HTS3003.subject: HTS
HTS3003.name: Soc of Econ Institutions
HTS3003.description: Examines links between economic structures-markets, regulatory bodies, and labor relations systems-and the wider structural and cultural context.

HTS3005.subject: HTS
HTS3005.name: Amer Environmental Hist
HTS3005.description: Transformation of the North American environment since 1500, including different notions of nature, romantic responses to wilderness during industrialization, rise of conservation movements, and environmental policy.

HTS3006.subject: HTS
HTS3006.name: United States Labor Hist
HTS3006.description: The changing nature of work and labor relations, with focus on unionization and government regulation, and equity issues in the workplace.

HTS3007.subject: HTS
HTS3007.name: Soc of Work and Industry
HTS3007.description: Analyzes paid employment as a decisive social attachment, emphasizing work organizations, technological change and authority relations, and social inequality among diverse groups of employees.

HTS3008.subject: HTS
HTS3008.name: Class,Power & Inequality
HTS3008.description: This course examines how social class and the market economy affect inequality and stratification in the U.S., with additional attention to the roles of race and gender.

HTS3009.subject: HTS
HTS3009.name: The American Civil War
HTS3009.description: Social, economic, political, and military aspects of the Civil War, including causes of the war, military campaigns, and long-term consequences.

HTS3011.subject: HTS
HTS3011.name: City in American Hist
HTS3011.description: Examines the historical background of the American city since colonial times, including city planning, urban technology and services, neighborhoods, and race relations.

HTS3012.subject: HTS
HTS3012.name: Urban Sociology
HTS3012.description: Sociological perspectives on the city, urbanization, and problems of community, evolution of cities and problems of urban life in the United States and Third World.

HTS3015.subject: HTS
HTS3015.name: History of Vietnam War
HTS3015.description: Diplomatic, military, and social aspects of America's war in Vietnam, including antiwar protests, the defense industry boom, and the war's enduring impact on American life.

HTS3016.subject: HTS
HTS3016.name: Women & Gender in U.S.
HTS3016.description: Course examines themes and theories of women's and gender history since the colonial period, including work, family, race, sexuality, and politics.

HTS3017.subject: HTS
HTS3017.name: Sociology of Gender
HTS3017.description: Gender as a dimension of social life that shapes and is shaped by the economy, schooling, family, politics, medicine and health, race, and social class.

HTS3018.subject: HTS
HTS3018.name: Religions & Cults in US
HTS3018.description: Explores controversial and influential new religious movements and cults in America, focusing on their origin, appeal, and impact.

HTS3019.subject: HTS
HTS3019.name: Family&Sexuality in U.S.
HTS3019.description: Changing patterns of family life and sex roles since colonial times, with a focus on mainstream ideals, utopian alternatives, and social criticism.

HTS3020.subject: HTS
HTS3020.name: Gender and Technology
HTS3020.description: Course examines the ways in which the design, development, and application of technologies, as well as cultural responses to them, have been gendered historically.

HTS3021.subject: HTS
HTS3021.name: Women in Science & Engr
HTS3021.description: Women in science and engineering and gender differences in participation, location, and status. Examines education, access, and apprenticeship, culture of science and engineering.

HTS3022.subject: HTS
HTS3022.name: Gender and Sports
HTS3022.description: Examines how gender norms and beliefs shape sport structures, participation opportunities and experiences in American sport.

HTS3023.subject: HTS
HTS3023.name: Free People of Color
HTS3023.description: Free people of color during the era of slavery, including everyday life, political and social philosophies, literature, community development, and movements for social change.

HTS3024.subject: HTS
HTS3024.name: African-Amer His to 1865
HTS3024.description: The experience of African and African American people in North America from the beginnings of slavery until the era of emancipation in the Civil War.

HTS3025.subject: HTS
HTS3025.name: Afr-Amer Hist since 1865
HTS3025.description: The African American experience since 1865, including Reconstruction, segregation, the African American family, the Harlem Renaissance, the Civil Rights Movement, and Black Power.

HTS3026.subject: HTS
HTS3026.name: Race and Ethnicity
HTS3026.description: Nature and significance of dominant/minority relations, including legacies of colonialism and slavery, roots of residential segregation, and effects of race on American politics.

HTS3027.subject: HTS
HTS3027.name: Civil Rights Movement
HTS3027.description: Examines why the civil rights movement emerged, how it was successful, and the impact it had on the U.S.

HTS3028.subject: HTS
HTS3028.name: Ancient Greece
HTS3028.description: Classical Athens and Sparta, myths and legends in historical context. Course ends with Alexander the Great and the rise of Rome.

HTS3029.subject: HTS
HTS3029.name: Ancient Rome
HTS3029.description: Growth of the Republic, antics and follies of the emperors, accomplishments of Rome, and causes of decline. Early Christianity and its impact on Europe included.

HTS3030.subject: HTS
HTS3030.name: Medieval Europe
HTS3030.description: The rise of barbarian kingdoms from Rome's ashes, the explosion of Islam, the monastic movement, Charlemagne's empire, the blossoming of medieval culture, and developinG European monarchies.

HTS3031.subject: HTS
HTS3031.name: European Labor History
HTS3031.description: The labor movement from 1700s to the present, including an examination of Marx and socialism, unionization, and work conditions, especially in Britain, Germany, and France.

HTS3032.subject: HTS
HTS3032.name: Europe Intellectual Hist
HTS3032.description: Introduction to intellectual problems and trends in modern Europe, including loss of faith in progress, evil and ethics, post-colonialism, feminism, linguistics, and psycho-analytic thought.

HTS3033.subject: HTS
HTS3033.name: Medieval England
HTS3033.description: Political, economic, and cultural development of England during the Middle Ages (c. 350-1400). Myths and legends of Stonehenge, the Druids, and King Arthur's Camelot explored.

HTS3035.subject: HTS
HTS3035.name: Britain 1815-1914
HTS3035.description: Developments in nineteenth-century Britain, including the industrial revolution, the growth of political democracy, imperialism, and movements for Irish Home rule and democratic socialism.

HTS3036.subject: HTS
HTS3036.name: Britain Since 1914
HTS3036.description: Britain's experience of two world wars, the growth of Labour and decline of the Liberals, the Welfare State, Thatcherism, and Tony Blair's "New Labour".

HTS3038.subject: HTS
HTS3038.name: French Revolution
HTS3038.description: Economic, intellectual, and cultural causes of the French Revolution, Jacobinism and the Terror, careers of Robespierre and Danton, and rise and fall of Napoleon's empire.

HTS3039.subject: HTS
HTS3039.name: Modern France
HTS3039.description: France from 1815 to 1968, emphasizing the continuing project of creating France as a powerful nation within the context of global culture and politics.

HTS3041.subject: HTS
HTS3041.name: Modern Spain
HTS3041.description: Resistance to Napoleon, deformed industrialization, Anarchist and fascist experiments form the background for Spain's transition from dictatorship to democracy after Franco's death.

HTS3043.subject: HTS
HTS3043.name: Modern Germany
HTS3043.description: Consolidation of Germany since Napoleonic wars, Germany's contributions both hideous and glorious to Europe and the West, and recent unification of East and West Germany.

HTS3045.subject: HTS
HTS3045.name: Nazi Germany-Holocaust
HTS3045.description: Genocide in the twentieth century, emphasizing the extermination of European Jews. Course investigates roots of racism, eugenics, and ideologies of genocide in comparative perspective.

HTS3046.subject: HTS
HTS3046.name: Sci Pol Culture Nazi Ger
HTS3046.description: Examines the social, political and cultural context of science and technology in Nazi Germany to understand the interaction of science and politics under totalitarian regimes.

HTS3048.subject: HTS
HTS3048.name: Modern Russian History
HTS3048.description: Provides an overview of Russian history during the 20th Century. Special emphasis will be on the Soviet period of Russian history from 1917-1991.

HTS3051.subject: HTS
HTS3051.name: Women&Gender-Middle East
HTS3051.description: The role of women in imperial, nationalist, and Islamist political programs in the Middle East and the impact of politics on women's lives.

HTS3055.subject: HTS
HTS3055.name: Globalization Modern Era
HTS3055.description: This course examines the process of globalization and global change in the twentieth century. Also offers a critical examination of various theories of globalization.

HTS3061.subject: HTS
HTS3061.name: Modern China
HTS3061.description: The decline of Confucian order, the impact of the West, changes and continuities of Chinese culture, the Communist revolution, nationalism, and economic reforms since 1978.

HTS3062.subject: HTS
HTS3062.name: Modern Japan
HTS3062.description: Japan's transformation in one century from a feudal state into an economic superpower and the impact of these changes on the Japanese people.

HTS3063.subject: HTS
HTS3063.name: British Colonization
HTS3063.description: Analysis of four British settlement colonies-Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and South Africa-emphasizing settlement, race relations, and national identity.

HTS3064.subject: HTS
HTS3064.name: Sociology of Development
HTS3064.description: Course examines competing perspectives on international development and surveys some of the crucial issues, including political instability, facing the Third World today.

HTS3065.subject: HTS
HTS3065.name: Hist Global Societies
HTS3065.description: Examines the historical patterns of interaction and inter- dependence between world regions, from approximately the 13th century to global interdependence to the contemporary world.

HTS3066.subject: HTS
HTS3066.name: Soc-Politics & Society
HTS3066.description: Political sociology studies the way power is distributed in society. This course takes a comparative and historical approach, focusing on the development of the nation-state.

HTS3067.subject: HTS
HTS3067.name: Revolutionary Movement
HTS3067.description: Comparative analysis of the origin, development, and impact of major twentieth century revolutionary movements.

HTS3068.subject: HTS
HTS3068.name: Social Movements
HTS3068.description: Why do social movements emerge? Why might they succeed? This course examines how ordinary people challenge powerful segments of society and contribute to social change.

HTS3069.subject: HTS
HTS3069.name: Modern Cuba
HTS3069.description: Cuba since 1492 emphasizing slavery and sugar, wars of independence, the revolution of 1959, and the regime of Fidel Castro.

HTS3070.subject: HTS
HTS3070.name: Culture and Society
HTS3070.description: Covers core issues in the study of culture. Focuses on key sites, social practices, and institutions. Topics include education, medicine, consumption, and the mass media.

HTS3071.subject: HTS
HTS3071.name: Sociology of Crime
HTS3071.description: This course examines the theories and issues such as perceptions of crime and criminals, characteristics of offenders and victims, and how crime is studied.

HTS3072.subject: HTS
HTS3072.name: Sociology of Education
HTS3072.description: Examines sociological perspectives on how individual, school, and social factors influence students and teachers. Particular attention is paid to gender, race, ethnicity, and social class.

HTS3073.subject: HTS
HTS3073.name: Sociology of Sports
HTS3073.description: Examines what constitutes "sports," and uses sociological lens to study sports relationship to education, policy, media, deviance, violence as well as gender, race and class.

HTS3075.subject: HTS
HTS3075.name: Foundations Sports Stds
HTS3075.description: Offers case studies of the multidisciplinary study of sports using the lenses of history, sociology, economics, science and technology to understand sports practices and controversies.

HTS3080.subject: HTS
HTS3080.name: History of Rocketry
HTS3080.description: Examines the history of rocketry, scientists, and organizations in the US, USSR, and Europe during the twentieth century.

HTS3081.subject: HTS
HTS3081.name: Tech and Environment
HTS3081.description: Examines how technology affected the environment during the 20th Century, with special attention to issues like industrialization, pollution, overcrowding, and the biotech revolution.

HTS3082.subject: HTS
HTS3082.name: Sociology of Science
HTS3082.description: The growth of science, its social structure; deviance and norms, the social context of scientific knowledge and practice, and science policy. Credit not allowed for both HTS 3082 and HTS 6115.

HTS3083.subject: HTS
HTS3083.name: Tech & American Society
HTS3083.description: The complex interplay between technical innovation and cultural change in the United States since 1850, with emphasis on the emergence of modern consumer-oriented society.

HTS3084.subject: HTS
HTS3084.name: Culture & Technology
HTS3084.description: Modernism and post-modernism: this course investigates culturally creative responses to modern manufacturing, transportation (trains, cars, airplanes), evolving gender ideals, and new communications.

HTS3085.subject: HTS
HTS3085.name: Law,Technology& Politics
HTS3085.description: Examines the ways in which courts, legislatures, and regulatory agencies have responded to challenges posed by new technology and shaped the course of technical change.

HTS3086.subject: HTS
HTS3086.name: Soc of Medicine & Health
HTS3086.description: Relationship between health and society, including health care problems in the United States and culture's role in defining health and sickness and in determining appropriate therapies.

HTS3087.subject: HTS
HTS3087.name: History of Medicine
HTS3087.description: An introduction to historical perspectives on the development of medicine, and its relationship to health, illness, and society. Credit not allowed for both HTS 3087 and HTS 2080.

HTS3088.subject: HTS
HTS3088.name: Race Medicine & Science
HTS3088.description: Examines how race is an issue in medicine and science in ways such as education, professions, treatments, experiments, and as a subject of analysis.

HTS3089.subject: HTS
HTS3089.name: Science Tech & Sports
HTS3089.description: This course examines what constitutes a "sport," debates on the role of social inequality in sports, and the intersection of science, technology and sport.

HTS3100.subject: HTS
HTS3100.name: Intro To Museum Studies
HTS3100.description: Covers theoretical and practical issues in museum studies, including the role of material culture in scholarly work, registration of artifacts, exhibit design, and public relations.

HTS3102.subject: HTS
HTS3102.name: Social Theory&Structure
HTS3102.description: Introduction to social theory, providing students with skills for reading theory and examining works of major social theorists, including Marx, Weber, Durkheim, Gilman, and Bourdieu.

HTS3103.subject: HTS
HTS3103.name: Honor's Thesis
HTS3103.description: This course is designed to allow honor's students to distinguish themselves by producing a significant, original research paper.

HTS3803.subject: HTS
HTS3803.name: Special Topics
HTS3803.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS3813.subject: HTS
HTS3813.name: Special Topics
HTS3813.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS3823.subject: HTS
HTS3823.name: Special Topics
HTS3823.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS4001.name: Seminar in US History
HTS4001.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in U.S. history. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

HTS4011.subject: HTS
HTS4011.name: Seminar in Sociology
HTS4011.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in sociology. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

HTS4031.subject: HTS
HTS4031.name: Seminar in European Hist
HTS4031.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in European history. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

HTS4061.subject: HTS
HTS4061.name: Seminar in Asian History
HTS4061.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in Asian history. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

HTS4081.subject: HTS
HTS4081.name: Seminar in Hist of Tech
HTS4081.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in the history of technology. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

HTS4086.subject: HTS
HTS4086.name: Sem Health Med & Society
HTS4086.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in health and medicine. Designed for HTS majors and HMS minors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

HTS4698.name: Research Assistantship
HTS4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

HTS4699.subject: HTS
HTS4699.name: Undergraduate Research
HTS4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

HTS4811.subject: HTS
HTS4811.name: Special Topics
HTS4811.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offering.

HTS4812.name: Special Topics
HTS4812.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

HTS4815.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

HTS4823.name: Special Topics
HTS4823.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS4833.name: Special Topics
HTS4833.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS4843.name: Special Topics
HTS4843.description: Allows a student and a professor to study topics not included in other courses in the department.

HTS4925.subject: HTS
HTS4925.name: Special Problems in HTS
HTS4925.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in history, technology, and society.

HTS4926.subject: HTS
HTS4926.name: Special Problems in HTS
HTS4926.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in History, Technology, and Society.

HTS4927.subject: HTS
HTS4927.name: Special Problems in HTS
HTS4927.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in History, Technology, and Society.
