ISYE4803.name: Special Topics
ISYE4803.description: Courses in special topics of timely interest to the profession, conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

ISYE4813.subject: ISYE
ISYE4813.name: Special Topics
ISYE4813.description: Courses in special topics of timely interest to the profession conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

ISYE4823.subject: ISYE
ISYE4823.name: Special Topics
ISYE4823.description: Courses in special topics of timely interest to the profession, conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

ISYE4833.subject: ISYE
ISYE4833.name: Honors Topics
ISYE4833.description: Topics of current interest in the field of ISYE that are covered with an appropriately high level of innovation and rigor.

ISYE4991.subject: ISYE
ISYE4991.name: Special Problems
ISYE4991.description: A variable hour credit opportunity to develop initiative and apply fundamental principles by performing semioriginal laboratory or research work in ISYE.

ISYE4992.subject: ISYE
ISYE4992.name: Special Problems
ISYE4992.description: A variable credit hour opportunity to develop initiative and apply fundamental principles by performing semioriginal laboratory or research work in ISYE.

ISYE4993.subject: ISYE
ISYE4993.name: Special Problems
ISYE4993.description: A variable credit hour opportunity to develop initiative and apply fundamental principles by performing semioriginal laboratory or research work in ISYE.

ISYE6101.subject: ISYE
ISYE6101.name: Organizational Behavior
ISYE6101.description: Studies the scientific generation, formalization, and application of the knowledge of individual and group behaviors that engineers need to function effectively within contexts.

ISYE6201.subject: ISYE
ISYE6201.name: Manufacturing Systems
ISYE6201.description: Topics include analysis of flows, bottlenecks and queuing, types of operations, manufacturing inventories, aggregreate production planning, lot sizes and lead times, and pull production systems.

ISYE6202.subject: ISYE
ISYE6202.name: Warehousing Systems
ISYE6202.description: Topics include design and analysis of materials handling systems, warehouse layout, order picking strategies, warehousing inventories, warehouse management systems, integration of production and distribution systems. Credit will not be awarded for both ISYE 6202 and ISYE 6383.

ISYE6203.subject: ISYE
ISYE6203.name: Transp&Supply Chain Sys
ISYE6203.description: Topics include supply chain characterization, site location, mode selection, distribution planning, vehicle routing, demand management, replenishment management, geographic information systems, and real-time control issues. Credit will not be awarded for both ISYE 6203 and ISYE 6383.

ISYE6205.subject: ISYE
ISYE6205.name: Cognitive Engineering
ISYE6205.description: Application of cognitive science concepts to system design, and the development of concepts appropriate for understanding and aiding cognition in naturally or technologically complex environments.

ISYE6215.subject: ISYE
ISYE6215.name: Human-Machine Systems
ISYE6215.description: The development and use of mathematical models of human behavior are considered. Approaches from estimation theory, control theory, queuing theory, and fuzzy set theory are considered.

ISYE6223.subject: ISYE
ISYE6223.name: Human Decision Making
ISYE6223.description: Prescriptive and descriptive theories of human decision making are discussed/contrasted. Approaches to aiding human decision making are considered in context of these theoretical frameworks.

ISYE6224.subject: ISYE
ISYE6224.name: Topics:Human-Integr Sys
ISYE6224.description: State-of-the-art research directions including supervisory control models of human command control tasks; human-computer interface in scheduling and supervision of flexible manufacturing systems.

ISYE6225.subject: ISYE
ISYE6225.name: Engineering Economy
ISYE6225.description: Advanced engineering economy topics, including economic worth, economic optimization under constraints, risk and uncertainty, foundations of utility theory.

ISYE6227.subject: ISYE
ISYE6227.name: Intro to Financial Engr
ISYE6227.description: Advanced techniques for economic analysis of capital investment. Basic terminology and financial engineering concepts for managing and valuing project risk. Real options applications in systems engineering.

ISYE6229.subject: ISYE
ISYE6229.name: Productivity Analysis
ISYE6229.description: Modern measurement of productivity measurement and analysis including principles, issues, and latest techniques associated with benchmarking, efficiency measurement, and productivity tracking. Empirical studies and group projects.

ISYE6230.subject: ISYE
ISYE6230.name: Economic Decision Analy
ISYE6230.description: Topics include preferences and utilities, social choice, equilibrium concepts, noncooperative and cooperative game theory, price mechanisms, auction mechanisms, voting theory, and incentive compatibility.

ISYE6231.subject: ISYE
ISYE6231.name: Human Integrated Systems
ISYE6231.description: Analysis and design of complex work domains in technological environments. Credit not allowed for both ISYE 6231 and AE 6721.

ISYE6232.subject: ISYE
ISYE6232.name: Real-Time Systems
ISYE6232.description: Study of system safety, human error, and software reliability.

ISYE6234.subject: ISYE
ISYE6234.name: Measurement & Evaluation
ISYE6234.description: Measurements of complex systems including workload, operator strategy, and performance.

ISYE6307.subject: ISYE
ISYE6307.name: Scheduling Theory
ISYE6307.description: Includes topics in sequencing and scheduling with emphasis on deterministic machine scheduling problems with some stochastic results examined. Complexity of various problems will be analyzed.

ISYE6320.subject: ISYE
ISYE6320.name: Public Impact Apps of OR
ISYE6320.description: The focus is on the health and public applications of Operations Research. Students will complete a group project with a non-profit organization and discuss papers.

ISYE6331.subject: ISYE
ISYE6331.name: Statistics Sup Chn Engrg
ISYE6331.description: Collection, management, and analysis of supply chain data.

ISYE6332.subject: ISYE
ISYE6332.name: Finance Sup Chn Engrg
ISYE6332.description: Investment and analysis of operating capital.

ISYE6333.subject: ISYE
ISYE6333.name: Opns Res For Sup Chns I
ISYE6333.description: Deterministic models of supply chains including location and material flow. Optimization techniques including linear programming, network flows, integer programming, and heuristics.

ISYE6334.subject: ISYE
ISYE6334.name: Opns Res For Sup Chns II
ISYE6334.description: Probabilistic models of supply chains, including the effects of variability; models of wholesale and retail demand; forecasting and simulation.

ISYE6335.subject: ISYE
ISYE6335.name: Supply Chain Engrg I
ISYE6335.description: Production scheduling; inventory systems; warehousing, including stocking strategies, order-picking, sortation, automation; distribution.

ISYE6336.subject: ISYE
ISYE6336.name: Supply Chain Engrg II
ISYE6336.description: Transportation: truck-load and less-than-truckload, and package-courier systems; container shipping, including port operations, steamship scheduling; railroad operations, including intermodal; air cargo. The international freight network and patterns of freight flow. Management and recirculation of trailers/containers. Labor issues.

ISYE6337.subject: ISYE
ISYE6337.name: Supply Chain Engrg III
ISYE6337.description: Problems of coordination and collaboration along the supply chain; make-or-buy decisions; pricing and auctions; wholesale and retail channels; supply chain dynamics, including the bullwhip effect. Distinctive supply chain issues in key economies.

ISYE6338.subject: ISYE
ISYE6338.name: Supply Chain Strategy
ISYE6338.description: Case studies of notable supply chains successes and failures.

ISYE6339.subject: ISYE
ISYE6339.name: Supply Chain Info Sys
ISYE6339.description: Planning and executing systems for inventory, warehousing, transportation, import/export, etc. Services-oriented architecture, cloud computing; systems integration; RFID and other technologies for scanning and monitoring.

ISYE6340.subject: ISYE
ISYE6340.name: Seminar in Sup Chn Engrg
ISYE6340.description: Through a program of industry speakers and facility tours, student will learn to assess and critique supply chain practice.

ISYE6341.subject: ISYE
ISYE6341.name: Capstone Project I
ISYE6341.description: Small groups of students undertake an industry-sponsored project under faculty guidance.

ISYE6342.subject: ISYE
ISYE6342.name: Capstone Project II
ISYE6342.description: Small groups of students undertake an industry-sponsored project under faculty guidance.

ISYE6380.subject: ISYE
ISYE6380.name: Prod Plan & Control
ISYE6380.description: Fundamentals of Production Planning and Lean Manufacturing

ISYE6381.subject: ISYE
ISYE6381.name: Mfg Reliability
ISYE6381.description: Fundamentals of Reliability and Maintainability Engineering.

ISYE6382.subject: ISYE
ISYE6382.name: Quality & Six Sigma
ISYE6382.description: Fundamentals of Quality Control and Six Sigma Methods. Credit will not be awarded for both ISYE 6382 and ISYE 3039.

ISYE6383.subject: ISYE
ISYE6383.name: Manu Supply Chain Ops
ISYE6383.description: Fundamentals of Manufacturing Supply Chain Operations. Credit will not be awarded for both ISYE 6383 and ISYE 6202 or ISYE 6383 and ISYE 6203.

ISYE6401.subject: ISYE
ISYE6401.name: Stat Models & Dsgn Expts
ISYE6401.description: Fundamental coverage of topics in multiple regression and factorial experiments.

ISYE6402.subject: ISYE
ISYE6402.name: Time Series Analysis
ISYE6402.description: Basic forecasting methods, ARIMA models, transfer functions.

ISYE6404.subject: ISYE
ISYE6404.name: Nonparametric Data Analy
ISYE6404.description: Nonparametric statistics and basic categorical data analysis.

ISYE6405.subject: ISYE
ISYE6405.name: Statistical Meth-Mfg Dgn
ISYE6405.description: Fractional factorial designs, response surface methods.

ISYE6411.subject: ISYE
ISYE6411.name: Statistics
ISYE6411.description: Relationships of statistical estimation and linear models with regression, planning and analysis of experiments, and the analysis of correlated data. More mathematical than ISYE 6401.

ISYE6412.subject: ISYE
ISYE6412.name: Theoretical Statistics
ISYE6412.description: Rigorous introduction to theory of statistical inference. Estimation and testing. Construction and assessment of estimators and tests. Fundamentals of decision theory, minimax, and Bayes Paradigms.

ISYE6413.subject: ISYE
ISYE6413.name: Dsgn & Analy-Experiments
ISYE6413.description: Analysis of variance, full and fractional factoral designs at two and three levels, orthogonal arrays, response surface methodology, robust parameter design for production/process improvement.

ISYE6414.subject: ISYE
ISYE6414.name: Regression Analysis
ISYE6414.description: Simple and multiple linear regression, inferences and diagnostics, stepwise regression and model selection, advanced regression methods, basic design and analysis of experiments, factorial analysis.

ISYE6416.subject: ISYE
ISYE6416.name: Computational Statistics
ISYE6416.description: This class describes the available knowledge regarding statistical computing. Topics include random deviates generation, importance sampling, Monte Carlo Markov chain (MCMC), EM algorithms, bootstrapping, model selection criteria, (e.g. C-p, AIC, etc.) splines, wavelets, and Fourier transform.

ISYE6420.subject: ISYE
ISYE6420.name: Bayesian Statistics
ISYE6420.description: Rigorous introduction to the theory of Beysian Statistical Inference. Bayesian estimation and testing. Conjugate priors. Noninformative priors. Bayesian computation. Bayesian networks and Bayesian signal processing. Various engineering applications.

ISYE6421.subject: ISYE
ISYE6421.name: Biostatistics
ISYE6421.description: An introduction to fundamental ideas and techniques in Biostatistics, with an emphasis on conceptual understanding and on the analysis of real data sets.

ISYE6644.subject: ISYE
ISYE6644.name: Simulation
ISYE6644.description: Covers modeling of discrete-event dynamic systems and introduces methods for using these models to solve engineering design and analysis problems.

ISYE6645.subject: ISYE
ISYE6645.name: Monte Carlo Methods
ISYE6645.description: Covers state-of-the-art Monte Carlo simulation techniques. These techniques will be used to model and solve a variety of real-world problems from several diverse areas in science and engineering, including supply chain analysis and design, pattern recognition, VLSI design, network reliability, financial engineering, and molecular biology.

ISYE6650.subject: ISYE
ISYE6650.name: Probabilistic Models
ISYE6650.description: An introduction to basic stochastic processes such as Poisson and Markov processes and their applications in areas such as inventory, reliability, and queueing.

ISYE6656.subject: ISYE
ISYE6656.name: Queueing Theory
ISYE6656.description: Processing networks with queuing. Performance analysis using Markov process description of system behavior. Applications and numerical studies in manufacturing, system maintainability, computer systems, telecommunication networks.

ISYE6661.subject: ISYE
ISYE6661.name: Linear Optimization
ISYE6661.description: Theory, algorithms, and applications of linear programming. Topics include the simplex method and resolution of degeneracy, duality and sensitivity analysis, basis factorization, the dual and revised simplex methods, and geometry of polyhedra. Intended for Ph.D. students.

ISYE6662.subject: ISYE
ISYE6662.name: Discrete Optimization
ISYE6662.description: Fundamentals of integer and combinatorial optimization. Topics include polyhedra, cuts, Lagrangean duality, complexity, and others. This course is intended for Ph.D. students.

ISYE6663.subject: ISYE
ISYE6663.name: Nonlinear Optimization
ISYE6663.description: Fundamentals of nonlinear optimization. Topics include optimality conditions; convex programming and duality; unconstrained and constrained methods. Polynomial algorithms and interior point methods. Dual methods. This course is for students seriously considering a PhD.

ISYE6664.subject: ISYE
ISYE6664.name: Stochastic Optimization
ISYE6664.description: An introduction to sequential decision making under uncertainty. Much of the course is devoted to the theoretical, modeling, and computational aspects of Markov decision processes.

ISYE6669.subject: ISYE
ISYE6669.name: Deterministic Optimiz
ISYE6669.description: An introduction to deterministic optimization methodologies including approaches from linear, discrete, and nonlinear optimization including algorithms and computations. Applications will be introduced as appropriate.

ISYE6673.subject: ISYE
ISYE6673.name: Financial Optimization
ISYE6673.description: An introduction to optimization techniques with special emphasis on applications to finance, including portfolio optimization, immunization, and risk management.

ISYE6679.subject: ISYE
ISYE6679.name: Computational Methods
ISYE6679.description: Strategies and techniques for converting optimization theory into effective computational procedures. Emphasis is on applications in linear, integer, and nonlinear programming; networks and graphs.

ISYE6701.subject: ISYE
ISYE6701.name: Energy Technol & Policy
ISYE6701.description: Examines energy production, use, and production, use, and policy using quantitative engineering and policy analysis. Addresses resource constraints, physical principles, and policy analysis methods.

ISYE6739.subject: ISYE
ISYE6739.name: Statistical Methods
ISYE6739.description: Overview of basic tools used in statistical analysis and modeling. Credit not allowed to students seeking a degree in ISYE.

ISYE6740.subject: ISYE
ISYE6740.name: Computational Data Analy
ISYE6740.description: Theoretical/computational foundations of analyzing large/complex modern datasets, including the fundamental concepts of machine learning and data mining needed for both resesarch and practice. Crosslisted with CSE 6740.

ISYE6759.subject: ISYE
ISYE6759.name: Stoch Process-Finance
ISYE6759.description: Mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization. Concepts from probability and mathematics are introduced as needed. Crosslisted with MATH 6759.

ISYE6761.subject: ISYE
ISYE6761.name: Stochastic Processes I
ISYE6761.description: Discrete time Markov chains, Poisson and renewal processes; transient and limiting behavior; average cost and utility measures of systems. Intended for Ph.D students. Crosslisted with MATH 6761.

ISYE6762.subject: ISYE
ISYE6762.name: Stochastic Processes II
ISYE6762.description: Continuous time Markov chains; uniformization, transient and limiting behavior; Brownian motion and martingales; optional sampling and convergence. Intended for Ph.D. students. Crosslisted with MATH 6762.

ISYE6767.subject: ISYE
ISYE6767.name: Sys-Computation Finance
ISYE6767.description: Introduction to large-scale system design to support computational finance for options, stocks, or other financial instruments. Some programming experience and previous exposure to stocks, bonds, and options required. Crosslisted with MATH 6767.

ISYE6769.subject: ISYE
ISYE6769.name: Fixed Income Securities
ISYE6769.description: Description, institutional features, and mathematical modeling of fixed income securities. Use of both deterministic and stochastic models. Crosslisted with MATH 6769.

ISYE6772.subject: ISYE
ISYE6772.name: Mgt Resources-Tech Firms
ISYE6772.description: This course explores the competitive advantage manufacturing and service firms derive from the effective management of their technology, workforce, materials, and information resources. Crosslisted with MGT 6772.

ISYE6773.subject: ISYE
ISYE6773.name: High-Tech Ventures
ISYE6773.description: This course provides a forum for the in-depth examination of issues involving the strategic management of high-tech corporate start-ups and small technology-based businesses. Crosslisted with MGT 6773.

ISYE6774.subject: ISYE
ISYE6774.name: MOT Project
ISYE6774.description: This course organizes students into multidisciplinary teams devoted to solving a real problem for a technology-based firm. Crosslisted with MGT 6774.

ISYE6775.subject: ISYE
ISYE6775.name: MOT Seminar
ISYE6775.description: This course introduces the frontiers of key technologies, provides a forum for visiting speakers from the corporate world, and supplements topics from other MOT courses. Crosslisted with MGT 6775.

ISYE6777.subject: ISYE
ISYE6777.name: Analysis-Emerging Tech
ISYE6777.description: Methods for technology monitoring, forecasting, and assessment. Crosslisted with PUBP 6777.

ISYE6779.subject: ISYE
ISYE6779.name: Dynamic System Modeling
ISYE6779.description: Models of dynamic systems, such as aircraft,ground vehicles, and machinery, and manual control. Numerical simulation techniques and applications. Interactive simulators. Student programming project. Crosslisted with AE 6779.

ISYE6781.subject: ISYE
ISYE6781.name: Reliability Theory
ISYE6781.description: Structural properties and reliability of coherent systems.

ISYE6783.subject: ISYE
ISYE6783.name: Financial Data Analysis
ISYE6783.description: Fundamentals of statistical inference for models used in the modern analysis of financial data. Crosslisted with MATH 6783.

ISYE6785.subject: ISYE
ISYE6785.name: The Practice of QCF
ISYE6785.description: Case studies, visiting lecturers from financial institutions, student group projects of an advanced nature, and student reports, all centered around quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with MATH and MGT 6785.

ISYE6792.subject: ISYE
ISYE6792.name: Manufacturing Seminar
ISYE6792.description: Guest speakers on a broad range of manufacturing-related topics: research, applications, and technology. Required for Certificate in Manufacturing. Crosslisted with ECE and ME 6792.

ISYE6793.subject: ISYE
ISYE6793.name: Adv Topics in QCF
ISYE6793.description: Advanced foundational material and analysis techniques in quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with MATH 6793.

ISYE6795.subject: ISYE
ISYE6795.name: Intro-Cognitive Science
ISYE6795.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on cognitive science. Interdisciplinary approaches to issues in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with CS and PSYC 6795.

ISYE6805.subject: ISYE
ISYE6805.name: Reliability Engineering
ISYE6805.description: Topics include hazard functions, life distributions, censoring, life tables, nonparametric and parametric estimation and inference, accelerated life testing, structure functions, reliability and maintenance systems, replacement theory.

ISYE6810.subject: ISYE
ISYE6810.name: Sys Montr&Prognostics
ISYE6810.description: The course focuses on sensor-based condition monitoring techniques, modeling of degradation processes, fault diagnostics and prognostics of failures in engineering systems using stochastic and statistical methods.

ISYE6831.subject: ISYE
ISYE6831.name: Advanced Simulation
ISYE6831.description: Topics include generalized semi-Markov processes; input and output analysis; random number, variate, and sample path generation, rare event simulation; and optimization via simulation.

ISYE6832.subject: ISYE
ISYE6832.name: Simulation Theory-Meth
ISYE6832.description: Theory, algorithms, and applications of computer simulation. Topics include generalized semi-Markov processes; input-output analysis; random number, variate, and sample path generation; variance reduction techniques; and optimization via simulation. This course is intended for Ph.D. students.

ISYE7000.subject: ISYE
ISYE7000.name: Master's Thesis
ISYE7000.description: Required of degree candidates in the master's thesis option.

ISYE7201.subject: ISYE
ISYE7201.name: Prod&Service Sys Engg
ISYE7201.description: Advanced models in operations planning, scheduling and control of supply chain, production and service systems. Intended for Ph.D. students.

ISYE7203.subject: ISYE
ISYE7203.name: Logistics Systems Engg
ISYE7203.description: Advanced modeling and analysis of freight transportation and logistics systems. Intended for Ph.D. students.

ISYE7204.subject: ISYE
ISYE7204.name: Info Prod & Ser Sys
ISYE7204.description: A course covers integration of statistics, signal processing and control for variability reduction (modeling, analysis, diagnosis, control) for complex systems in a data rich environment.

ISYE7210.subject: ISYE
ISYE7210.name: Real-Time Interact Sim
ISYE7210.description: Principles and laboratory experience in design and implementation of interactive simulations of complex dynamic systems.

ISYE7400.subject: ISYE
ISYE7400.name: Adv Design-Experiments
ISYE7400.description: Random and mixed models, nested and blocked designs. Intended for Ph.D. students and those seeking the M.S. in Statistics.

ISYE7401.subject: ISYE
ISYE7401.name: Adv Statistical Modeling
ISYE7401.description: Nonlinear models, logistic regression, loglinear models. Intended for Ph.D. students and those seeking the M.S. in Statistics.

ISYE7405.subject: ISYE
ISYE7405.name: Multivariate Data Analy
ISYE7405.description: Multivariate ANOVA, principal components, factor analysis etc. Intended for Ph.D. students and those seeking the M.S. in Statistics.

ISYE7406.subject: ISYE
ISYE7406.name: Data Mining&Stat Learn
ISYE7406.description: Topics include neural networks, support vector machines, classification trees, boosting and discriminant analyses. Intended for Ph.D. students and those seeking the M.S. in Statistics.

ISYE7441.subject: ISYE
ISYE7441.name: Theory of Linear Models
ISYE7441.description: Intended for Ph.D. students and those seeking the M.S. in Statistics.

ISYE7510.subject: ISYE
ISYE7510.name: Graph Algorithms
ISYE7510.description: Algorithms for graph problems such as maximum flow, covering, matching, coloring, planarity, minimum cuts, shortest paths, and connectivity. Crosslisted with MATH 7510 and CS 7510.

ISYE7653.subject: ISYE
ISYE7653.name: Case Studies-Logist/Mfg
ISYE7653.description: Advanced topics in logistics and manufacturing through the use of industrial case studies. Difficult modeling issues such as data representation and consistency will be introduced.

ISYE7661.subject: ISYE
ISYE7661.name: Linear Inequalities
ISYE7661.description: Theoretical foundations of linear and integer programming. Topics include representation of polyhedra, polarity, simplex and ellipsoid algorithms, diophantine equations, Hilbert bases, total dual integrality, and others.

ISYE7682.subject: ISYE
ISYE7682.name: Convexity
ISYE7682.description: Convex sets, theory of finite systems of linear inequalities, convex functions, convex programming.

ISYE7683.subject: ISYE
ISYE7683.name: Adv Nonlinear Prog
ISYE7683.description: Convex programming; linear, conic quadratic and semidefinite programming; cheap optimization methods for extremely large-scale convex problems.

ISYE7686.subject: ISYE
ISYE7686.name: Adv Combinatorial Opt
ISYE7686.description: Typical coverage includes: Matching theory, network optimization, traversals in graphs, integrality of polyhedra, matroids, covers, cliques, and stable sets.

ISYE7687.subject: ISYE
ISYE7687.name: Adv Integer Programming
ISYE7687.description: General integer modeling concepts; valid inequalities and facets; duality; general algorithms such as branch-and-bound and branch-and-cut; special purpose algorithms; applications.

ISYE7688.subject: ISYE
ISYE7688.name: Comp Math Prog
ISYE7688.description: Study of solution techniques in mathematical optimization, emphasizing computational aspects of both theory and algorithms.

ISYE7790.subject: ISYE
ISYE7790.name: Cognitive Modeling
ISYE7790.description: A hands-on course covering a range of cognitive methodologies. It explores the analysis, development, construction, and evaluation of models of cognitive processing. Crosslisted with CS and PSYC 7790.

ISYE8014.subject: ISYE
ISYE8014.name: Topics in SIAC
ISYE8014.description: A seminar course to introduce important research problems and applications related to the system informatics and control in production and service systems.

ISYE8795.subject: ISYE
ISYE8795.name: Colloquium-Cognitive Sci
ISYE8795.description: Reading of research papers by leading cognitive scientists, attendance at their colloquia, and meeting with them to discuss research. Crosslisted with CS and PSYC 8795.

ISYE8802.subject: ISYE
ISYE8802.name: Special Topics
ISYE8802.description: Special Topics in Industrial and Systems Engineering

ISYE8803.subject: ISYE
ISYE8803.name: Special Topics
ISYE8803.description: Special topics in Industrial and Systems Engineering.

ISYE8811.subject: ISYE
ISYE8811.name: Special Topics
ISYE8811.description: Special topics in Industrial and Systems Engineering.

ISYE8813.subject: ISYE
ISYE8813.name: Special Topics in OR
ISYE8813.description: Special Topics in the field of Operations Research.

ISYE8851.subject: ISYE
ISYE8851.name: Topics in Manufacturing
ISYE8851.description: Current topics in manufacturing including: manufacturing automation and controls, advanced planning systems, heuristic scheduling techniques, stochastic models of manufacturing systems, advanced warehousing, and materials handling.

ISYE8852.subject: ISYE
ISYE8852.name: Topics in Logistics
ISYE8852.description: Current topics in logistics including: inventory control in supply chain design, stochastic vehicle routing, computational methods in logistics systems, location theory, and geographic information systems.

ISYE8861.subject: ISYE
ISYE8861.name: Topics in Stochastics
ISYE8861.description: Coverage of advanced topics of interest that support research interests of students in the field.

ISYE8862.subject: ISYE
ISYE8862.name: Topics in Simulation
ISYE8862.description: Coverage of advanced topics of interest that support research interests of students in the field.

ISYE8871.subject: ISYE
ISYE8871.name: Topics in Optimization
ISYE8871.description: Topics may vary with each offering and include subjects such as integer programming, combinatorics, graphs and networks, matching, matroids, polyhedral combinatroics, as well as others.

ISYE8872.subject: ISYE
ISYE8872.name: Topics-Nonlinear Optimiz
ISYE8872.description: Similar to ISYE 8871 but deals with subjects in nonlinear programming, interior-point methods, convexity, global optimization, etc. Topics may vary each term.

ISYE8997.subject: ISYE
ISYE8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
ISYE8997.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

ISYE8998.subject: ISYE
ISYE8998.name: Research Assistantship
ISYE8998.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

JAPN1001.subject: JAPN
JAPN1001.name: Elementary Japanese I
JAPN1001.description: Essential principles of Japanese grammar and phonetics, acquisition of vocabulary through conversational exercises, video, and tape material. Introduction to the kana writing system. Humanities credit is awrded for JAPN 1001 upon successful completion of JAPN 1002 or JAPN 2001.

JAPN1002.subject: JAPN
JAPN1002.name: Elementary Japanese II
JAPN1002.description: Continuation of JAPN 1001. Introduction to kanji symbols.

JAPN1813.subject: JAPN
JAPN1813.name: Special Topics
JAPN1813.description: Permits a group of students too pursue areas of the Japanese language and culture not extensively treated in other courses.

JAPN1814.subject: JAPN
JAPN1814.name: Special Topics
JAPN1814.description: Topics of current interest in Japanese.

JAPN2001.subject: JAPN
JAPN2001.name: Intermediate Japanese I
JAPN2001.description: Further principles of Japanese grammar and vocabulary. Introduction to different styles and levels of speech. More kanji.

JAPN2698.subject: JAPN
JAPN2698.name: Research Assistantship
JAPN2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

JAPN2699.subject: JAPN
JAPN2699.name: Undergraduate Research
JAPN2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

JAPN2813.subject: JAPN
JAPN2813.name: Special Topics
JAPN2813.description: Topics of current interest in Japanese.

JAPN3001.subject: JAPN
JAPN3001.name: Advanced Japanese I
JAPN3001.description: Learn advanced grammar structures and develop the ability to produce longer conversations involving complex styles and levels of speech. More kanji.

JAPN3061.subject: JAPN
JAPN3061.name: Technical Japanese I
JAPN3061.description: Introduction to technical and scientific Japanese. Specialized vocabulary and concepts of chemistry, electrical engineering, computer science, and biology. Analysis and discussion of scientific issues in society.

JAPN3691.subject: JAPN
JAPN3691.name: Tech & Scientific Japn
JAPN3691.description: Reading of intermediate/advanced technical and scientific Japanese texts. Analysis and discussion of scientific issues in society. Part of the Japanese intensive summer language program. Admission by application only.

JAPN3692.subject: JAPN
JAPN3692.name: Business Japanese
JAPN3692.description: Acquisition of business terminology, protocols, decorum strategies, and improvement of oral communication skills. Reading and writing of notes, correspondence, and reports. Part of the Japanese intensive summer language program. Admission by application only.

JAPN3693.subject: JAPN
JAPN3693.name: Japan Today
JAPN3693.description: Development of awareness toward cultural differences and potential communication problems through exploration of current socio-economic and corporate-cultural issues in Japan. Part of the Japanese intensive summer language program. Admission by application only.

JAPN3813.subject: JAPN
JAPN3813.name: Special Topics
JAPN3813.description: Topics of current interest in Japanese.

JAPN3823.subject: JAPN
JAPN3823.name: Special Topics
JAPN3823.description: Topics of current interest in Japanese.

JAPN3833.subject: JAPN
JAPN3833.name: Special Topics
JAPN3833.description: Topics of current interest in Japanese.

JAPN4113.subject: JAPN
JAPN4113.name: Adv Reading & Listening
JAPN4113.description: This course introduces advanced grammar and stylistic and idiomatic expressions in Japanese in both written and spoken contexts on a wide range of topics.

JAPN4123.subject: JAPN
JAPN4123.name: Tech&Bus Jpn Translation
JAPN4123.description: This is an applied language course that provides practical experience in translating technical and business documents to and from Japanese.

JAPN4143.subject: JAPN
JAPN4143.name: Ling Culture Relativism
JAPN4143.description: This course examines 'cultural relativism' (Eastern/ Western, Japan/U.S.) as evidenced through linguistic systems communication strategies, and even religious orientation. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN4163.subject: JAPN
JAPN4163.name: Japn Literature Culture
JAPN4163.description: This is an introductory course in Japanese literature and culture where students read and interpret authenitic literary texts and learn and discuss key cultural concepts. Conducted in Japanese.

JAPN4165.subject: JAPN
JAPN4165.name: Crit Rdgs Jpn Cult/Arts
JAPN4165.description: This course helps improve reading skills of advanced learners by analyzing various written texts on topics of culture and society. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN4173.subject: JAPN
JAPN4173.name: Anime: Culture&Society
JAPN4173.description: Students will be able to appreciate anime's significance in historical, societal and cultural contexts, as well as the aesthetic quality of its form. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN4183.subject: JAPN
JAPN4183.name: Japn Cult/Soc Thru Songs
JAPN4183.description: Students will be exposed to songs in different historical, societal and cultural contexts of Japan, and appreciate their aesthetic quality. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN4231.subject: JAPN
JAPN4231.name: Design Websites in Jpn
JAPN4231.description: This course provides instruction in text input in Japanese and explores language and intercultural communication issues when designing Web pages in Japanese. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN4233.subject: JAPN
JAPN4233.name: Cali Pedagogy for Jpn
JAPN4233.description: This course explores pedagogical issues in designing Computer-Assisted Language Instruction (CALI) programs for teaching Japanese. Taught in Japanese. Prerequisites: JAPN 3002 (JAPN 4231 highly recommended).

JAPN4235.subject: JAPN
JAPN4235.name: 3D RPG Develop. Japn.
JAPN4235.description: This course explores pedagogical issues in designing Japanese instructional materials based on the 3D, RPG platform of Second Life. Taught primarily in Japanese. Prerequisites: JAPN 3002 (JAPN 4231 and JAPN 4233 are highly recommended).

JAPN4500.subject: JAPN
JAPN4500.name: Intercultural Seminar
JAPN4500.description: Integrates cross-cultural research and reflection into discussion of current issues in Japan. Intended for students who have had some study-abroad experience in Japan. Conducted mostly in Japanese.

JAPN4543.subject: JAPN
JAPN4543.name: Adv Japanese For NLP Dev
JAPN4543.description: This course will explore advanced linguistic, semantic and pragmatic issues unique to Japanese required for developing a NLP system of text-based Japanese.

JAPN4695.subject: JAPN
JAPN4695.name: Japanese Internship
JAPN4695.description: Professional experience with a business/organization in which students enhance their language skills and cultural knowledge in Japanese in relation to the practical goals/objectives of the entity.

JAPN4698.subject: JAPN
JAPN4698.name: Research Assistantship
JAPN4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

JAPN4699.subject: JAPN
JAPN4699.name: Undergraduate Research
JAPN4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

JAPN4743.subject: JAPN
JAPN4743.name: Japan Society & Politics
JAPN4743.description: Surveys key aspects of Japanese society and politics through the use of Japanese language readings, films, and other instructional materials. Course taught mostly in Japanese. Crosslisted with INTA 4743.

JAPN4750.subject: JAPN
JAPN4750.name: Japn Discourse & Grammar
JAPN4750.description: This course is about Japanese spoken and written discourse, designed for acquiring skills for managing interpersonal relationships through advanced discourse.

JAPN4780.subject: JAPN
JAPN4780.name: Jpn Applied Linguistics
JAPN4780.description: This course helps develop analytical skills to better understand human languages, particularly English and Japanese. Taught in English. Credit not allowed for both JAPN 4780 and LING 4780.

JAPN4813.subject: JAPN
JAPN4813.name: Special Topics
JAPN4813.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

JAPN4823.subject: JAPN
JAPN4823.name: Special Topics
JAPN4823.description: Topics of current interest in Japanese.

JAPN4833.subject: JAPN
JAPN4833.name: Special Topics
JAPN4833.description: Topics of current interest in Japanese.

JAPN4901.subject: JAPN
JAPN4901.name: Special Problems
JAPN4901.description: Provides the special instruction required under special programs.

JAPN4902.subject: JAPN
JAPN4902.name: Special Problems
JAPN4902.description: Special problems course for advanced students. Topics to be arranged with instructor.

KOR1001.subject: KOR
KOR1001.name: Elementary Korean I
KOR1001.description: Students will be able to speak, comprehend, read and write basic Korean sentences, and they will learn fundamentals in inter-personal relationships in Korean culture. Humanities credit awarded upon successful completion of KOR 1002 or KOR 2001.

KOR1813.subject: KOR
KOR1813.name: Special Topics
KOR1813.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR1814.subject: KOR
KOR1814.name: Special Topics
KOR1814.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR2001.subject: KOR
KOR2001.name: Intermediate Korean I
KOR2001.description: This course continues the introduction to modern colloquial Korean.

KOR2698.subject: KOR
KOR2698.name: Research Assistantship
KOR2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

KOR2699.subject: KOR
KOR2699.name: Undergraduate Research
KOR2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

KOR2813.subject: KOR
KOR2813.name: Special Topics
KOR2813.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR3001.subject: KOR
KOR3001.name: Advanced Korean I
KOR3001.description: Development of richer perspectives about Korean culture and enhanced skills in reading, writing, and vocabulary. Conducted in Korean.

KOR3002.subject: KOR
KOR3002.name: Advanced Korean II
KOR3002.description: Further development of richer perspectives about Korean culture and enhanced skills in reading, writing, and vocabulary. Conducted in Korean.

KOR3691.subject: KOR
KOR3691.name: Business Korean
KOR3691.description: This course aims to improve oral/written communication skills in business situations in Korea. Taught in Korean; part of Korean intensive summer language program.

KOR3692.subject: KOR
KOR3692.name: Issues & Tech In Korea
KOR3692.description: This course introduces key terms and discusses advances in technology and science in Korea today. Taught in Korean; part of Korean intensive summer language program.

KOR3693.subject: KOR
KOR3693.name: Exploring Modern Korea
KOR3693.description: This course equips students to understand contemporary Korea through reading and discussion about contemporary topics. Taught in Korean; part of Korean intensive summer language program.

KOR3813.subject: KOR
KOR3813.name: Special Topics
KOR3813.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR3823.subject: KOR
KOR3823.name: Special Topics
KOR3823.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR3833.subject: KOR
KOR3833.name: Special Topics
KOR3833.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR4001.subject: KOR
KOR4001.name: Contemporary Korean
KOR4001.description: This course aims to further the students' knowledge by exposing them to accurate and contemporary expressions in text and multimedia materials. Taught in Korean.

KOR4002.subject: KOR
KOR4002.name: Select Rdngs Of Mod Kor
KOR4002.description: This course aims to enhance students' Korean skills through advanced reading and comprehension, translation, grammar, and writing practice. Taught in Korean.

KOR4698.subject: KOR
KOR4698.name: Research Assistantship
KOR4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

KOR4699.subject: KOR
KOR4699.name: Undegraduate Research
KOR4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

KOR4813.subject: KOR
KOR4813.name: Special Topics
KOR4813.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR4823.subject: KOR
KOR4823.name: Special Topics
KOR4823.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR4833.subject: KOR
KOR4833.name: Special Topics
KOR4833.description: Topics of current interest in Korean.

KOR4901.subject: KOR
KOR4901.name: Special Problems
KOR4901.description: Special problems course for advanced students. Topics to be arranged with instructor.

KOR4902.subject: KOR
KOR4902.name: Special Problems
KOR4902.description: Special problems for advanced students. Topics to be arranged with instructor.

LCC2100.subject: LCC
LCC2100.name: Intro-Sci,Tech & Culture
LCC2100.description: As the introductory course to the major in Science, Technology and Culture, this course explores the ways in which disciplines construct and represent the knowledge they generate.

LCC2200.subject: LCC
LCC2200.name: Intro to Gender Studies
LCC2200.description: This course introduces the cultural concept of gender, examining topics such as biology and gender, social constructions of gender, and the psychology of sexual roles.

LCC2300.subject: LCC
LCC2300.name: Intro Biomedicine & Cult
LCC2300.description: This course provides an introduction to central cultural topics in biomedicine, such as health care, medical practice, medical research, and the systems of cultural meaning within which ideas of health and disease circulate.

LCC2400.subject: LCC
LCC2400.name: Intro to Media Studies
LCC2400.description: This course offers an introduction to the historical development and cultural impact of various forms of media print, radio, television, film, and interactive electronic applications.

LCC2500.subject: LCC
LCC2500.name: Intro to Film
LCC2500.description: Introduces film techniques and vocabulary in an historical and cultural context. Written texts are supplemented by viewings of specific shots, scenes, and films.

LCC2600.subject: LCC
LCC2600.name: Intro to Perform Studies
LCC2600.description: An examination of the origins of the field of performance studies in literary study of theatre and drama, anthropological investigations of ritual, and sociological analyses of performance in everyday life.

LCC2661.subject: LCC
LCC2661.name: Theatre Production I
LCC2661.description: In this "hands-on" course, students learn theatrical construction and painting techniques while building scenery for DramaTech productions.

LCC2662.subject: LCC
LCC2662.name: Theatre Production II
LCC2662.description: In this "hands-on" course, students create the lighting, property, and costume effects for two DramaTech Theatre productions.

LCC2698.subject: LCC
LCC2698.name: Research Assistantship
LCC2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LCC2699.subject: LCC
LCC2699.name: Undergraduate Research
LCC2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LCC2700.subject: LCC
LCC2700.name: Intr-Computational Media
LCC2700.description: Introduction to key concepts, methods, and achievements in computational media, and the convergence of digital technology with cultural traditions of representation.

LCC2710.subject: LCC
LCC2710.name: Visual Culture & Design
LCC2710.description: Studio-based course that provides students with the skills needed to create digital visual designs and to analyze designs from an historical and theoretical perspective.

LCC2720.subject: LCC
LCC2720.name: Prin of Visual Design
LCC2720.description: Studio-based course that provides students with basic skills needed to create digital visual images and to analyze designs from historical and theoretical perspectives.

LCC2730.subject: LCC
LCC2730.name: Construct-Moving Image
LCC2730.description: Provides the student with the conceptual, formal, aesthetic, and technical approaches to reconsider film, videos, and animation within the context of emerging digital forms.

LCC2803.subject: LCC
LCC2803.name: Special Topics
LCC2803.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LCC2813.subject: LCC
LCC2813.name: Special Topics in STAC
LCC2813.description: Study of one or more topics of current interest in the area of science, technology, and culture.

LCC2823.subject: LCC
LCC2823.name: Special Topics-Lit/Cult
LCC2823.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in literary and cultural studies.

LCC3102.subject: LCC
LCC3102.name: The Classical Tradition
LCC3102.description: Explores the definition and transmission of science and technology within Greek, Arabic, and medieval Latin contexts.

LCC3104.subject: LCC
LCC3104.name: Age-Scientific Discovery
LCC3104.description: Examines the relationships among texts representing the literary, artistic, and scientific thought of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

LCC3106.subject: LCC
LCC3106.name: Age of Sci Revolution
LCC3106.description: Examines interrelation of technological, literary, artistic, and philosophical thought in the late sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

LCC3108.subject: LCC
LCC3108.name: Sci, Tech & Enlightenment
LCC3108.description: Considers the conceptual reformulation of the internal and external world urged by the sciences, technology, and culture of the Enlightenment.

LCC3110.subject: LCC
LCC3110.name: Sci, Tech & Romanticism
LCC3110.description: Examines the relationships among romantic ideology, science, and literature, including Romanticism's imaginative responses to Enlightenment science and the Industrial Revolution.

LCC3112.subject: LCC
LCC3112.name: Evolution&Industrial Age
LCC3112.description: Connects later nineteenth century scientific and technological concepts and discoveries, particularly theories of evolution, to the literature and culture of the industrial age.

LCC3114.subject: LCC
LCC3114.name: Sci, Tech & Modernism
LCC3114.description: Explores a cross-section of technological, scientific, and cultural production characteristics of the first half of the twentieth century.

LCC3116.subject: LCC
LCC3116.name: Sci, Tech& Postmodernism
LCC3116.description: Focuses on the relation among information technology, nonlinear physics, and the art, literature, and culture of postmodernism. Explores postmodern critiques of the Enlightenment and modernity.

LCC3118.subject: LCC
LCC3118.name: Sci, Tech&American Empire
LCC3118.description: Considers nineteenth and twentieth century science and technology as they shaped American culture with particular attention to the relationship between science, technology, progress, and empire.

LCC3202.subject: LCC
LCC3202.name: Studies in Fiction
LCC3202.description: Examines the elements of fiction and what has made fiction, especially the novel, distinctive, popular, and enduring. Readings may include formal, cultural, and historical theories.

LCC3204.subject: LCC
LCC3204.name: Poetry and Poetics
LCC3204.description: A study of traditions of poetic practice and poetic theory in English through intensive line by line readings of poems from different periods in literary history.

LCC3206.subject: LCC
LCC3206.name: Communication & Culture
LCC3206.description: Examines ways in which forms and media of communication create and are created by other cultural constructs.

LCC3208.subject: LCC
LCC3208.name: African-Amer Lit/Cult
LCC3208.description: Explores the works of African American writers from the Colonial period to the present and examines a variety of cultural constructs that have fundamentally shaped the African American literary tradition.

LCC3210.subject: LCC
LCC3210.name: Ethnicity-Amer Culture
LCC3210.description: Explores literary and historical works considering ethnic issues in American culture, including immigration, social assimilation, "double consciousness," the development of ethnic identity/pride, and multiculturalism.

LCC3212.subject: LCC
LCC3212.name: Women, Lit & Culture
LCC3212.description: Students in this course will analyze writings by women and examine feminist and other relevant cultural critiques of literature.

LCC3214.subject: LCC
LCC3214.name: Science Fiction
LCC3214.description: Examines science fiction texts from the last 200 years to show how they reflect ambiguous reactions to change.

LCC3216.subject: LCC
LCC3216.name: Theatre I
LCC3216.description: The dramatic literature, theory, performance practices, and historical and cultural context of the theatre from prehistory through the Medieval period.

LCC3218.subject: LCC
LCC3218.name: Theatre II
LCC3218.description: The dramatic literature, theory, performance practices, and historical and cultural context of theatre from the Renaissance through Restoration.

LCC3219.subject: LCC
LCC3219.name: Literature and Medicine
LCC3219.description: This course examines works of literature dealing overtly with illness and healing, works about or by phyicians and other caregivers, and works that raise questions about ethical behavior in the face of sickness.

LCC3220.subject: LCC
LCC3220.name: Theatre III
LCC3220.description: The dramatic literature, theory, performance practices, and historical and cultural contexts of the theatre from Modernism to our contemporary period.

LCC3222.subject: LCC
LCC3222.name: Regionalism-Amer Lit
LCC3222.description: Explores the literary and cultural representations of a particular American region or locale (the South, the West, California, New York City, etc.) and the role such representations have played in the formation of both regional and national identity.

LCC3225.subject: LCC
LCC3225.name: Gender Study-Disciplines
LCC3225.description: This course explores the concept of gender and its usefulness as a theoretical category in a variety of disciplines. It includes cultural studies of literature, communication media, cultural anthropology, sociology, history, and science.

LCC3226.subject: LCC
LCC3226.name: Major Authors
LCC3226.description: An examination of the works and career of a major author in historical and cultural context.

LCC3228.subject: LCC
LCC3228.name: Shakespeare
LCC3228.description: An examination of Shakespeare's works with attention to generic conventions, historical context, and the relationship of text and performance. Major works of Shakespeare's contemporaries are studied as appropriate.

LCC3234.subject: LCC
LCC3234.name: Creative Writing
LCC3234.description: This course explores a range of creative literary genres, and combines study and analysis of existing modes of one or more forms in order to establish a basis for original creative work by class members.

LCC3252.subject: LCC
LCC3252.name: Film and Television
LCC3252.description: Explores in depth a theoretical issue central to film and/or television. Among its concerns are authorship, genre theory, spectatorship, ideology, narrative theory, and the relationship between these media and social history.

LCC3254.subject: LCC
LCC3254.name: Film History
LCC3254.description: Surveys the history of film from its machine origins to its present digital developments. It focuses on various movements, figures, and narrative developments in world cinema.

LCC3256.subject: LCC
LCC3256.name: Major Filmmakers
LCC3256.description: Traces in depth an individual artist's career and affords students the opportunity to immerse themselves in the works of an important figure in the world of film.

LCC3257.subject: LCC
LCC3257.name: Global Cinema
LCC3257.description: This course examines selected movements, styles, and trends in world cinema, emphasizing how contemporary film's global nature affects cultural representation.

LCC3258.subject: LCC
LCC3258.name: Documentary Film
LCC3258.description: This course examines significant movements, styles, and trends in fact-based cinema, emphasizing its cultural implications and formal strategies.

LCC3259.subject: LCC
LCC3259.name: Experimental Film
LCC3259.description: This course examines the history and trends in experimental film and video, emphasizing the relationship to avant-garde art movements.

LCC3262.subject: LCC
LCC3262.name: Performance Studies
LCC3262.description: An examination of cultural theories of performance and their application to the analysis of specific performative events.

LCC3302.subject: LCC
LCC3302.name: Science, Tech & Ideology
LCC3302.description: Examines specific scientific, philosophical, and literary/cultural texts in order to determine the role ideology plays in the construction of culture, especially scientific and technological culture.

LCC3304.subject: LCC
LCC3304.name: Science, Tech, & Gender
LCC3304.description: Examines specific philosophical, scientific, and cultural texts to determine the role that gender has played in the scientific and technological knowledge, currently and historically.

LCC3306.subject: LCC
LCC3306.name: Science,Technology& Race
LCC3306.description: Examines specific historical and contemporary construction of race, within the prevailing scientific theories and ideologies in order to determine the role played by "race" in scientific and technological culture.

LCC3308.subject: LCC
LCC3308.name: Environment Ecocritic
LCC3308.description: Surveys the emergence of ecocriticism as an analytical framework for interpreting the verbal and visual rhetorics of environmentalism in both western and nonwestern cultures.

LCC3310.subject: LCC
LCC3310.name: Rhetoric-Sci Inquiry
LCC3310.description: This course takes as its subject the ways in which argumentative and persuasive discourse is used to create and disseminate scientific knowledge.

LCC3314.subject: LCC
LCC3314.name: Tech of Representation
LCC3314.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues raised by technologies of representation, including written, spoken, and gestural languages; print, painting and illustration; still and moving photography; recorded sound; and computer-mediated communications and interactive digital media.

LCC3316.subject: LCC
LCC3316.name: Postcolonialism
LCC3316.description: Surveys the development of Postcolonial literary theory and historiography in order to analyze the interdependent discourses and practices of post-Enlightenment science/technology and European imperialism.

LCC3318.subject: LCC
LCC3318.name: Biomedicine & Culture
LCC3318.description: Discusses the history of biology and medicine; popular representations of health, disease, and the medical establishment; and the cultural implications of medical imaging technologies.

LCC3352.subject: LCC
LCC3352.name: Film Technology
LCC3352.description: Examines the development of film technology and the implications of that technology for cinema's treatment of technology.

LCC3362.subject: LCC
LCC3362.name: Sci, Tech & Performance
LCC3362.description: Examines contemporary theories of performance in relation to the production of scientific knowledge and technologies of representation.

LCC3400.subject: LCC
LCC3400.name: Tech Communication
LCC3400.description: Exposes students to the concepts and principles that drive technical communication. Students will learn about technical communication by studying principles that influence this genre of document production. Credit not allowed for LCC 3400 and (LCC 3401 or LCC 3403).

LCC3401.subject: LCC
LCC3401.name: Technical Comm Practices
LCC3401.description: Designed to introduce students to the types of documents and communication abilities required by their future professions, the course focuses on an understanding of both visual and verbal rhetoric in application to technical documents. Credit not allowed for both LCC 3401 and (LCC 3400 or LCC 3403).

LCC3402.subject: LCC
LCC3402.name: Graphic/Visual Design
LCC3402.description: Introduction to fundamentals of graphic and visual design of print and digital media. Familiarity with use of the World Wide Web, page layout, and computer graphic software recommended.

LCC3403.subject: LCC
LCC3403.name: Tech Communication
LCC3403.description: This course introduces students to workplace document genres to develop visual and verbal skills in critical analysis and document development. Credit not allowed for both LCC 3403 and (LCC 3400 or LCC 3401).

LCC3404.subject: LCC
LCC3404.name: Design for the Internet
LCC3404.description: An introduction to the theory and practice of effective communication on the Internet through the design of documents for the World Wide Web.

LCC3406.subject: LCC
LCC3406.name: Video Production
LCC3406.description: An introduction to video production including basic skills in storyboarding, scripting, filming, editing, and sound.

LCC3408.subject: LCC
LCC3408.name: Rhetoric-Tech Narratives
LCC3408.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by such narrative documents as technical proposals, recommendations reports, grant proposals, and marketing studies. Emphasis on document design, graphics, navigation systems, and editing.

LCC3410.subject: LCC
LCC3410.name: Non-Linear Documents
LCC3410.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by hypertext documents. Emphasis in designing for multiple audiences, page and document design, and navigation in a nonlinear environment.

LCC3412.subject: LCC
LCC3412.name: Communicating Sci/Tech
LCC3412.description: Examines both the theoretical and practical issues involved in communicating scientific and/or technological material to a variety of lay audiences.

LCC3414.subject: LCC
LCC3414.name: Intellectual Property
LCC3414.description: This course introduces students to intellectual property issues, focusing on ways that policy shapes national character and on application of constitutional and statutory law. Credit not allowed for both LCC 3414 and LCC 6319.

LCC3502.subject: LCC
LCC3502.name: Medieval Lit & Culture
LCC3502.description: Introduction to Greece, Rome, and Medieval Europe through an examination of one or a few major cultural conflicts expressed in the literary genres and periods.

LCC3504.subject: LCC
LCC3504.name: Renaissance Lit& Culture
LCC3504.description: An examination of literature and culture from 1450 to 1650 with an emphasis on both major achievements and divergent voices.

LCC3506.subject: LCC
LCC3506.name: Enlightenment Lit & Cult
LCC3506.description: Examines the nature of the age from an initial boldness, optimism, and faith in reason to a recognition of its limits.

LCC3508.subject: LCC
LCC3508.name: American Culture I
LCC3508.description: American literature from the Puritan period through the Civil War, including major movements, key authors and texts, study of literary works within broader historical and cultural context.

LCC3510.subject: LCC
LCC3510.name: American Culture II
LCC3510.description: Examines representations of the United States from its geographical expansion in the late-nineteenth century to the closing of the frontier and emergence as global power.

LCC3512.subject: LCC
LCC3512.name: Brit/Cont Romanticism
LCC3512.description: Examines British and Continental Romanticism as it appeared during the latter part of the eighteenth century and the first half of the nineteenth century.

LCC3514.subject: LCC
LCC3514.name: Victorian Lit & Culture
LCC3514.description: Investigates the period 1830-1901 in English literature and culture, focusing on how that period defined key questions, especially ones about human nature, society, and the relation of religion to science.

LCC3516.subject: LCC
LCC3516.name: Lit & Cultural Modernism
LCC3516.description: A partial investigation of the aesthetic ferment that characterizes English-language cultural production from the turn of the century to the end of World War II.

LCC3518.subject: LCC
LCC3518.name: Lit/Cult Postmodernism
LCC3518.description: A survey of major themes, representational techniques, and social and cultural concerns of postmodern art and literature.

LCC3661.subject: LCC
LCC3661.name: Theatre Production III
LCC3661.description: In this "hands-on" course, students will create and execute a publicity campaign and operate the box office for DramaTech Theatre productions.

LCC3662.subject: LCC
LCC3662.name: Theatre Production IV
LCC3662.description: This course provides students an opportunity to perform onstage in a production at DramaTech Theatre. Auditions are required.

LCC3705.subject: LCC
LCC3705.name: Prin-Information Design
LCC3705.description: Presents principles and practices guiding the development of emerging digital genres. Emphasis on maximizing the affordances of the computer in organizing and communicating complex information.

LCC3710.subject: LCC
LCC3710.name: Prin-Interaction Design
LCC3710.description: Examines principles of design for shaping the procedural and participatory affordances of digital environments, emphasizing the role of cultural context and media transitions.

LCC3823.subject: LCC
LCC3823.name: Special Topics Lit/Cult
LCC3823.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in literary and cultural studies.

LCC3833.subject: LCC
LCC3833.name: Special Topics in STAC
LCC3833.description: Study of one or more current issues in science, technology, and culture.

LCC3843.subject: LCC
LCC3843.name: Spec Topic-Communication
LCC3843.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in communication studies.

LCC3853.subject: LCC
LCC3853.name: Special Topics in Film
LCC3853.description: Examines one or more current topics in film studies.

LCC3863.subject: LCC
LCC3863.name: Spec Topics-Performance
LCC3863.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in performance studies.

LCC4100.subject: LCC
LCC4100.name: Seminar in STAC
LCC4100.description: A capstone seminar to the major, this course will ask students to draw upon their training in order to engage topical issues in the cultural studies of science.

LCC4102.subject: LCC
LCC4102.name: Senior Thesis
LCC4102.description: Preparation for and writing of a thesis through faculty-directed independent study.

LCC4200.subject: LCC
LCC4200.name: Seminar in Lit/Cult
LCC4200.description: Concentration on a single literary or cultural theorist and/or a major school of literary or cultural theory. Schools of theory that will be considered include, among others, Materialist, Feminist, Structuralist, Post-Structuralist, and Cultural Studies.

LCC4204.subject: LCC
LCC4204.name: Poetry and Poetics II
LCC4204.description: Advanced study of the traditions of poetic theory and practice in conjunction with a weekly workshop session centered on students' own poetry.

LCC4300.subject: LCC
LCC4300.name: Sem-Biomedicine&Culture
LCC4300.description: This course offers an opportunity to investigate in-depth biomedical issues, biomedical concerns in a particular period, or the impact of technological development on biomedicine.

LCC4400.subject: LCC
LCC4400.name: Seminar in Media Studies
LCC4400.description: Offers an in-depth investigation of the historical development and cultural impact of different forms of media including: television, film, and interactive electronic applications.

LCC4402.subject: LCC
LCC4402.name: Basic Multimedia Design
LCC4402.description: Introduces students to client and user needs and technology assessments, the interactive design process, and to creation of proof-of-concept applications using Macromedia Director.

LCC4404.subject: LCC
LCC4404.name: Adv Design & Production
LCC4404.description: Intensive studio course dealing with advanced concepts and techniques of the design and production of interactive multimedia.

LCC4406.subject: LCC
LCC4406.name: Profession Communication
LCC4406.description: Intended primarily for students planning careers in professional communication, this course will alternate among a number of issues including intellectual property law, integrating print and electronic media, and cultural studies of corporate environments.

LCC4500.subject: LCC
LCC4500.name: Seminar in Film Studies
LCC4500.description: An in-depth investigation of a major movement, theory, period, or technological development in film studies.

LCC4600.subject: LCC
LCC4600.name: Seminar in Performance
LCC4600.description: An in-depth investigation of a specific issue or theme in Performance Studies.

LCC4602.subject: LCC
LCC4602.name: Performance Practicum
LCC4602.description: Practical experience and theoretical investigations in theatre and performance making including acting, directing, designing, playwriting, performance art, performance and new media.

LCC4698.subject: LCC
LCC4698.name: Research Assistantship
LCC4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LCC4699.subject: LCC
LCC4699.name: Undergraduate Research
LCC4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LCC4701.subject: LCC
LCC4701.name: Ug Rsch Proposal Writing
LCC4701.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing a proposal for their research option project and thesis. Prerequisite: 3 hours total of undergraduate research (xx2698, xx2699 xx4698, or xx4699) either before entry to class or during same term. Credit not allowed for both LCC 4701 and LCC 4700.

LCC4702.subject: LCC
LCC4702.name: Ug Rsch Thesis Writing
LCC4702.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing their final thesis for the research option. Prerequisite: 9 total hours of undergraduate research (xx2698, xx2699, xx4698, or xx4699) must have been completed before the course or by completion of course. Credit not allowed for both LCC 4702 and LCC 4700.

LCC4720.subject: LCC
LCC4720.name: Interactive Narrative
LCC4720.description: Examines significant examples of this emerging genre, including its roots in experimental uses of older media, and engages students in creating their own interactive narrative.

LCC4725.subject: LCC
LCC4725.name: Games Dsgn-Cultural Prac
LCC4725.description: Emphasis is on the design elements common to games and the expressive possibilities and cultural concerns specific to digital games.

LCC4730.subject: LCC
LCC4730.name: Experimental Digital Art
LCC4730.description: Provides students with key conceptual, formal, aesthetic and technical elements needed in creating artifacts in areas ranging from augmented and mixed reality to scientific visualization.

LCC4731.subject: LCC
LCC4731.name: Game AI
LCC4731.description: Examines expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games.

LCC4732.subject: LCC
LCC4732.name: Intelligent Story Sys
LCC4732.description: Examines AI-based approaches to representing, understanding, and generating stories.

LCC4811.subject: LCC
LCC4811.name: Special Topics
LCC4811.description: Topics of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LCC4812.subject: LCC
LCC4812.name: Special Topics
LCC4812.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LCC4813.subject: LCC
LCC4813.name: Special Topics
LCC4813.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LCC4814.subject: LCC
LCC4814.name: Special Topics
LCC4814.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LCC4824.subject: LCC
LCC4824.name: Special Topics
LCC4824.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LCC4904.subject: LCC
LCC4904.name: Internship
LCC4904.description: Offers students a workplace-based learning experience that stresses application of principles and skills gained in other STC classes.

LCC4906.subject: LCC
LCC4906.name: Special Problems
LCC4906.description: Study of specialized aspects of literature or cultural studies selected on the basis of current interest.

LCC6213.subject: LCC
LCC6213.name: Educ Appls-New Media
LCC6213.description: This seminar introduces students to a variety of perspectives on learning as they apply to work in educational technology.

LCC6215.subject: LCC
LCC6215.name: Media Studies
LCC6215.description: This course focuses on the study of mass media from historical, theoretical, and cultural perspectives.

LCC6310.subject: LCC
LCC6310.name: Comput-Expressive Medium
LCC6310.description: Explores the development of the representational power of the computer and the interplay between digital technology and culture.

LCC6311.subject: LCC
LCC6311.name: Visual Culture & Design
LCC6311.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts.

LCC6312.subject: LCC
LCC6312.name: Dsgn,Tech&Representation
LCC6312.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues raised by technologies of representation through critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts.

LCC6313.subject: LCC
LCC6313.name: Prin-Interactive Design
LCC6313.description: Design principles of exploiting the affordances of the digital medium, including large information spaces and procedural environments.

LCC6314.subject: LCC
LCC6314.name: Design Networked Media
LCC6314.description: Issues in hypertextual and multimedia design in networked environments, including the World Wide Web, interactive television, and wireless applications.

LCC6315.subject: LCC
LCC6315.name: Project Production
LCC6315.description: Focuses on defining user and client needs, analysis of competing products, budgeting, scheduling and management of the production process, and the design of the testing process.

LCC6316.subject: LCC
LCC6316.name: History Digital Media
LCC6316.description: Examines digital media in the context of earlier media, such as handwriting and printing as well as photography, radio, film, and television.

LCC6317.subject: LCC
LCC6317.name: Interactive Fiction
LCC6317.description: Students create interactive fictions in a variety of formats including intersecting story worlds, interactive characters, simulations, and replay worlds.

LCC6318.subject: LCC
LCC6318.name: Experimental Media
LCC6318.description: Students will develop the critical, intellectual, and creative tools necessary to understand, work with, and reimagine design at the developmental stages of emerging technologies.

LCC6319.subject: LCC
LCC6319.name: Intellect Prop Plcy&Law
LCC6319.description: Students examine constitutionally informed policy and pragmatic legal issues in intellectual property law, focusing on the effects of power structures and information digitization. Credit not allowed for both LCC 6319 and LCC 3414.

LCC6320.subject: LCC
LCC6320.name: Globalization& New Media
LCC6320.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information.

LCC6321.subject: LCC
LCC6321.name: Arch-Responsive Spaces
LCC6321.description: Students explore the architecture of hybrid computational and physical spaces, and how we can build habitations configured of physical matter and responsive computational media.

LCC6325.subject: LCC
LCC6325.name: Game Design and Analysis
LCC6325.description: Focused topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including issues of creation, and reception, such as a single sub-genre, procedural technique, or media tradition.

LCC6330.subject: LCC
LCC6330.name: Expressive Virtual Space
LCC6330.description: Practical and theoretical investigation of virtual space in real-time 3D environments with a focus on meditation and functionality.

LCC6340.subject: LCC
LCC6340.name: Mixed Reality Exp Design
LCC6340.description: This course introduces students to the design of digital experienced for education and entertainment using Augmented Reality, Tangible Computing, or other forms of Mixed Reality.

LCC6350.subject: LCC
LCC6350.name: Spatial Const of Meaning
LCC6350.description: Study of the way in which space is manipulated to construct meaning in design formulation. Emphasis on logical structure, geometry, and experiential correlates.

LCC6399.subject: LCC
LCC6399.name: Discovery & Invention
LCC6399.description: This course provides students with a survey of applied research methods for digital media design, emphasizing how to develop innovative computational products and services.

LCC6650.subject: LCC
LCC6650.name: Project Studio
LCC6650.description: This course offers students the opportunity to work on focused research within existing long-term projects of the New Media Center (NMC).

LCC6743.subject: LCC
LCC6743.name: STS Core Seminar
LCC6743.description: This survey course covers key works in Science, Technology & Society, and guest lectures introduce students to faculty doing STS-related research across the Ivan Allen College. Credit not allowed for both LCC 6743 and PUBP 6743 or HTS 6743.

LCC6748.subject: LCC
LCC6748.name: Social Justice & Design
LCC6748.description: Focuses on social justice from a Science, Technology, and Society (STS) point of view that is informed by critical theory and philosophy of design. Cerdit not allowed for both LCC 6748 and PUBP 6748.

LCC6749.subject: LCC
LCC6749.name: Feminist Theory STS
LCC6749.description: This course is an advanced science, technology and society (STS) seminar in feminist theory. Credit not allowed for both LCC 6749 and PUBP 6749.

LCC6753.subject: LCC
LCC6753.name: HCI Prof Prep & Practice
LCC6753.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Speakers. Atlanta-area lab visits. Career trajectories. Project presentations. Technical, resume and interviewing skills, Atlanta-area HCI resources. Credit not allowed for both LCC 6753 and CS 6753 or PSYC 6753.

LCC6770.subject: LCC
LCC6770.name: Mixed reality Design
LCC6770.description: Introduction to the design of Mixed Reality experiences. Focuses on informal design, integration of media theory, HCI and technology issues. Significant group design projects.

LCC6800.subject: LCC
LCC6800.name: Master's Project
LCC6800.description: Final project course in information design and technology. Credit not allowed for both LCC 6800 and LCC 6998.

LCC6998.subject: LCC
LCC6998.name: HCI Master's Project
LCC6998.description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree in the Digital media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects. Credit not allowed for both LCC 6998 and LCC 6800.

LCC7000.subject: LCC
LCC7000.name: Master's Thesis
LCC7000.description: Final thesis course in information design and technology.

LCC8000.subject: LCC
LCC8000.name: Proseminar-Media Theory
LCC8000.description: Key traditions of media theory that contribute to the study of Digital Media.

LCC8001.subject: LCC
LCC8001.name: Digital Media Studies
LCC8001.description: Advanced work in production and critique of new media forms.

LCC8813.subject: LCC
LCC8813.name: Adv Issues-Interact Narr
LCC8813.description: Focused topics in the theory and practice of interactive narrative, both fiction and non-fiction, such as a single sub-genre, procedural technique, or media tradition.

LCC8823.subject: LCC
LCC8823.name: Spec Top-Game Dsgn&Analy
LCC8823.description: Advanced topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including creation, reception, procedural technique, and tradition.

LCC8831.subject: LCC
LCC8831.name: Sp Top-Tech of Represent
LCC8831.description: Topics in the theoretical investigation of the development of representational technology from scroll and codex to digital media.

LCC8832.subject: LCC
LCC8832.name: Sp Top-Tech of Represent
LCC8832.description: Topics in the theoretical investigation of the development of representational technology from scroll and codex to digital media.

LCC8833.subject: LCC
LCC8833.name: Sp Top-Tech of Represent
LCC8833.description: Topics in the theoretical investigation of the development of representational technology from scroll and codex to digital media.

LCC8903.subject: LCC
LCC8903.name: Special Problems in HCI
LCC8903.description: Small-group or individual investigation of advanced topics in human-computer interaction. Guided study and research.

LCC8997.subject: LCC
LCC8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
LCC8997.description: For graduate students holding teaching assistantships.

LCC8998.subject: LCC
LCC8998.name: Research Assistantship
LCC8998.description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

LING1813.subject: LING
LING1813.name: Special Topics
LING1813.description: Topics of current interest in Linguistics.

LING2100.subject: LING
LING2100.name: Intro to Linguistics
LING2100.description: Introductory course that surveys various fields in linguistics, including first/second language acquisition, phonetics/phonology, morphology/syntax, semantics/pragmatics, language variation, computational linguistics/natural language processing, and writing systems. Credit not allowed for both LING 2100 and LING 2001.

LING2698.subject: LING
LING2698.name: Research Assistantship
LING2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LING2699.subject: LING
LING2699.name: Undergraduate Research
LING2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LING2813.subject: LING
LING2813.name: Special Topics
LING2813.description: Topics of current interest in Linguistics.

LING3813.subject: LING
LING3813.name: Special Topics
LING3813.description: Permits students to work in languages not treated in other courses and/or engage in special language research.

LING3823.subject: LING
LING3823.name: Special Topics
LING3823.description: Topics of current interest in Linguistics.

LING3833.subject: LING
LING3833.name: Special Topics
LING3833.description: Topics of current interest in Linguistics.

LING4698.subject: LING
LING4698.name: Research Assistnatship
LING4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LING4699.subject: LING
LING4699.name: Undergraduate Research
LING4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LING4780.subject: LING
LING4780.name: Jpn Applied Linguistics
LING4780.description: This course helps to develop analytical skills to better understand human languages, particularly English and Japanese. Taught in English. Credit not allowed for both LING 4780 and JAPN 4780.

LING4813.subject: LING
LING4813.name: Special Topics
LING4813.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LING4823.subject: LING
LING4823.name: Special Topics
LING4823.description: Topics of current interest in Linguistics.

LING4833.subject: LING
LING4833.name: Special Topics
LING4833.description: Topics of current interest in Linguistics.

LING4901.subject: LING
LING4901.name: Special Prob-Linguistics
LING4901.description: Special problems course for advanced students; topics to be arranged with instructor.

LING4902.subject: LING
LING4902.name: Special Prob-Linguistics
LING4902.description: Special problems for advanced students; topics to be arranged with instructor.

LMC2000.subject: LMC
LMC2000.name: Intro-Lit, Media, & Comm
