LMC2000.description: An the introductory course to LMC, this course introduces students to key texts and modes of analysis associated with the study of literature, film, digital media, and communication.

LMC2050.subject: LMC
LMC2050.name: Lit, Media, Comm Seminar
LMC2050.description: This course introduces second-semester majors to the intellectual movements, interpretive frameworks, and research skills central to the disciplines represented in LMC.

LMC2100.subject: LMC
LMC2100.name: Intro to STAC
LMC2100.description: Relation to other courses, programs and curricula: As the introductory course to the LMC Science, Technology and Culture thread, this course explores the way in which disciplines construct and represent the knowledge they generate.

LMC2200.subject: LMC
LMC2200.name: Intro to Gender Studies
LMC2200.description: This course introduces the cultural concept of gender, examining topics such as biology and gender, social constructions of gender, and the psychology of sexual roles.

LMC2300.subject: LMC
LMC2300.name: Intro Biomedicine & Cult
LMC2300.description: This course provides an introduction to central cultural topics in biomedicine, such as health care, medical practice, medical research, and the systems of cultural meaning within which ideas of health and disease circulate.

LMC2400.subject: LMC
LMC2400.name: Intro to Media Studies
LMC2400.description: This course offers an introduction to the historical development and cultural impact of various forms of media print, radio, television, film, and interactive electronic applications.

LMC2500.subject: LMC
LMC2500.name: Intro to Film
LMC2500.description: Introduces film techniques and vocabulary in an historical and cultural context. Written texts are supplemented by viewings of specific shots, scenes, and films.

LMC2600.subject: LMC
LMC2600.name: Intro to Perform Studies
LMC2600.description: An examination of the origins of the field of performance studies in literary study of theatre and drama, anthropological investigations of ritual, and sociological analyses of performance in everyday life.

LMC2661.subject: LMC
LMC2661.name: Theatre Production I
LMC2661.description: In this hands-on course, students learn theatrical construction and painting techniques while building scenery for DramaTech productions.

LMC2662.subject: LMC
LMC2662.name: Theatre Production II
LMC2662.description: In this hands-on course, students create the lighting, property, and costume effects for two DramaTech Theatre productions.

LMC2698.subject: LMC
LMC2698.name: Research Assistantship
LMC2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC2699.subject: LMC
LMC2699.name: Undergraduate Research
LMC2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC2700.subject: LMC
LMC2700.name: Intr-Computational Media
LMC2700.description: Introduction to key concepts, methods, and achievements in computational media, and the convergence of digital technology with cultural traditions of representation.

LMC2720.subject: LMC
LMC2720.name: Prin of Visual Design
LMC2720.description: Studio-based course that provides students with basic skills needed to create digital visual images and to analyze designs from historical and theoretical perspectives.

LMC2730.subject: LMC
LMC2730.name: Construct-Moving Image
LMC2730.description: Provides the student with the conceptual, formal, aesthetic, and technical approaches to reconsider film, videos, and animation within the context of emerging digital forms.

LMC2813.subject: LMC
LMC2813.name: Special Topics in STAC
LMC2813.description: Study of one or more topics of current interest in the area of science, technology, and culture.

LMC2823.subject: LMC
LMC2823.name: Special Topics-Lit/Cult
LMC2823.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in literary and cultural studies.

LMC3102.subject: LMC
LMC3102.name: The Classical Tradition
LMC3102.description: Explores the definition and transmission of science and technology within Greek, Arabic, and medieval Latin contexts.

LMC3104.subject: LMC
LMC3104.name: Age Scientific Discovery
LMC3104.description: Examines the relationships among texts representing the literary, artistic, and scientific thought of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

LMC3106.subject: LMC
LMC3106.name: Age Sci Revolution
LMC3106.description: Examines interrelation of technological, literary, artistic, and philosophical thought in the late sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

LMC3108.subject: LMC
LMC3108.name: Sci Tech & Enlightenment
LMC3108.description: Considers the conceptual reformulation of the internal and external world urged by the sciences, technology, and culture of the Enlightenment.

LMC3110.subject: LMC
LMC3110.name: Sci, Tech & Romanticism
LMC3110.description: Examines the relationships among romantic ideology, science, and literature, including Romanticism's imaginative responses to Enlightenment science and the Industrial Revolution.

LMC3112.subject: LMC
LMC3112.name: Evolution&Industrial Age
LMC3112.description: Connects later nineteenth century scientific and technological concepts and discoveries, particularly theories of evolution, to the literature and culture of the industrial age.

LMC3114.subject: LMC
LMC3114.name: Sci, Tech & Modernism
LMC3114.description: Explores a cross-section of technological, scientific, and cultural production characteristics of the first half of the twentieth century.

LMC3116.subject: LMC
LMC3116.name: Sci Tech & Postmodernisms
LMC3116.description: Focuses on the relation among information technology, nonlinear physics, and the art, literature, and culture of postmodernism. Explores postmodern critiques of the Enlightenment and modernity.

LMC3118.subject: LMC
LMC3118.name: Sci Tech&American Empire
LMC3118.description: Considers nineteenth and twentieth century science and technology as they shaped American culture with particular attention to the relationship between science, technology, progress, and empire.

LMC3202.subject: LMC
LMC3202.name: Studies in Fiction
LMC3202.description: Examines the elements of fiction and what has made fiction, especially the novel, distinctive, popular, and enduring. Readings may include formal, cultural, and historical theories.

LMC3204.subject: LMC
LMC3204.name: Poetry and Poetics
LMC3204.description: A study of traditions of poetic practice and poetic theory in English through intensive line by line readings of poems from different periods in literary history.

LMC3206.subject: LMC
LMC3206.name: Communication & Culture
LMC3206.description: Examines ways in which forms and media of communication create and are created by other cultural constructs.

LMC3208.subject: LMC
LMC3208.name: African-Amer Lit/Cult
LMC3208.description: Explores the works of African American writers from the Colonial period to the present and examines a variety of cultural constructs that have fundamentally shaped the African American literary tradition.

LMC3210.subject: LMC
LMC3210.name: Ethnicity American Cult
LMC3210.description: Explores literary and historical works considering ethnic issues in American culture, including immigration, social assimilation, "double consciousness", the development of ethnic identity/pride, and multiculturalism.

LMC3212.subject: LMC
LMC3212.name: Women, Lit & Culture
LMC3212.description: Students in this course will analyze writings by women and examine feminist and other relevant cultural critiques of literature.

LMC3214.subject: LMC
LMC3214.name: Science Fiction
LMC3214.description: Examines science fiction texts from the last 200 years to show how they reflect ambigous reactions to change.

LMC3215.subject: LMC
LMC3215.name: Science Fiction Film TV
LMC3215.description: This course investigates science fiction as the genre developed during film history and has become one of the most popular forms of television narrative.

LMC3216.subject: LMC
LMC3216.name: Theatre I
LMC3216.description: The dramatic literature, theory, performance practices, and historical culture context of the theatre from prehistory through the Medieval period.

LMC3218.subject: LMC
LMC3218.name: Theatre II
LMC3218.description: The dramatic literature, theory, performance practices, and historical culture context of the theatre in the Renaissance and Restoration periods.

LMC3219.subject: LMC
LMC3219.name: Literature & Medicine
LMC3219.description: This course examines works of literature dealing overtly with illness and healing, works about or by physicians and other caregivers, and works that raise questions about ethical behavior in the face of sickness.

LMC3220.subject: LMC
LMC3220.name: Theatre III
LMC3220.description: The dramatic literature, theory, performance practices, and historical culture context of the theatre in the Renaissance and Restoration periods.

LMC3222.subject: LMC
LMC3222.name: Regionalism American Lit
LMC3222.description: Explores the literary and cultural representations of a particular American region or locale (the South, the West, California, New York City, etc.) and the role such presentations have played in the formation of both regional and national identity.

LMC3225.subject: LMC
LMC3225.name: Gender Study-Disciplines
LMC3225.description: This course explores the concept of gender and its usefulness as a theoretical category in a variety of disciplines. It includes cultural studies of literature, communication media, cultural anthropology, sociology, history, and science.

LMC3226.subject: LMC
LMC3226.name: Major Authors
LMC3226.description: An examination of the works and career of a major author in historical and cultural context.

LMC3228.subject: LMC
LMC3228.name: Shakespeare
LMC3228.description: An examination of Shakespeare's works with attention to generic conventions, historical context, and the relationship of text and performance. Major works of Shakespeare's contemporaries are studied as appropriate.

LMC3234.subject: LMC
LMC3234.name: Creative Writing
LMC3234.description: This course explores a range of creative literary genres, and combines study and analysis of existing modes of one or more forms in order to establish a basis for original creative work by class members.

LMC3244.subject: LMC
LMC3244.name: Mod/Contemp Brit Poetry
LMC3244.description: This course examines British poetry of the last 100 years in relation to modern and postmodern modes of cultural expression, philosophy, and literary critcism.

LMC3248.subject: LMC
LMC3248.name: Poetry & Digital Culture
LMC3248.description: This course examines modernist, postmodern, and contemporary poetry in relation to digital culture, including the computer, World Wide Web, Web 2.0, social media, and apps.

LMC3252.subject: LMC
LMC3252.name: Film and Television
LMC3252.description: Explores in depth a theoretical issue central to film and/or television. Among its concerns are authorship, genre history, spectatorship, ideology, narrative theory, and the relationship between these media and social history.

LMC3253.subject: LMC
LMC3253.name: Animation
LMC3253.description: This course examines animation from its earliest days as a "cinema of attractions' to its current development as a predominantly digital practice.

LMC3254.subject: LMC
LMC3254.name: Film History
LMC3254.description: Surveys the history of film from its machine origins to its present digital developments. It focuses on various movements, figures, and narrative developments in world cinema.

LMC3255.subject: LMC
LMC3255.name: Cinema & Digital Culture
LMC3255.description: This course examines the impact of digital technologies on contemporary cinema as well as the influence of different cinematic traditions on new digital media.

LMC3256.subject: LMC
LMC3256.name: Major Filmmakers
LMC3256.description: Traces in depth an individual artist's career and affords students the opportunity to immerse themselves in the works of an important figure in the world of film.

LMC3257.subject: LMC
LMC3257.name: Global Cinema
LMC3257.description: This course examines selected movements, styles, and trends in world cinema, emphasizing how contemporary film's global nature affects cultural representation.

LMC3258.subject: LMC
LMC3258.name: Documentary Film
LMC3258.description: This course examines significant movements, styles, and trends in fact-based film, emphasizing its cultural implications and formal strategies.

LMC3259.subject: LMC
LMC3259.name: Experimental Film
LMC3259.description: This course examines the history and trends in experimental film and video, emphasizing the relationship to avant-garde art movements.

LMC3262.subject: LMC
LMC3262.name: Performance Studies
LMC3262.description: An examination of cultural theories of performance and their application to the analysis of specific performative events.

LMC3302.subject: LMC
LMC3302.name: Sci, Tech & Ideology
LMC3302.description: Examines specific scientific, philosophical, and literary/cultural texts in order to determine the role ideology plays in the construction of culture, especially scientific and technological culture.

LMC3304.subject: LMC
LMC3304.name: Science, Tech & Gender
LMC3304.description: Examines specific philosophical, scientific, and cultural texts to determine the role that gender has played in the scientific and technological knowledge, currently and historically.

LMC3306.subject: LMC
LMC3306.name: Science, Tech & Race
LMC3306.description: Examines specific historical and contemporary construction of race, within the prevailing scientific theories and ideologies in order to determine the role played by "race" in scientific and technological culture.

LMC3308.subject: LMC
LMC3308.name: Environment Ecocritic
LMC3308.description: Surveys the emergence of ecocriticism as an analytical framework for interpreting the verbal and visual rhetorics of environmentalism in both western and nonwestern cultures.

LMC3310.subject: LMC
LMC3310.name: Rhetoric Sci Inquiry
LMC3310.description: This course takes as its subject the ways in which argumentative and persuasive discourse is used to create and disseminate scientific knowledge.

LMC3314.subject: LMC
LMC3314.name: Tech of Representation
LMC3314.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues related by technologies of representation, including written, spoken, and gestural languages; print, painting and illustration; still and moving photography; recorded sound; and computer mediated communications and interactive digital media.

LMC3316.subject: LMC
LMC3316.name: Postcolonialism
LMC3316.description: Studies in the development of Postcolonial literary theory and historiography in order to analyze the interdependent discourses and practices of post-Enlightenment science/technology and European imperialism.

LMC3318.subject: LMC
LMC3318.name: Biomedicine & Culture
LMC3318.description: Discuss the history of biology and medicine; popular representations of health, disease, and the medical establishment; and the cultural implications of medical imaging technologies.

LMC3352.subject: LMC
LMC3352.name: Film Technology
LMC3352.description: Examines the development of film technology and the implications of that technology for cinema's treatment of technology.

LMC3362.subject: LMC
LMC3362.name: Sci, Tech & Performance
LMC3362.description: Examines contemporary theories of performance in relation to the production of scientific knowledge and technologies of representation.

LMC3402.subject: LMC
LMC3402.name: Graphic & Visual Design
LMC3402.description: Introduction to fundamentals of graphic and visual design of print and digital media. Familiarity with use of the World Wibe Web, page layout, and computer graphic software recommended.

LMC3403.subject: LMC
LMC3403.name: Tech Communication
LMC3403.description: This course introduces students to workplace document genres to develop visual and verbal skills in critical analysis and document development.

LMC3406.subject: LMC
LMC3406.name: Video Production
LMC3406.description: An introduction to video production including basic skills in storyboarding, scripting, filming, editing, and sound.

LMC3408.subject: LMC
LMC3408.name: Rhetoric-Tech Narratives
LMC3408.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by such narrative documents as technical proposals, recommendations reports, grant proposals, and marketing studies. Emphasis on document design, graphics, navigation systems, and editing.

LMC3410.subject: LMC
LMC3410.name: Non-Linear Documents
LMC3410.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by hypertext documents. Emphasis in designing for multiple audiences, page and document design, and navigation in a nonlinear environment.

LMC3412.subject: LMC
LMC3412.name: Communicating Sci/Tech
LMC3412.description: Examines both the theoretical and practical issues involved in communicating scientific and/or technological material to a variety of lay audiences.

LMC3414.subject: LMC
LMC3414.name: Intellectual Property
LMC3414.description: This course introduces students to intellectual property issues, focusing on ways that policy shapes national character and on application of constitutional and statutory law.

LMC3431.subject: LMC
LMC3431.name: Tech Comm Approaches
LMC3431.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written, visual, oral, and analytic strategies.

LMC3432.subject: LMC
LMC3432.name: Tech Comm Strategies
LMC3432.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written, visual, oral, and analytic strategies.

LMC3502.subject: LMC
LMC3502.name: Medieval Lit & Culture
LMC3502.description: Introduction to Greece, Rome, and Medieval Europe through an examination of one or a few major culture conflicts expressed in the literary genres and periods.

LMC3504.subject: LMC
LMC3504.name: Renaisance Lit&Culture
LMC3504.description: An examination of literature and culture from 1450 to 1650 with an emphasis on both major achievements and divergent voices.

LMC3506.subject: LMC
LMC3506.name: Enlightenment Lit & Cult
LMC3506.description: Examines the nature of the age from an intial boldness, optimism, and faith in reason to a recognition of its limits.

LMC3508.subject: LMC
LMC3508.name: American Culture I
LMC3508.description: American literature from the Puritan period through the Civil War, including major movements, key authors and texts, study of literary works within broader historical and cultural context.

LMC3510.subject: LMC
LMC3510.name: American Culture II
LMC3510.description: Examines presentations of the United States from its geographical expansion in the late-nineteenth century to the closing of the frontier and emergence as global power.

LMC3512.subject: LMC
LMC3512.name: Brit/Cont Romanticism
LMC3512.description: Examines British and Continental Romanticism as it appeared during the latter part of the eighteenth century and the first half of the nineteenth century.

LMC3514.subject: LMC
LMC3514.name: Victorian Lit & Culture
LMC3514.description: Investigates the period 1830 - 1901 in English literature and culture, focusing on how that period defined key questions, especially ones about human nature, society, and the relation of religion to science.

LMC3516.subject: LMC
LMC3516.name: Lit & Cultural Modernism
LMC3516.description: A partial investigation of the aesthetic ferment that characterizes English-language cultural production from the turn of the century to the end of World War II.

LMC3518.subject: LMC
LMC3518.name: Lit/Cult Postmodernism
LMC3518.description: A survey of major themes, representational techniques, and social and cultural concerns of postmodern art and literature.

LMC3661.subject: LMC
LMC3661.name: Theatre Production III
LMC3661.description: In this "hands-on" course, students will create and execute a publicity campaign and operate the box office for DramaTech Theatre productions.

LMC3662.subject: LMC
LMC3662.name: Theatre Production IV
LMC3662.description: This course providess students an opportunity to perform onstage in a production at DramaTech Theatre. Auditions are required.

LMC3705.subject: LMC
LMC3705.name: Prin Information Design
LMC3705.description: Presents principles and practices guiding the development of emerging digital genres. Emphasis on maximizing the affordances of the computer in organizing and communicating complex information.

LMC3710.subject: LMC
LMC3710.name: Prin Interaction Design
LMC3710.description: Examines principles of design for shaping the procedural and participatory affordances of digital environments, emphasizing the role of cultural context and media transitions.

LMC3773.subject: LMC
LMC3773.name: Global Issues&Leadership
LMC3773.description: This project based class uses global issues to explore diverse viewpoints, cultures and cognitive biases to develop leadership and presentation skills in small diverse groups.

LMC3823.subject: LMC
LMC3823.name: Special Topics Lit/Cult
LMC3823.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in literary and cultural studies.

LMC3833.subject: LMC
LMC3833.name: Special Topics in STAC
LMC3833.description: Study of one or more current issues in science, technology, and culture.

LMC3843.subject: LMC
LMC3843.name: Spec Topic-Communication
LMC3843.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in communication studies.

LMC3853.subject: LMC
LMC3853.name: Special Topics in Film
LMC3853.description: Examines one or more current topics in film studies.

LMC3863.subject: LMC
LMC3863.name: Spec Topics-Performance
LMC3863.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in performance studies.

LMC4100.subject: LMC
LMC4100.name: Seminar in STAC
LMC4100.description: A capstone seminar to the LMC major, this course will ask students to draw upon their training in order to engage topical issues in the cultural studies of science.

LMC4102.subject: LMC
LMC4102.name: Senior Thesis
LMC4102.description: Preparation for and writing of a thesis through faculty-directed independent study.

LMC4200.subject: LMC
LMC4200.name: Seminar Lit/Cult Theory
LMC4200.description: Concentration on a single literary or cultural theorist and/or a major school of literary or cultural theory. Schools of theory that will be considered include, among others, Materialist, Feminist, Structuralist, Post-Structuralist, and Cultural Studies.

LMC4204.subject: LMC
LMC4204.name: Poetry and Poetics II
LMC4204.description: Advanced study of the traditions of poetic theory and practice with a special emphasis on processes of poetic conception and revision.

LMC4300.subject: LMC
LMC4300.name: Seminar Biomed & Culture
LMC4300.description: This course offers an opportunity to investigate in-depth biomedical issues, biomedical concerns in a particular period, or the impact of technological development on biomedicine.

LMC4400.subject: LMC
LMC4400.name: Seminar in Media Studies
LMC4400.description: Offers an in-depth investigation of the historical development and cultural impact of different forms of media including: television, film, and interactive electronic applications.

LMC4406.subject: LMC
LMC4406.name: Professional Comm
LMC4406.description: Intended primarily for students planning careers in professional communication, this course will alternate among a number of issues including property law, integrating print and electronic media, and cultural studies of corporate environments.

LMC4500.subject: LMC
LMC4500.name: Seminar in Film Studies
LMC4500.description: An in-depth investigation of a major movement, theory, period, or technological development in film studies.

LMC4600.subject: LMC
LMC4600.name: Seminar Perform Studies
LMC4600.description: An in-depth investigation of a specific issue or theme in Performance Studies.

LMC4602.subject: LMC
LMC4602.name: Performance Practicum
LMC4602.description: Practical experience and theoretical investigations in theatre and performance making including acting, directing, designing, playwriting, performance art, performance and new media.

LMC4698.subject: LMC
LMC4698.name: Research Assistantship
LMC4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC4699.subject: LMC
LMC4699.name: Undergraduate Research
LMC4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC4701.subject: LMC
LMC4701.name: US Rsch Proposal Writing
LMC4701.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing a proposal for their research option project and thesis.

LMC4702.subject: LMC
LMC4702.name: US Rsch Thesis Writing
LMC4702.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing their undergraduate thesis.

LMC4720.subject: LMC
LMC4720.name: Interactive Narrative
LMC4720.description: Examines significant examples of this emerging genre, including its roots ini experimental uses of older media, and engages students in creating their own interactive narrative.

LMC4725.subject: LMC
LMC4725.name: Game Design
LMC4725.description: Emphasis is on the design elements common to games and the expressive possibilities and cultural concerns specific to digital games.

LMC4730.subject: LMC
LMC4730.name: Experimental Digital Art
LMC4730.description: Provides students with key conceptual, formal, aesthetic and technical elements needed in creating artifacts in areas ranging from augmented and mixed reality to scientific visualization.

LMC4731.subject: LMC
LMC4731.name: Game AI
LMC4731.description: Examines expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games.

LMC4811.subject: LMC
LMC4811.name: Special Topics
LMC4811.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC4812.subject: LMC
LMC4812.name: Special Topics
LMC4812.description: Topics of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC4813.subject: LMC
LMC4813.name: Special Topics
LMC4813.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC4815.subject: LMC
LMC4815.name: Special Topics
LMC4815.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC4904.subject: LMC
LMC4904.name: Internship
LMC4904.description: Offers students a workplace-based learning experience that stresses application of principles and skills gained in other STAC classes.

LMC6213.subject: LMC
LMC6213.name: Edu Applications New
LMC6213.description: This course introduces students to a variety of perspectives on learning as they apply to work in educational technology. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6213 and LCC 6213.

LMC6215.subject: LMC
LMC6215.name: Issues in Media Studies
LMC6215.description: This course focuses on the study of mass media from historical, theoretical, and cultutral perspectives. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6215 and LCC 6215.

LMC6310.subject: LMC
LMC6310.name: The Computer Expressive
LMC6310.description: Explores the development of the representational power of the computer and the interplay between digital technology and culture. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6310 and LCC 6310.

LMC6311.subject: LMC
LMC6311.name: Visual Culture and Desi
LMC6311.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6311 and LCC 6311.

LMC6312.subject: LMC
LMC6312.name: Dsgn Tech & Representati
LMC6312.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues raised by technologies of representation through critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6312 and LCC 6312.

LMC6313.subject: LMC
LMC6313.name: Prin of Interaction Desi
LMC6313.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6313 and LCC 6313.

LMC6314.subject: LMC
LMC6314.name: Design of Networked Medi
LMC6314.description: Issues in hypertextual and multimedia design in networked environments, including the World Wide Web, interactive television, and wireless applications. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6314 and LCC 6314.

LMC6315.subject: LMC
LMC6315.name: Produc Production
LMC6315.description: Focuses on defining user and client needs, analysis of competing products, budgeting, scheduling and management of the production process, and the design of the testing process. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6315 and LCC 6315.

LMC6316.subject: LMC
LMC6316.name: Historical Approahces Di
LMC6316.description: Examines digital media in the context of earlier media, such as handwriting and printing as well as photography, radio, film, and television. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6316 and LCC 6316.

LMC6317.subject: LMC
LMC6317.name: Interactive Fiction
LMC6317.description: Students create interactive fictions in a variety of formats including intersecting story worlds, interactive characters, simulations, and replay worlds. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6317 and LCC 6317, LMC 6317 and LCC 4720, or LMC 6317 and LMC 4720.

LMC6318.subject: LMC
LMC6318.name: Experimental Media
LMC6318.description: Students will develop the critical, intellectual, and creative tools necessary to understand, work with, and reimagine design at the developmental stages of emerging technologies. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6318 and LCC 6318.

LMC6319.subject: LMC
LMC6319.name: Intellectual Property
LMC6319.description: Students examine constitutionally informed policy and pragmatic legal issues in intellectual property law, focusing on the effects of power structures and information digitization. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6319 and LCC 6319.

LMC6320.subject: LMC
LMC6320.name: Globalization and New Me
LMC6320.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6320 and LCC 6320.

LMC6321.subject: LMC
LMC6321.name: Architecture of Responsi
LMC6321.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6321 and LCC 6321.

LMC6325.subject: LMC
LMC6325.name: Game Design and Analysis
LMC6325.description: Focused topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including issues of creation, and reception, such as a single sub-genre, procedural technique, or media tradition. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6325 and LCC 6325, LMC 6325 and LCC 4725, or LMC 6325 and LMC 4725.

LMC6330.subject: LMC
LMC6330.name: Expressive Virtual Space
LMC6330.description: Practical and theoretical investigation of virtual space in real-time 3D environments with a focus on meditation and functionality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6330 and LCC 6330.

LMC6340.subject: LMC
LMC6340.name: Reality Experience Desi
LMC6340.description: This course introduces students to the design of digital experienced for education and entertainment using Augmented Reality, Tangible Computing, or other forms of Mixed Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6340 and LCC 6340.

LMC6350.subject: LMC
LMC6350.name: Spatial Construction
LMC6350.description: Study of the way in which space is manipulated to construct meaning in design formulation. Emphasis on logical structure, geometry, and experiential correlates. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6350 and LCC 6350.

LMC6399.subject: LMC
LMC6399.name: Discovery & Invention
LMC6399.description: Required course for all DM majors. The purpose of this course is to give students a suite of methods they can use in professional settings to discover opportunities for inventive new computational products and services. It complements the design and production skills developed in 6310 and 6313 with applied research skills. For students in the MS DM and MS HCI programs it will also help them in the development of their MS proposals. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6399 and LCC 6399.

LMC6650.subject: LMC
LMC6650.name: Project Studio
LMC6650.description: This course offers students the opportunity to work on focused research within existing long-term projects of the New Media(NM) Center.

LMC6743.subject: LMC
LMC6743.name: STS Core Seminar
LMC6743.description: This survey course covers key works Science, Technology & Society, and guest lectures introduce students to faculty doing STS-related research across the Ivan Allen College. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6743 and LCC 6743, LMC 6743 and HTS 6743, or LMC 6743 and PUBP 6743.

LMC6748.subject: LMC
LMC6748.name: Social Justice & Design
LMC6748.description: Focuses on social justice from a Science, Technology, and Society(STS) point of view that is informed by critical theory and philosophy of design. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6748 and LCC 6748 or LMC 6748 and PUBP 6748.

LMC6749.subject: LMC
LMC6749.name: Feminist Theory and STS
LMC6749.description: This course is an advanced science, technology and society (STS) seminar in feminist theory. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6749 and LCC 6749 or LMC 6749 and PUBP 6749.

LMC6753.subject: LMC
LMC6753.name: HCI Prof Prep & Practice
LMC6753.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Speakers. Atlanta-area lab visits. Career trajectories. Project presentations. Technical, resume and interviewing skills, Atlanta-area HCI resources. Students cannot receieve credit for LMC 6753 and CS 6753, LMC 6753 and LCC 6753, LMC 6753 and ID 6753, or LMC 6753 or PSYC 6753.

LMC6770.subject: LMC
LMC6770.name: Mix Reality Design
LMC6770.description: This course introduces students to mixed reality design and prototyping with a focus on Augmented Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6770 and CS 4770.

LMC6800.subject: LMC
LMC6800.name: DM MS Project Course
LMC6800.description: Final project course in Digital Media.

LMC6998.subject: LMC
LMC6998.name: HCI Master's Project
LMC6998.description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree in the Digital Media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

LMC7000.subject: LMC
LMC7000.name: Master's Thesis
LMC7000.description: Final Thesis course in Digital Media.

LMC8000.subject: LMC
LMC8000.name: Media Theory
LMC8000.description: Key traditions of media theory that contribute to the study of Digital Media. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 8000 and LCC 8000.

LMC8001.subject: LMC
LMC8001.name: Digital Media Studies
LMC8001.description: Advanced work in production and critique of new media forms. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 8001 and LCC 8001.

LMC8801.subject: LMC
LMC8801.name: Special Topics
LMC8801.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC8823.subject: LMC
LMC8823.name: Special Topics in Game
LMC8823.description: Advanced topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including creation, reception, procedural technique, and tradition.

LMC8831.subject: LMC
LMC8831.name: Special Topics Tech Rep
LMC8831.description: Special Topics in Technologies of Representation

LMC8903.subject: LMC
LMC8903.name: Special Problems in HCI
LMC8903.description: Small-group of individual investigation of advanced topics in human-computer interaction. Guided study and research.

LMC8997.subject: LMC
LMC8997.name: Teaching Assistantship
LMC8997.description: For graduate students holding teaching assistantships

LMC8998.subject: LMC
LMC8998.name: Research Assistantship
LMC8998.description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

LMC8999.subject: LMC
LMC8999.name: PhD Doctoral Prep
LMC8999.description: Doctoral Thesis Prep in Digital Media

LS0198.subject: LS
LS0198.name: Reading Skills
LS0198.description: Development of reading comprehension and speed, vocabulary, and study skills. Review of grammar and usage.

LS0298.subject: LS
LS0298.name: English Skills
LS0298.description: Development of basic skills used in writing the sentence, paragraph, and short essay. Development of reading speed.

LS0398.subject: LS
LS0398.name: Mathematical Skills
LS0398.description: Intense review of arithmetic and algebra skills. Development of mathematics study skills.

MATH0399.subject: MATH
MATH0399.name: Support for Precalculus
MATH0399.description: Practicum for Learning Support students enrolled in MATH 1113 (Precalculus).

MATH1111.subject: MATH
MATH1111.name: Precalculus Without Trig
MATH1111.description: Analytic geometry, the function concept, polynomials, exponential logarithms, the theory of equations.

MATH1113.subject: MATH
MATH1113.name: Precalculus
MATH1113.description: Analytic geometry, the function concept, polynomials, exponential, logarithms, trigonometric functions, mathematical induction, and the theory of equations. May only be used for degree credit with departmental approval.

MATH1501.subject: MATH
MATH1501.name: Calculus I
MATH1501.description: Differential calculus and basic integral calculus including the fundamental theorem of calculus. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1501 and 1712.

MATH1502.subject: MATH
MATH1502.name: Calculus II
MATH1502.description: This course concludes the treatment of single variable calculus and begins linear algebra, the linear basis of the multivariable theory. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1502 and MATH 1522. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1502 and MATH 15X2.

MATH1503.subject: MATH
MATH1503.name: Calculus I For Life Sci
MATH1503.description: Differential and basic calculus: sequences, difference equations, limits, continuity, differentiation, integration, applications. The topics parallel those of MATH 1501 with applications from life sciences.

MATH1504.subject: MATH
MATH1504.name: Calculus II For Life Sci
MATH1504.description: Taylor approximations, introduction to differential equations, linear algebra, and introduction to multivariable calculus. Motivating examples drawn from life sciences.

MATH1511.subject: MATH
MATH1511.name: Honors Calculus I
MATH1511.description: The topics covered parallel those of 1501 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment. Credit not allowed for both honors calculus and the corresponding regular calculus course.

MATH1512.subject: MATH
MATH1512.name: Honors Calculus II
MATH1512.description: The topics covered parallel those of 1502 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment. Credit not allowed for both honors calculus and the corresponding regular calculus course. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1512 and MATH 1522. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1512 and MATH 15X2.

MATH1522.subject: MATH
MATH1522.name: Linear Algebra for Calc
MATH1522.description: Basic topics in linear algebra, such as covered in MATH 1502, and needed for MATH 2401. May not be taken for credit by students who have taken MATH 1502 or MATH 1512.

MATH1550.subject: MATH
MATH1550.name: Intro to Diff Calculus
MATH1550.description: An introduction to differential calculus including applications and the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1550 and MATH 1501, MATH 1551, or MATH 1503.

MATH1551.subject: MATH
MATH1551.name: Differential Calculus
MATH1551.description: Differential calculus including applications and the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1551 and MATH 1501, MATH 1503, or MATH 1550.

MATH1552.subject: MATH
MATH1552.name: Integral Calculus
MATH1552.description: Integral calculus: Definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration, improper integrals, infinite series, applications. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1552 and MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512 or MATH 1555.

MATH1553.subject: MATH
MATH1553.name: Intro to Linear Algebra
MATH1553.description: An introduction to linear alegbra including eigenvalues and eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1553 and MATH 1522, MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512, MATH 1554 or MATH 1564.

MATH1554.subject: MATH
MATH1554.name: Linear Algebra
MATH1554.description: Linear algebra eigenvalues, eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares, diagnolization, quadratic forms.

MATH1555.subject: MATH
MATH1555.name: Calculus Life Sciences
MATH1555.description: Overview of intergral calculus, multivariable calculus, and differential equations for biological sciences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1555 and MATH 1552, MATH 1502, MATH 1504 or MATH 1512.

MATH1564.subject: MATH
MATH1564.name: LinAlg w Abstract Vec Sp
MATH1564.description: This is an intensive first course in linear algebra including the theories of linear transformations and abstract vector spaces. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1564 and MATH 1553, MATH 1554, MATH 1522, MATH 1502, MATH 1504 or MATH 1512.

MATH15X2.subject: MATH
MATH15X2.name: Transfer Calculus II
MATH15X2.description: This course includes the treatment of single variable calculus in MATH 1502. This course is not equivalent to MATH 1502. Credit not allowed for both MATH 15X2 and MATH 1502. Credit not allowed for both MATH 15X2 and MATH 1512.

MATH1601.subject: MATH
MATH1601.name: Intro to Higher Math
MATH1601.description: This course is designed to teach problem solving and proof writing. Mathematical subject matter is drawn from elementary number theory and geometry.

MATH1711.subject: MATH
MATH1711.name: Finite Mathematics
MATH1711.description: Linear equations, matrices, linear programming, sets and counting, probability and statistics.

MATH1712.subject: MATH
MATH1712.name: Survey of Calculus
MATH1712.description: Techniques of differentiation, integration, application of integration to probability and statistics, multidimensional calculus. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1712 and 1501.

MATH1803.subject: MATH
MATH1803.name: Special Topics
MATH1803.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in Mathematics.

MATH2106.subject: MATH
MATH2106.name: Foundations Math Proof
MATH2106.description: An introduction to proofs in advanced mathematics, intended as a transition to upper division courses including Abstract Algebra I and Analysis I.

MATH2401.subject: MATH
MATH2401.name: Calculus III
MATH2401.description: Multivariable calculus: Linear approximation and Taylor's theorems, Lagrange multiples and constrained optimization, multiple integration and vector analysis including the theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes.

MATH2403.subject: MATH
MATH2403.name: Differential Equations
MATH2403.description: Methods for obtaining numerical and analytic solutions of elementary differential equations. Applications are also discussed with an emphasis on modeling.

MATH2406.subject: MATH
MATH2406.name: Abstract Vector Spaces
MATH2406.description: A proof-based development of linear algebra and vector spaces, with additional topics such as multilinear algebra and group theory.

MATH2411.subject: MATH
MATH2411.name: Honors Calculus III
MATH2411.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2401 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment. Credit is not allowed for both honors calculus and the corresponding regular calculus course.

MATH2413.subject: MATH
MATH2413.name: Honors Diff Equations
MATH2413.description: The course treats the theory of ordinary differential equations from an advanced perspective, delving into the theory as well as computational aspects. It is designed for mathematics majors, and others who wish to take advanced courses in the area.

MATH2551.subject: MATH
MATH2551.name: Multivariable Calculus
MATH2551.description: Multivariable calculus: Linear approximation and Taylor's theorems, Lagrange multiples and constrained optimization, multiple integration and vector analysis including the theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes. Credit will not be awarded for both MATH 2551 and MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2561.

MATH2552.subject: MATH
MATH2552.name: Differential Equations
MATH2552.description: Methods for obtaining numerical and analytic solutions of elementary differential equations. Applications are also discussed with an emphasis on modeling. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2552 and MATH 2403 or MATH 2413 or MATH 2562.

MATH2561.subject: MATH
MATH2561.name: Honors Multivar Calculus
MATH2561.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2551 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2561 and MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2551.

MATH2562.subject: MATH
MATH2562.name: Honors Diff Equations
MATH2562.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2552 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment.

MATH2602.subject: MATH
MATH2602.name: Linear and Discrete Math
MATH2602.description: Topics in linear algebra, sequences, differences, finite sums and difference equations, multivariate optimization with an emphasis in discrete and recursive methods.

MATH2603.subject: MATH
MATH2603.name: Intro Discrete Math
MATH2603.description: Mathematical logic and proof, mathematical induction, counting methods, recurrence relations, algorithms and complexity, graph theory and graph algorithms. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2603 and MATH 2602.

MATH2605.subject: MATH
MATH2605.name: Calc III for Comput Sci
MATH2605.description: Topics in linear algebra and multivariate calculus and their applications in optimization and numerical methods, including curve fitting, interpolation, and numerical differentiation and integration.

MATH2698.subject: MATH
MATH2698.name: Research Assistantship
MATH2698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MATH2699.subject: MATH
MATH2699.name: Undergraduate Research
MATH2699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MATH2801.subject: MATH
MATH2801.name: Special Topics
MATH2801.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH2802.subject: MATH
MATH2802.name: Special Topics
MATH2802.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH2803.subject: MATH
MATH2803.name: Special Topics
MATH2803.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH2804.subject: MATH
MATH2804.name: Special Topics
MATH2804.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH2805.subject: MATH
MATH2805.name: Special Topics
MATH2805.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH3012.subject: MATH
MATH3012.name: Applied Combinatorics
MATH3012.description: Elementary combinatorial techniques used in discrete problem solving: counting methods, solving linear recurrences, graph and network models, related algorithms, and combinatorial designs.

MATH3022.subject: MATH
MATH3022.name: Honors App Combinatorics
MATH3022.description: Topics are parallel to those of MATH 3012 with a more rigorous and intensive treatment. Credit is not allowed for both MATH 3012 and 3022.

MATH3215.subject: MATH
MATH3215.name: Probability & Statistics
MATH3215.description: This course is a problem-oriented introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics, providing a foundation for applications and further study.

MATH3225.subject: MATH
MATH3225.name: Honors Prob & Statistics
MATH3225.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 3215, with a more rigorous and intensive treatment. Credit is not allowed for both MATH 3215 and 3225.

MATH3670.subject: MATH
MATH3670.name: Statistics and Applns
MATH3670.description: Introduction to probability, probability distributions, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, linear regression and analysis of variance. Students cannot recieve credit for both MATH 3670 and MATH 3770 or ISYE 3770 or CEE 3770.

MATH3801.subject: MATH
MATH3801.name: Special Topics
MATH3801.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH3802.subject: MATH
MATH3802.name: Special Topics
MATH3802.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH3803.subject: MATH
MATH3803.name: Special Topics
MATH3803.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH3804.subject: MATH
MATH3804.name: Special Topics
MATH3804.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH3805.subject: MATH
MATH3805.name: Special Topics
MATH3805.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH4012.subject: MATH
MATH4012.name: Coding Theory
MATH4012.description: Introduction to linear error correcting codes with an emphasis on the algebraic tools required, including matrices vector spaces, groups, polynomial rings, and finite fields.

MATH4022.subject: MATH
MATH4022.name: Intro to Graph Theory
MATH4022.description: The fundamentals of graph theory: trees, connectivity, Euler torus, Hamilton cycles, matchings, colorings, and Ramsey theory.

MATH4032.subject: MATH
MATH4032.name: Combinatorial Analysis
MATH4032.description: Combinatorial problem-solving techniques including the use of generating functions, recurrence relations, Polya theory, combinatorial designs, Ramsey theory, matroids, and asymptotic analysis.

MATH4080.subject: MATH
MATH4080.name: Senior Project I
MATH4080.description: The first of a two-course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.

MATH4090.subject: MATH
MATH4090.name: Senior Project II
MATH4090.description: The second course of a two-course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.

MATH4107.subject: MATH
MATH4107.name: Abstract Algebra I
MATH4107.description: This course develops in the theme of "Arithmetic congruence and abstract algebraic structures". Strong emphasis on theory and proofs.

MATH4108.subject: MATH
MATH4108.name: Abstract Algebra II
MATH4108.description: Continuation of Abstract Algebra I, with emphasis on Galois theory, modules, polynomial fields, and the theory of linear associative algebra.

MATH4150.subject: MATH
MATH4150.name: Intro To Number Theory
MATH4150.description: Primes and unique factorization, congruences, Chinese remainder theorem, Diophantine equations, Diophantine approximations, quadratic reciprocity. Applications such as fast multiplication, factorization, and encryption.

MATH4221.subject: MATH
MATH4221.name: Stochastic Processes I
MATH4221.description: Simple random walk and the theory of discrete time Markov chains.

MATH4222.subject: MATH
MATH4222.name: Stochastic Processes II
MATH4222.description: Renewal theory, Poisson processes and continuous time Markov processes, including an introduction to Brownian motion and martingales.

MATH4255.subject: MATH
MATH4255.name: Monte Carlo Methods
MATH4255.description: Probability distributions, limit laws, and applications through the computer.

MATH4261.subject: MATH
MATH4261.name: Math Statistics I
MATH4261.description: Sampling distributions, Normal, t, chi-square, and f distributions. Moment-generating function methods, Bayesian estimation, and introduction to hypothesis testing.

MATH4262.subject: MATH
MATH4262.name: Math Statistics II
MATH4262.description: Hypothesis testing, likelihood ratio tests, nonparametric tests, bivariate and multivariate normal distributions.

MATH4280.subject: MATH
MATH4280.name: Information Theory
MATH4280.description: The measurement and quantification of information. These ideas are applied to the probabilistic analysis of the transmission of information over a channel along which random distortion of the message occurs.

MATH4305.subject: MATH
MATH4305.name: Linear Algebra
MATH4305.description: Finite dimensional vector spaces, inner product spaces, least squares, linear transformations, the spectral theorem for normal transformations. Applications to convex sets, positive matrices, difference equations.

MATH4317.subject: MATH
MATH4317.name: Analysis I
MATH4317.description: Real numbers, topology of Euclidean spaces, Cauchy sequences, completeness, continuity and compactness, uniform continuity, series of functions, Fourier series.

MATH4318.subject: MATH
MATH4318.name: Analysis II
MATH4318.description: Differentiation of functions of one real variable, Riemann-Stieltjes integral, the derivative in Rn, and integration in Rn.

MATH4320.subject: MATH
MATH4320.name: Complex Analysis
MATH4320.description: Topics from complex function theory, including contour integration and conformal mapping.

MATH4347.subject: MATH
MATH4347.name: Partial Diff Eqns I
MATH4347.description: Method of characteristics for first- and second-order partial differential equations, conservation laws and shocks, classification of second-order systems and applications.

MATH4348.subject: MATH
MATH4348.name: Partial Diff Eqns II
MATH4348.description: Green's functions and fundamental solutions. Potential, diffusion, and wave equations.

MATH4431.subject: MATH
MATH4431.name: Introduction to Topology
MATH4431.description: Point set topology, topological spaces and metric spaces, continuity and compactness, homotopy, and covering spaces.

MATH4432.subject: MATH
MATH4432.name: Algebraic Topology
MATH4432.description: Introduction to algebraic methods in topology. Includes homotopy, the fundamental group, covering spaces, simplicial complexes. Applications to fixed point theory and group theory.

MATH4441.subject: MATH
MATH4441.name: Differential Geometry
MATH4441.description: The theory of curves, surfaces, and more generally, manifolds. Curvature, parallel transport, covariant differentiation, Gauss-Bonet theorem.

MATH4541.subject: MATH
MATH4541.name: Dynamics& Bifurcations I
MATH4541.description: A broad introduction to the local and global behavior of nonlinear dynamical systems arising from maps and ordinary differential equations.

MATH4542.subject: MATH
MATH4542.name: Dynamics&Bifurcations II
MATH4542.description: A continuation of Dynamics and Bifurcations I.

MATH4580.subject: MATH
MATH4580.name: Linear Programming
MATH4580.description: A study of linear programming problems, including the simplex method, duality, and sensitivity analysis with applications to matrix games, interger programming, and networks.

MATH4581.subject: MATH
MATH4581.name: Math Methods in Engr
MATH4581.description: The Laplace transform and applications, Fourier series, boundary value problems for partial differential equations.

MATH4640.subject: MATH
MATH4640.name: Numerical Analysis I
MATH4640.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms for some basic problems in computational mathematics. Discussion of both implementation issues and error analysis.

MATH4641.subject: MATH
MATH4641.name: Numerical Analysis II
MATH4641.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of initial and boundary value problems in differential equations.

MATH4698.subject: MATH
MATH4698.name: Research Assistantship
MATH4698.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MATH4699.subject: MATH
MATH4699.name: Undergraduate Research
MATH4699.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MATH4755.subject: MATH
MATH4755.name: Mathematical Biology
MATH4755.description: Problems from the life sciences and the mathematical methods for solving them are presented. The underlying biological and mathematical principles and the interrelationships are emphasized. Crosslisted with BIOL 4755.

MATH4777.subject: MATH
MATH4777.name: Vector&Parallel Sci Comp
MATH4777.description: Scientific computational algorithms on vector and parallel computers. Speed-up and algorithm complexity, interprocesses communication, synchronization, modern algorithms for linear systems, programming techniques, code optimization. Crosslisted with CS 4777.

MATH4782.subject: MATH
MATH4782.name: Quantum Info&Quant Comp
MATH4782.description: Introduction to quantum computing and quantum information theory, formalism of quantum mechanics, quantum gates, algorithms, measurements, coding, and information. Physical realizations and experiments. Crosslisted with PHYS 4782.

MATH4801.subject: MATH
MATH4801.name: Special Topics
MATH4801.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH4802.subject: MATH
MATH4802.name: Special Topics
MATH4802.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH4803.subject: MATH
MATH4803.name: Special Topics
MATH4803.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH4804.subject: MATH
MATH4804.name: Special Topics
MATH4804.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH4805.subject: MATH
MATH4805.name: Special Topics
MATH4805.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

MATH4999.subject: MATH
MATH4999.name: Special Problems
MATH4999.description: Reading or research in topics of current interest.

MATH6014.subject: MATH
MATH6014.name: Graph Theory
MATH6014.description: Fundamentals, connectivity, matchings, colorings, extremal problems, Ramsey theory, planar graphs, perfect graphs. Applications to operations research and the design of efficient algorithms.

MATH6021.subject: MATH
MATH6021.name: Topology-Euclidean Space
MATH6021.description: Metric spaces, normed linear spaces, convexity, and separation; polyhedra and simplicial complexes; surfaces; Brouwer fixed point theorem.

MATH6112.subject: MATH
MATH6112.name: Advanced Linear Algebra
MATH6112.description: An advanced course in Linear Algebra and applications.

MATH6121.subject: MATH
MATH6121.name: Algebra I
MATH6121.description: Graduate-level linear and abstract algebra including groups, finite fields, classical matrix groups and bilinear forms, multilinear algebra, and matroids. First of two courses.

MATH6122.subject: MATH
MATH6122.name: Algebra II
MATH6122.description: Graduate-level linear and abstract algebra including rings, fields, modules, some algebraic number theory and Galois theory. Second of two courses.

MATH6221.subject: MATH
MATH6221.name: Classical Probability
MATH6221.description: Classical introduction to probability theory including expectation, notions of convergence, laws of large numbers, independence, large deviations, conditional expectation, martingales, and Markov chains.

MATH6235.subject: MATH
MATH6235.name: Stoch Process-Finance II
MATH6235.description: Advanced mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization. Concepts from advanced probability and mathematics are introduced as needed.

MATH6241.subject: MATH
MATH6241.name: Probability I
MATH6241.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes. Topics of this course include measure and integration foundations of probability, distribution functions, convergence concepts, laws of large numbers, and central limit theory. First of two courses.

MATH6242.subject: MATH
MATH6242.name: Probability II
MATH6242.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes. Topics of this course include results for sums of independent random variables, Markov processes, martingales, Poisson processes, Brownian motion, conditional probability and conditional expectation, and topics from ergodic theory. Second of two classes.

MATH6262.subject: MATH
MATH6262.name: Statistical Estimation
MATH6262.description: Basic theories of statistical estimation, including optimal estimation in finite samples and asymptotically optimal estimation. A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of estimation utilized by statisticians.

MATH6263.subject: MATH
MATH6263.name: Testing Stat Hypotheses
MATH6263.description: Basic theories of testing statistical hypotheses, including a thorough treatment of testing in exponential class families. A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of hypothesis testing utilized by statisticians.

MATH6266.subject: MATH
MATH6266.name: Linear Statistical Model
MATH6266.description: Basic unifying theory underlying techniques of regression, analysis of variance and covariance, from a geometric point of view. Modern computational capabilities are exploited fully. Students apply the theory to real data through canned and coded programs.

MATH6267.subject: MATH
MATH6267.name: Multivariate Stat Analy
MATH6267.description: Multivariate normal distribution theory, correlation and dependence analysis, regression and prediction, dimension-reduction methods, sampling distributions and related inference problems, selected applications in classification theory, multivariate process control, and pattern recognition.

MATH6300.subject: MATH
MATH6300.name: Fractal Geometry
MATH6300.description: Hausdorff dimension, box-counting dimension, iterated function systems, continued fractions, number theory, Julia sets.

MATH6307.subject: MATH
MATH6307.name: Ordinary Diff Eqns I
MATH6307.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of ordinary differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, normal forms. First of two courses.

MATH6308.subject: MATH
MATH6308.name: Ordinary Diff Eqns II
MATH6308.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, and normal forms. Second of two courses.

MATH6321.subject: MATH
MATH6321.name: Complex Analysis
MATH6321.description: Complex integration, including Goursat's theorem; classification of singularities, the argument principle, the maximum principle; Riemann Mapping theorem; analytic continuation and Riemann surfaces; range of an analytic function, including Picard's theorem.

MATH6337.subject: MATH
MATH6337.name: Real Analysis I
MATH6337.description: Measure and integration theory. Topics include measures, measurable functions, integration and differentiation of measures.

MATH6338.subject: MATH
MATH6338.name: Real Analysis II
MATH6338.description: Topics include Lp spaces, Banach and Hilbert spaces, basic functional analysis.

MATH6341.subject: MATH
MATH6341.name: Partial Diff Eqns I
MATH6341.description: Introduction to the mathematical theory of partial differential equations covering the basic linear models of science and exact solution techniques.

MATH6342.subject: MATH
MATH6342.name: Partial Diff Eqns II
MATH6342.description: This course covers the general mathematical theory of linear stationary and evolution problems plus selected topics chosen from the instructor's interests.

MATH6421.subject: MATH
MATH6421.name: Algebraic Geometry I
MATH6421.description: The study of zero sets of polynomials: algebraic varieties, regular and rational mappings, the Zariski topology.

MATH6422.subject: MATH
MATH6422.name: Algebraic Geometry II
MATH6422.description: A continuation of Algebraic Geometry I.

MATH6441.subject: MATH
MATH6441.name: Algebraic Topology I
MATH6441.description: Simplicial homology. Chain complexes and acyclic carriers. Simplicial approximation. The exact homology sequence. Maps of spheres. Mayer-Vietoris sequence.

MATH6442.subject: MATH
MATH6442.name: Algebraic Topology II
MATH6442.description: Continuation of MATH 6441. Singular homology. Local homology and manifolds. CW complexes. Cohomology. Duality in manifolds.

MATH6451.subject: MATH
MATH6451.name: General Topology
MATH6451.description: Introduction to topological and metric spaces. Continuity, compactness, convergence, completion. Product and quotient spaces. Elementary homotopy.

MATH6452.subject: MATH
MATH6452.name: Differential Topology
MATH6452.description: Manifolds. Differentiable structures. Tangent bundles. Embeddings and immersions. Maps on manifolds. Transversality. Morse-Sard Theorem. Vector bundles.

MATH6453.subject: MATH
MATH6453.name: Geometric Topology
MATH6453.description: Characteristic classes, Morse theory, three-manifolds, four-manifolds, symplectic and contact manifolds, knot theory.

MATH6455.subject: MATH
MATH6455.name: Differential Geometry I
MATH6455.description: Core topics in differential, including: Lie groups, curvature, and relations with topology.

MATH6456.subject: MATH
MATH6456.name: Differential Geometry II
MATH6456.description: Introduces students to topics of current interest in geometry.

MATH6457.subject: MATH
MATH6457.name: Geometry and Topology I
MATH6457.description: The course is an introduction to the fundamental group, covering spaces and techniques used to describe and study differentiable Manifolds and smooth functions.

MATH6458.subject: MATH
MATH6458.name: Geometry and Topology II
MATH6458.description: Introduction to differential geometry and (co) homology.

MATH6514.subject: MATH
MATH6514.name: Industrial Math I
MATH6514.description: Applied mathematics techniques to solve real-world problems. Topics include mathematical modeling, asymptotic analysis, differential equations and scientific computation. Prepares the student for MATH 6515.

MATH6515.subject: MATH
MATH6515.name: Industrial Math II
MATH6515.description: Applications of mathematical techniques from MATH 6514 to solve real-world problems. Group projects to solve industrial problems in topics chosen by the instructor.

MATH6580.subject: MATH
MATH6580.name: Intro to Hilbert Spaces
MATH6580.description: Geometry, convergence, and structure of linear operators in infinite dimensional spaces. Applications to science and engineering, including integral equations and ordinary partial differential equations.

MATH6583.subject: MATH
MATH6583.name: Integral Eqns&Transforms
MATH6583.description: Volterra and Fredholm linear integral equations; relation to differential equations; solution methods; Fourier, Laplace, and Mellin transforms; applications to boundary value problems and integral equations.

MATH6584.subject: MATH
MATH6584.name: Special Functions
MATH6584.description: Gamma function; exponential function; orthogonal polynomials; Bessel, Legendre, and hypergeometric functions; application to singular ordinary differential equations; and separation of variables for partial differential equations.

MATH6635.subject: MATH
MATH6635.name: Numerical Meth-Finance
MATH6635.description: Basic numerical and simulation techniques used in the pricing of derivative securities and in related problems in finance. Some programming experience required.

MATH6640.subject: MATH
MATH6640.name: Num Meth-Part Diff Eqns
MATH6640.description: Introduction to the implementation and analysis of numerical algorithms for the numerical solution of the classic partial differential equations of science and engineering. Must have knowledge of a computer programming language, familiarity with partial differential equations and elements of scientific computing.

MATH6641.subject: MATH
MATH6641.name: Adv Num Meth-Pt Diff Eqn
MATH6641.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for nonlinear partial differential equations including elliptic, hyperbolic, and/or parabolic problems. Must have knowledge of classic linear partial differential equations and exposure to numerical methods for partial differential equations at the level of MATH 6640 or numerical linear algebra at the level of MATH 6643.

MATH6643.subject: MATH
MATH6643.name: Numerical Linear Algebra
MATH6643.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of the classic problems of linear algebra including linear systems, least squares, Singular value decomposition, eigenvalue problems. Crosslisted with CSE 6643.

MATH6644.subject: MATH
MATH6644.name: Iterative Meth-Sys Eqns
MATH6644.description: Iterative methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations including Jacobi, G-S, SOR, CG, multigrid, Newton quasi-Newton, updating, and gradient-based methods. Crosslisted with CSE 6644.

MATH6645.subject: MATH
MATH6645.name: Numerical Approx Theory
MATH6645.description: Theoretical and computational aspects of polynomial, rational, trigonometric, spline, and wavelet approximation.

MATH6646.subject: MATH
MATH6646.name: Numer Meth: Ord Diff Eqn
MATH6646.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for initial and two-point boundary value problems for ordinary differential equations.

MATH6647.subject: MATH
MATH6647.name: Numeric Meth:Dynamic Sys
MATH6647.description: Approximation of the dynamical structure of a differential equation and preservation of dynamical structure under discretization. Must be familiar with dynamical systems and numerical methods for initial and boundary value problems in ordinary differential equations.

MATH6701.subject: MATH
MATH6701.name: Math Meth-Appli Sci I
MATH6701.description: Review of linear algebra and ordinary differential equations, brief introduction to functions of a complex variable.

MATH6702.subject: MATH
MATH6702.name: Math Meth-Appl Sci II
MATH6702.description: Review of vector calculus and its applications to partial differential equations.

MATH6705.subject: MATH
MATH6705.name: Modeling and Dynamics
MATH6705.description: Mathematical methods for solving problems in the life sciences. Models-based course on basic facts from the theory of ordinary differential equations and numerical methods of their solution. Introduction to the control theory, diffusion theory, maximization, minimization and curve fitting. Math majors may not use this course toward any degree in the School of Mathematics.

MATH6710.subject: MATH
MATH6710.name: Numerical Methods-CSE II
MATH6710.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms widely used in computational science and engineering. Numerical linear algebra, linear programming, and applications. Crosslisted with CSE 6710.

MATH6711.subject: MATH
MATH6711.name: Numerical Methods-CSE II
MATH6711.description: Efficient numerical techniques for solving partial differential equations and large-scale systems of equations arising from discretization of partial differential equations or variational problems in applications in science and engineering. Crosslisted with CSE 6711.

MATH6759.subject: MATH
MATH6759.name: Stoch Process-Finance I
MATH6759.description: Mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization. Concepts from probability and mathematics are introduced as needed. Crosslisted with ISYE 6759.

MATH6761.subject: MATH
MATH6761.name: Stochastic Processes I
MATH6761.description: Discrete time Markov chains, Poisson processes, and renewal processes. Transient and limiting behavior. Average cost and utility measures of systems. Algorithms for computing performance measures. Modeling of inventories, and flows in manufacturing and computer networks. Crosslisted with ISYE 6761.

MATH6762.subject: MATH
MATH6762.name: Stochastic Processes II
MATH6762.description: Continuous time Markov chains. Uniformization, transient and limiting behavior. Brownian motion and martingales. Optional sampling and convergence. Modeling of inventories, finance, flows in manufacturing and computer networks. Crosslisted with ISYE 6762

MATH6767.subject: MATH
MATH6767.name: Sys-Computation Finance
MATH6767.description: Computational Finance Introduction to large scale system design to support computational finance for options, stocks, or other financial instruments. Some programming experience, and previous exposure to stocks, bonds, and options required. Crosslisted with ISYE 6767

MATH6769.subject: MATH
MATH6769.name: Fixed Income Securities
MATH6769.description: Description, institutional features, and mathematical modeling of fixed income securities. Use of both deterministic and stochastic models. Crosslisted with ISYE 6769.

MATH6781.subject: MATH
MATH6781.name: Reliability Theory
MATH6781.description: Reliability systems and related distributions, failure rate functions and nonparametric classes, accelerated life testing, dependent failure analysis, statistical inference of reliability data. Crosslisted with ISYE 6781.

MATH6783.subject: MATH
MATH6783.name: Financial Data Analysis
MATH6783.description: Fundamentals of statistical inference for models used in the modern analysis of financial data. Crosslisted with ISYE 6783.

MATH6785.subject: MATH
MATH6785.name: The Practice of QCF
MATH6785.description: Case studies, visiting lecturers from financial institutions, student group projects of an advanced nature, and student reports, all centered around quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with ISYE and MGT 6785.

MATH6793.subject: MATH
MATH6793.name: Adv Topics in QCF
MATH6793.description: Advanced foundational material and analysis techniques in quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with ISYE 6793.

MATH7012.subject: MATH
MATH7012.name: Enumerative Combinatoric
MATH7012.description: Fundamental methods of enumeration and asymptotic analysis, including the use of inclusion/exclusion, generating functions, and recurrence relations. Applications to strings over a finite alphabet and graphs.

MATH7014.subject: MATH
MATH7014.name: Advanced Graph Theory
MATH7014.description: Advanced topics in graph theory. Selection of arguments varies every year.

MATH7016.subject: MATH
MATH7016.name: Combinatorics
MATH7016.description: Fundamental combinatorial structures including hypergraphs, transversal sets, colorings, Sperner families, intersecting families, packings and coverings, perfect graphs, and Ramsey theory. Algebraic and topological methods, applications.

MATH7018.subject: MATH
MATH7018.name: Probab Combinatorics
MATH7018.description: Applications of probabilistic techniques in discrete mathematics, including classical ideas using expectation and variance as well as modern tools, such as martingale and correlation inequalities.

MATH7244.subject: MATH
MATH7244.name: Stochastic Calculus I
MATH7244.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. First of two courses.

MATH7245.subject: MATH
MATH7245.name: Stochastic Calculus II
MATH7245.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. Continuation of MATH 7244.

MATH7334.subject: MATH
MATH7334.name: Operator Theory
MATH7334.description: Theory of linear operators on Hilbert space. Spectral theory of bounded and unbounded operators. Applications.

MATH7337.subject: MATH
MATH7337.name: Harmonic Analysis
MATH7337.description: Fourier analysis in Euclidean space. Basic topics including L1 and L2 theory; advanced topics such as distribution theory, uncertainty, Littlewood-Paley theory.

MATH7338.subject: MATH
MATH7338.name: Functional Analysis
MATH7338.description: Topics include the Hahn-Banach theorems, the Baire Category theorem and its consequences, duality in Banach spaces, locally convex spaces, and additional topics.

MATH7510.subject: MATH
MATH7510.name: Graph Algorithms
MATH7510.description: Algorithms for graph problems such as maximum flow, covering, matching, coloring, planarity, minimum cuts, shortest paths, and connectivity. Crosslisted with ISYE 7510 and CS 7510.

MATH7581.subject: MATH
MATH7581.name: Calculus Variations
MATH7581.description: Minimization of functionals, Euler-Lagrange equations, sufficient conditions for a minimum; geodesic, isoperometric, and time of transit problems; variational principles of mechanics; applications to control theory.

MATH7586.subject: MATH
MATH7586.name: Tensor Analysis
MATH7586.description: Review of linear algebra, multilinear algebra, algebra of tensors, co- and contravariant tensors, tensors in Riemann spaces, geometrical interpretation of skew tensors.

MATH8305.subject: MATH
MATH8305.name: Aural-Oral Engl for Math
MATH8305.description: Enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for SOM international graduate students, post-docs, and new faculty who speak English as their second language (ESL) and who will be teaching undergraduate students.

MATH8306.subject: MATH
MATH8306.name: Intermed Academic Commun
MATH8306.description: Continued enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for current and future SOM graduate international teaching assistants and international lead instructors who speak English as their second language (ESL).

MATH8307.subject: MATH
MATH8307.name: Advanced Academic Commun
MATH8307.description: Continued enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for current and future SOM graduate international teaching assistants and international lead instructors who speak English as their second language (ESL).

MATH8801.subject: MATH
MATH8801.name: Special Topics
MATH8801.description: This course enables the School of Mathematics to comply with requests for courses in selected topics.

MATH8802.description: This course enables the School of Mathematics to comply with requests for courses in selected topics.
